"Is There a Huronion Group?" is the title of a paper recently read before the National Academy of Sciences at Washington by Prof. R. D. Irving of the Wisconsin University.
BOSTON, Dec. 24.--Late last night the jury in the famous Codman will case returned a sealed verdict, and to-day, when the court room was opened a great crowd was present to hear the verdict.

Now that short biographies of American statesmen have become popular, it was very fitting that a life of Jay should be prepared. Jay was one of our worthies, and this not so much, perhaps, for his performances as for his character.

The play, "Fashing's Thursday in Venice," will be presented Tuesday evening in the Metropolitan Opera House, for the benefit of the Industrial School for Poor Girls, in charge of the Ladies' Bikur Cholim Society.

LONDON, Dec. 24.--The British steamer Albany, Capt. Gough, from New-Orleans, which arrived at Liverpool Dec. 21, reports that on the 18th inst., in latitude 50 north, longitude 25 50' west, she passed a disabled four-masted steamer, showing three red lights, sailing in a northeasterly direction.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 24.--Patrolman Cook last night saw a burglar at work and tried to arrest him. He threw something at the officer, which struck him on the head and exploded, fracturing the skull. It is supposed to have been dynamite. Cook is in a critical condition, but may recover.

NEW-DERRY, Penn., Dec. 24.--On the premises of John Cummins of this township are a corn crib and a pig sty, both of which are built of logs. The logs are thickly punctured with bullet holes, and the bullets that made them are still embedded in the logs.

"One thing to be said of real estate in this city," remarked a dealer yesterday in commenting upon the present market. "is that while it may sometimes be dull it can never be weak. As an investment its value increases too steadily to be influenced by ordinary financial tremors.
The incoming vessels continue to report severe gales on the ocean. The steamship Chateau Leoville, which arrived from Bordeaux, had a stormy passage of 16 days.

"There is," said Massimo d'Azeglio, as wisely as epigrammatically, "some instinct of civil war in the heart of every Italian"--of civil war, as he might no less truly have added, based on intrigue and plotting.

MONROETON, Penn., Dec. 24.--Orlando Devine and his brother of this place saw a raccoon put its head out of a hole in a big tree at G.W. Kipp's saw mill the other day. They resolved to capture the animal by cutting the tree down. When the tree fell it struck another large tree, and both fell on the roof of the mill, crushing it in and doing over $1,000 damage to machinery in the mill.

It is an alarming fact, which has been brought to the attention of physicians in Boston in recent years, that deaths from heart disease are six to one as compared to what they used to be 35 years ago.
The Fleetfoot Harriers had a run yesterday, in which the hares, Perry and Ashe, after a five-mile course through Prospect Park, finished first in 43:00.

The toboggan slide at Fleetwood Park, the longest in the world, was opened to the public at 4 P.M. yesterday, in the presence of a large crowd. The first toboggan started was Maud S., John Murphy's pet. Sheriff Grant, in fur cap and fur-trimmed coat, held the reins, so to speak, and behind him were Alfred de Cordova and Frank Hardy, who were also wrapped in furs.

LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 24.--Widow Millett, who for 40 years lived alone in an old cottage near the business portion of the town, died last week. She was very eccentric, and for years no one was permitted to see the inside of her home.

WARRENTON, Ga., Dec. 24.--The Hon. Charles McGregor, one of the most prominent politicians of Eastern Georgia, was shot from an ambush late last night while on his way home. The ball of a 44-calibre pistol entered his right side, and is lodged just under the skin of the left.
A licensed victualer, who is either well read in the classics or simply in Lempriere, has just opened a curious cafe and brasserie in Montmartre.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25.--Martin McGonigle, living at 1,112 Monmouth-street, in the Twenty-fifth Ward, is dying in the Episcopal Hospital from the effects of three gaping wounds inflicted, he said, by a man named Patrick Braceland.

McWillie, and two other young men, were walking on President-street looking at the markets and amusing themselves with horn blowing and ...

Joyce, O. Martaine, R.G. Plummer, H. Percival, C.M. Dietz; apprentices--G. Hayne, J. Bross, --O'Mara, Henry Schaffer.

As a writer on historical themes Miss Julia Pardoe undoubtedly had talents. She was deeply interested in the study, she possessed a lively imagination, she had a capacity for lucid expression, her sympathies were mainly with right things, and she was capable of very hard work.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29.--When you pass over from Norway into Sweden, from one sister country of the Northern Peninsula to the other, the question of their relation each to each is forced upon your mind. You ask how the union between them came to pass, and whether it exists in name only or in deed.

LONDON, Dec. 25.--Discount was quiet during the past week at 2 @1 . On the Stock Exchange business was limited, owing partly to the holidays. The tendency throughout the week was rather downward. American railroad securities were inactive, with a weak tone, owing to the number of sales to liquidate accounts prior to the close of the ...

The Auburn Advertiser thinks "there are significant signs that ex-Gov. Cornell hopes to come to the front once more in politics. He has a firm friend in Congressman Belden. Mr. Cornell has also hundreds of admiring friends among the farmers of the State of New-York, by whom he is regarded as a very earnest and conscientious popular representative."

Last night was a gala night with the Anti-Poverty Society, which filled the Academy of Music to overflowing. Green streamers and wreaths and sheaves of evergreen clung about the boxes and stage. McAuliff's orchestra helped the singers.

The flags on the Barge Office and on the revenue cutters in the harbor were at half mast yesterday out of respect to the memory of exSecretary of the Treasury Manning.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 25.--It is now a settled fact that the rates from Chicago and points West to the St. Paul Winter carnival will be one fare for the round trip.

A tall, lank man, whose rolling gait was evidence that he had been looking upon the cup which cheers and then inebriates, stood for a moment in front of a hardware store on Thirdavenue on Christmas Eve. A tin bath-tub about two feet long had fastened his wavering red eye.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25.--The St. Louis Browns defeated the Chicago White Stockings in a well-contested game at Central Park this afternoon by a score of 6 to 3. Ryan and Carroll battery for Chicago, Foutz and Bushong for Browns. The weather was delightful.

A physician who lives in the northern part of the city is noted for his extreme leanness. He is very tall and thin. Several days ago, during his absence, a match boy called at the house, was admitted, taken into the back office, and the doctor's wife bought some of his stock.

Father Time, passing over New-York at the close of a Christmas day, never strung on his rosary a more gorgeous sun than yesterday's. Its brightness was unimpaired from morning to night, except by the incense from thousands of kitchen fires speaking of the good cheer preparing for the Christmas dinner.

A detailed explanation of an item in the annual report of the State Board of Agriculture --"other expenses, $22,873 66"--would furnish entertaining reading for the holiday season.

John Powell and William Mason, the two Dobbs Ferry burglars, came near escaping yesterday from the White Plains Jail. Powell was sentenced recently to 17 years in Sing Sing Prison, but had not yet been taken there. Mason had not been tried.

LOCK HAVEN, Penn., Dec. 25.--Lloyd McCloskey and a young lady were skating on the river this afternoon, when they broke through the ice. McCloskey was drowned, but the lady clung to the ice until she was rescued. McCloskey's body was recovered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25.--The average Washington Democrat dislikes to read about his anxiety to hold office almost as much as he hungers for office. He and his fellow-office seekers in the District are much disgruntled because comment has been made upon their scramble for the chair of Postmaster Conger, ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 25.--The Chicago theatrical managers had the satisfaction when they closed their houses last night of knowing that the worst week of the season was over, and that it had not been much more trying than usual, though it had been pretty good shopping weather. There were empty seats at all the houses.

The attempt to kill M. Ferry proves that French assassinations are much like French duels. The would-be murderer fired thrice at him, and hit him twice. Either M. Ferry must have the skin of a rhinoceros or the bullets must have been pellets propelled by some powder which had been procured from our Government stores.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 25.--Mrs. Annie O'Neil, a widow, and her little family of three children, two boys and a girl, lived just south of the Hamlet of Rhinecliff, on the main road. She lost her husband about 10 years ago, and in all those years labored hard to keep her little brood together and provide them a decent living.

Traffic between Bergen Point and Elizabethport, N.J., across Newark Bay on the New-Jersey Central Railroad is still blocked by the accident to the drawbridge Saturday evening. The officials except to have the damage repaired Wednesday, but it may take a week.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 25.--At midnight last night the Sheriff of Kenton County, Ky., received a telegram from the tollgate keeper at Erlanger, a village about eight miles from Covington, on the Cincinnati Southern Railway. The telegram read: "Erlanger, Ky., 25. Send officers; bloody riot. Jeff Childers."

George F. Slosson and Frank Ives are hard at work practicing for the coming balk-line billiard tournament at St. Louis Jan. 3. Yesterday afternoon Slosson played 400 to Ives's 165, and the former won in 16 innings, Ives having 103 to his credit.
LONDON, Dec. 25.--The British mission to Abyssinia has returned to Massowah.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 25.--The American Society of Naturalists will hold its annual meeting in Peabody Museum, Yale University, here, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday of this week.

The result of the Government's suit against certain persons connected with the Northern Pacific Railroad Company is neither creditable to the defendants nor reassuring to those who have feared that it would be impossible to prevent the spoliation of timber lands on the public domain.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25.--Alderman John McCormick, the Republican representative in the City Council of the Seventeenth Ward, isn't a very pretty man anyway, but he went home in a cab last evening with much less beauty than usual.

The new and splendid church erected in connection with the recently built Capuchin Convent, near to St. John Lateran, was inaugurated with much pomp on the Feast of the Immaculate Conception. The church is dedicated to St. Anthony of Padua.
The little London weekly called The Academy remains for one reason or another a favorite with savants.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25.--Christmas brings many presents to Mr. George W. Childs, but not nearly so many as he himself makes in his openhanded generosity. The value of his offerings probably exceeds that of similar donations by any other man in the United States.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 25.--Christmas Day was observed by the striking spinners at the Stafford Mill with a discussion of the grievances which had led to the strike, and a consideration of the best plan of action to pursue. There was a full attendance of strikers at the meeting held this afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25.--A passenger train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad ran into a coal train at Third-street and Gray's Ferry Road this afternoon.

The prospectus of a Mausoleum Safe Deposit Company for the Dead has been issued. The scale of rates between the vaults on the lower and upper floors will place this style of a last resting place within the reach of all. The scheme will probably commend itself to those who object to cremation or burial.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25.--After King Kalakaua of the Sandwich Islands had vetoed the bill to abolish the office of Governor and also another measure providing for the performance of such duties as pertained to that office, a call of the House was ordered to consider the vetoes, and fiery speeches were made by Minister of the Interior Thurston, Gen. Ashford, and others.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 25.--The strike of the letter carriers here turned the Post Office upside down. The Christmas mail was heaped in great piles over the tables, in four times as large a quantity as the usual mail, and there were only the four new men to deliver it, ...

This week and next will be the busiest owners and trainers of race horses will have until the weather which permits of active training comes along. Entries to the 28 stakes opened by the Coney Island Jockey Club, and to the 13 opened by the Brooklyn Jockey Club, will all close on Jan. 1.

The Manhattan Club will give a reception early in January to President Cleveland and his Cabinet, Gov. Hill and staff, and all the prominent Democratic statesmen in the country will be invited.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Dec. 25.--Fire broke out in the penitentiary shoe shop last night and the entire structure was soon completely destroyed.

Hospital Sunday was very generally observed in all the churches of the city yesterday. A few churches will not make their hospital collection until next Sunday, however. The subscriptions were very liberal, but the amounts could not be ascertained last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 25.--The tobacco season of 1887 closed here yesterday. The total sales of Louisville for the year amounted to 135,101 hogsheads, the greatest number ever sold anywhere in one year. The sales of Louisville for 1885, "jubilee year." were 126,677 hogsheads.

Bernard David of the Cigarmakers presided at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union. The Balfe Musical Club applied to have the action compelling it to withdraw from the Musical Protective Union rescinded, but was unsuccessful, and was given 30 days in which to withdraw.

J.T. Ford, one of the Nicaragua Canal engineers, was sent to Jamaica in advance of Lieut. Peary's expedition, to select a force of laborers and have them ready on the arrival of the steamer Hondo. Mr. Ford returned here from Jamaica on leave and will sail for Nicaragua Jan. 5. He is a swarthy young Englishman, who has had nine years' active experience in the Public Works Department of Jamaica.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 25.--Carroll McBee, who was taken from Neosho, Mo., to be tried in Cherokee County, Ala., for a murder committed there 22 years ago, has been acquitted. His victim was Capt. Joseph Hardwick.

The week which theatrical managers fear most of any in the year has passed, and with today begins a week which is always looked forward to with pleasurable anticipations. Business during the holidays is regarded as certain to pick up, and when Christmas falls on Sunday, as this year, the prospects of full houses on Monday are reasonably assured in advance.

The family of Alexander Kalenscher, a toy peddler, of 196 Henry-street, were so anxious about him yesterday that they made inquiry at Police Headquarters. No rocord of him was found. He went Thursday last to Yonkers, and one of his sons who went there last evening got no tidings of him. He had little money and a stock of toys.

PEACE DALE, R.I, Dec. 25.--The place is well named. The village is in a dale through which the Saugatuck flows silently and swiftly. Everything about the place betokens a spirit of peace and of thrift. Immense buildings of grayish-colored stone line the banks of the little river.

ODESSA, Dec. 25.--Twelve thousand conscripts of the Autumn draft are assembling here for transportation to the Caucasus. This is regarded as a pacific sign, as, if there were any probability of an outbreak of war, they would be sent to the interior to replace regulars drafted for the frontier.

Chimes filled the frosty air of New-York with Christmas hymns yesterday and, with the deep-toned soloists in the other church belfries, called people to share in the great church festival of the year. The Christmas green was bright in nearly every sanctuary and the Christmas anthem filled the air with harmony.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, in his sermon last night, reviewed the events of the closing year. He was glad, he said, to be able to say that the Knights of Labor were beginning to show self-control and judgment, and employers were beginning to take more interest in the welfare of their employes.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 25.--Miss Annie Cane of Dallas, Texas, was burned to death at Ward's Seminary yesterday. She was in her room, partially dressed, and climbed up in a chair to arrange a picture over the mantel, when her clothes caught fire from the grate.

Working girls found a pleasant afternoon's recreation yesterday in the entertainment which Miss Markstein provided for their amusement and instruction at 80 Fifth-avenue, in the rooms of Cartier's dancing hall.

The Manhattan Temperance Association met in the Cooper Union yesterday afternoon, the Rev. I.K. Funk in the chair. The Supreme Court was complimented on its decision in the Kansas case, and it was asserted that personal liberty must succumb to personal rights.
Joseph Whitty was arrested at 2 o'clock yesterday morning for being intoxicated. He was locked up in a cell in the prison attached to the West Thirty-seventh-street police station.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia,, Dec. 26.--Frank C. McNeally, Saco's youthful bank embezzler, breathes the air of Halifax no longer. At 3 o'clock this afternoon, accompanied by his brother Harry, he took an express train for St. John, where connection is made with railways running into the United States.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Dec. 26.--Mrs. Sarah G. Ewing, age 62, living four miles west of here, was found dead in her barnyard yesterday by her grandson. Her body was terribly mangled by hogs which were with the greatest difficulty driven off. During the absence of her daughter and the latter's husband on Saturday the old lady had gone out to milk. The hogs, it is thought, pulled her down and killed her.

ALBANY, Dec. 26.--Patrick Gallagher, at Malone, began a Christmas drunk Saturday night, carrying a bottle of stimulants home with him. He sat down at a table and drank. On Sunday morning the light was found burned out and Gallagher dead. Paris green covered the floor. It is thought that he took paris green while drunk by mistake.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 26.--Gen. John C. Fremont, accompanied by his wife and daughter, arrived in this city last night. They left New-York eight days ago, stopping two days at Washington on route. The General and family propose to spend the remainder of the Winter in Los Angeles or the vicinity, and while here he will complete his second volume of memoirs.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26.--Edward H. Kendricks, one of the oldest telegraph operators in the country, in a fit of despondency jumped from the Sixth-street bridge about 9 o'clock tonight, and was drowned. He was about 52 years old and had been in the employ of the Western Union Company for over 25 years. His health had been bad for several months, and recently he showed signs of insanity, the result of excessive drinking.
ALBANY, Dec. 26.--William Reid, one of Albany's best-known citizens, is dead, after a brief illness. He was known as "Tax" Reid from the fact that he was always buying tax titles.

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 26.--People in the town of Penn Yan are excited over the discovery of a case of smallpox. A lad named Warren Rudd in some way contracted the disease. The health officers have been notified and have quarantined Rudd's house. The local physicians pronounce it a case of smallpox in the most virulent form. It is the first case in this region for over 30 years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26.--The fateful Begum of Oude and her troubled court looked out this evening at the Chicago Opera House upon the most brilliant audience seen in Chicago in many a year. BALTIMORE, Dec. 26.--Allen M. Clarke, a bookkeeper for L. Shanby Davis of New-York, committed suicide on Christmas Day by jumping down a well on his father's place in Pocomoke City, Worcester County. He had overworked himself and had gone home to rest.

GYPSUM CITY, Kan., Dec. 19.--The real estate excitement which raged fiercely last Summer in many Western towns and cities has in a great measure subsided.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 26.--The polo games at the Casino Rink this afternoon and evening were league games and they were very interesting, though very much one-sided. BOSTON, Dec. 27.--The Boston School Board at its meeting to-night passed an order that the Committee on Accounts for 1888 be requested to include in the estimates for 1888-9 the sum of $20,000 for the support of public kindergartens during the year. It was also voted to secure the opinion of the City Solicitor as to whether additional legislation is necessary before the city can incorporate the Kindergarten method in its system of teaching.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 27.--The little son of Harvey Hevener, while coasting on Fairmount this afternoon, ran into a street car, and was so badly injured that death followed in hour. A companion was terribly cut and bruised. The car driver did not see the sled until too late to stop the car.

The Chicago and Northwestern Railroad's earnings for the entire month of November were officially reported yesterday. The aggregate was $2,650,190 an increase of $287,581. The Omaha Company earned for November $718,932, an increase of $82,452.

NEWPORT, R. I., Dec. 27.--The suit of J. M. Fisk, a prominent New-York Summer resident, against ex-Gov. George Peabody Wetmore, to restrain him from using drains across the lawn of the former's summer residence here, was begun this morning and is still being heard. The court has already granted Mr. Fisk an injunction against one such drain.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 27.--Daniel Stillwell, aged 70, a highly respected citizen of South Pittsburg, Tenn., froze to death last night. He was attempting to make his way home from the Alabama State Line, seven miles distant, and in the face of the first snowstorm of the season. He wandered from the road and perished in a field within calling distance of his own house.

VIENNA, Dec. 27.--The Frembenblatt attributes the present comparative calm to the moderation and love of peace of those Cabinets which the Invalide Russe, the War Office organ in St. Petersburg, would induce its readers to believe are treacherously preparing for war.

CHICAGO Dec. 27.--The inquest on the body of William Macaulley, who was shot by his wife saturday, was held to-day and resulted in the discharge of Mrs. Macaulley. The jury found that he came to his death from injuries inflicated by his wife, who at the time of the murder, was insane and irresponsible for her acts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--Local Assembly No. 10,235, comprising all the men in this city engaged in passenger traffic on the Reading Railroad, including telegraph operators, and numbering over 1,000 men, met to-night, surrendered its charter, and disbanded. They preferred to leave the order rather than obey an order to strike which they expected to receive.

The little people of the Church of the Messiah, at Park-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, saw life under a golden tinge last night, for their Christmas tree festivities were made specially notable by the presence of the only old gentleman in the world who can go to the circus whenever he wants to and have the show just as he wants it.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Dec. 28.--A full investigation into the affairs of William B. Cramer, the ex-Mayor and carriage manufacturer who absconded from here last week, shows liabilities aggregating $20,000, with assets of about $1,500. For months prior to his departure Cramer had been turning everything available into cash.
OTTAWA, Dec. 28.--Senator Shultz of Winnipeg has been appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Manitoba, the appointment to take effect on May 1 next.

Mrs. John Jacob Astor's will was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It was dated June 18, 1886, and is witnessed by Charles F. Southmayd of the old firm of Evarts, Southmayd Choate, (who is said to have drawn it,) and by C.W. Baldwin of Orange, N.J. She names as her Executors her only child, William Waldorf Astor, and Adrian Iselin, Jr. The will is to be probated to-day.

The Knights of Labor in this city are indignant with Mr. Corbin and Superintendent Sweigard, whom they accuse of bad faith. According to their statement the committee of the Knights were given to understand by Mr. Corbin that all the strikers would be taken back to work, and Mr. Sweigard, acting under those instructions, gave the order.

RACINE, Wis., Dec. 28.--Two freight trains on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road collided while backing up to a water tank at Western Union Junction this morning. Both cabooses and several cars were wrecked and burned, the debris taking fire from the cabooses' stoves. Two brakemen were injured by jumping from the trains. Traffic was blockaded for several hours. Loss, $5,000 to $8,000.

Dr. Deems conducted the services. There was a large attendance at the church, including many clergymen. The remains will be taken to Logansport, Ill., today for interment.
ALBANY, Dec. 28.--Special meetings of the Canal and Land Boards were held to-day for the purpose of clearing up some matters before the old State officers retire.

When one considers the temptations to which the Post Office clerks and letter carriers are subject in the handling and delivery of letters which they know contain money, it is not surprising that occasionally one of them falls and is detected in stealing the matter intrusted to his care.

NEW-BEDFORD, Dec. 28.--An instance has occurred here which shows that the old talk of honor among thieves is not wholly imaginary. On the 13th inst., in the Superior Court, Thomas Branigan and James Flynn of Taunton were found guilty of burglary in the houses of Col. Frederick Mason in Taunton and Spencer Borden of Fall River.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 28.--The ship Ida Wilson has been seized by Canadian customs officers opposite San Juan Island. Three hundred sheep and other stock were seized. It is said that smuggling has been systematically practiced in this locality.

The dry goods merchants are making generous contributions to the hospital fund. The following persons have been appointed an auxiliary committee to solicit and receive contributions: Walter H. Lewis, 86 Worth-street; ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--Capt. James W. Pope, Assistant Quartermaster, has been assigned to duty as Commandant of the Military Prison at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., vice Capt. Asa P. Blunt, Assistant Quartermaster, who is, at his own request, ordered to duty at Boston as Post Quartermaster.
At a meeting of the new Board of Directors of the American Jockey Club, held yesterday, the resignation of Judge A.C. Monson as Secretary and Treasurer of the Board was tendered and accepted.

William Mck. Gatchell, the Secretary of the Manhattan Temperance Union, recently wrote to Mayor Hewitt calling his attention to the frequent violations of the Sunday, the excise, and the concert saloon laws and blaming the police for not preventing the violations.

Dwight H. Olmstead, Chairman of the citizens' meeting held at Murray Hill Hotel on Dec. 19 for the purpose of considering a plan to provide the west side with rapid transit facilities, appointed the following committee in pursuance of the resolution adopted at that meeting: Dwight H. Olmstead, Ogden Goelet, ...

ASHLAND, Wis., Dec. 28.--There have been troublesome times at High Bridge, a small station on the Wisconsin Central Road, for some weeks, the employes of the charcoal pits objecting to the presence of the peace officers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--Mr. Stanley Waterloo to-day became managing editor of the Chicago Mail, with practically full control of the paper, thus leaving Mr. Snowden entirely free to devote his time and attention to the Times.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 28.--The strike on the Reading Railroad was renewed at this end of the line to-day with extreme vigor, and every man was ordered out from Elizabethport to Williamsport.
Further railroad earnings for the third week of December were reported yesterday as follows:

When Matthew Byrnes and his son Matthew went to Europe last July they left their large real estate business to be managed during their absence by Ernest H. Adams, a young man who had been in their employ for many years, and who had risen to the position of confidential clerk and bookkeeper.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The Central Traffic Association has authorized Commissioner Blanchard to prepare amendments to be submitted to Congress to amend the inter-State act.

Although no formal caucus of the members of the new Board of Aldermen has been held, it is pretty well understood that Daniel E. GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The whipping that Miss Jennie Baxter, the 20-year-old daughter of Dr. W.G. Baxter, a prominent citizen in Lodi, gave Marvin Phillips, a dashing young school teacher and Harvard man, at Lodi, at the annual Christmas tree exercises, has caused a great sensation in the southern part of Ontario County.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 28.--Adam Martin of Liverpool, Perry County, has been arrested and held in $3,000 bail for defrauding an old soldier named Scyoc out of $1,840 of $3,600 received by Scyoc on account of arrearages of pension. Martin represented himself as a lawyer and succeeded in getting the veteran's confidence.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., Dec. 28.--The color line has been drawn in this ancient Quaker town, which was almost the home of anti-slavery and the underground railway, in a way that has seemed to outrage a portion of the colored population of the place as no previous discrimination against it ever did.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 28.--The completion of the Minneapolis, Sault Ste. Marie and Atlantic Railway to a connection with the Canadian Pacific at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., opening a new short and direct ...

LONDON, Dec. 28.--The strange disturbance in Eastern Europe grows no better day by day. It is still impossible to sift the true from the false in the cloud of rumors about the movements of troops and the preparations for mobilization, and the only sign on which to base comment is the increase in the virulence of the Austrian and Russian papers.
There was a lage attendance at the Christmas reception of the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn at its armory on Clermontavenue, last night. The armory was in "full dress" decoration itself.
The ease with which a Central American Government may still be stolen is a constant temptation to the degenerate descendants of Cortez and his corsairs.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28.--The fifth annual convention of the Modern Language Association began this evening with a public meeting, followed by a reception at the University of Pennsylvania.
READING, Penn., Dec. 28.--A law suit resulting from an odd incident is reported from the village of Sinking Spring, this county. The village undertaker is Adam Huntzinger.
The Sunday-school children of the Church of the Holy Communion, at Twentieth-street and Sixth-avenue, held their Christmas festival yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The last act in the "tripartite" comedy was played very quietly to-day. It was a famous incident in Western railway annals, and the projectors and promoters of the great combination expected and were confident of success.
TORONTO, Dec. 28.--A case is now pending at Osgoode Hall before the official Referee which will probably prove the most sensational one that has been known here for many years.
DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 28.--It is announced that the Duluth and Union National Banks here are to consolidate Jan. 1. The new bank will have a paid-up stock of $1,000,000.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The blast furnace property on Annsville Creek in this village, including the narrow gauge railroad leading from the furnace to the Croft Mine in Putnam County, and the mine was sold at Referee's sale to-day by Franklin Couch, Referee, and was purchased by Lawrence Farrell of New-York, representing Frederick Livingston and W.D. Schoonmaker of New-York and Joseph Cunningham of Paterson, N.J., who represented Senator Jones of Nevada. The price paid was $33,600.
Judge Charles A. Rapallo died peacefully yesterday afternoon, in the presence of his wife and two daughters, at his home, 17 West Thirtyfirst-street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--W.C. Reed of San Francisco, a Government claimant, tells the following story in a petition which was presented to Congress last week and has just been printed by order of the Senate:
PITTSBURG, Dec. 28.--The Western Nail Manufacturers' Association held their regular meeting here to-day.
The cigarmakers in the employ of Crouse Kimball held a shop meeting yesterday afternoon to consider the reduction in prices that the firm had ordered after the beginning of next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28.--The formal decision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission upon the question whether the express companies are subject to the provisions of the act to regulate commerce was announced to-day.
All the Brooklyn police courts had shoplifters among their prisoners yesterday, and Justice Walsh found that two of his were respectable women, the mothers of families and the owners of real estate.

Josef Hofmann, the boy pianist, has been invited to visit Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt on the afternoon of Jan. 14, when he will be entertained by Mrs. Vanderbilt and a few friends, including Chauncey M. Depew.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 28.--The railroads here have decided on raising rates on cypress shingles 40 cents per 1,000 to Cincinnati and points outside of Alabama.
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 28.--Cigaratte smoking numbers another victim in Richard H. Barringer, a popular young man of this city. He was a constant smoker.

The funeral of George T. Coffin, janitor of Tammany Hall and Sergeant-at-Arms of the Tammany Society, was yheld at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning from St. Ann's Catholic Church, in East Twelfthstreet.

The Grand Jury continued yesterday the investigation of the charges made by Forster L. Backus to the effect that money had been paid to certain members of the Brooklyn Board of Education to influence the promotion of Principals in the public schools.

TOROOTO, Ontario, Dec. 28.--George Mann of the Li-Quor Tea Company made an assignment today. His liabilities are $60,000 and assets $40,000. The Central Bank is the principal creditor. The other creditors are tea and book houses in NewYork and England.
The new increased rates on fourth, fifth, and sixth class freights will go into effect on east-bound shipments on Jan. 2. On west-bound shipments the increase will be made on Jan. 9.
The Democratic members of the Kings County Board of Supervisors held a caucus last evening in the County Court House, Brooklyn, and decided to bury John Y. McKane--if possible.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 28.--There was another death this morning among the Italians afflicted with diptheria who were allowed to come through New-York to Baltimore by the loose quarantine system.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 28.--A novel case has been decided by Judge Kenyon. In 1886 Charles G. Mead, of the town of Rochester, held a claim against W.A. Davis, Jr., a dealer in Shawangunk Mountain millstones.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28.--M.D. Babcock, inventor of the fire extinguishing apparatus bearing his name, died at the San Francisco Almshouse Saturday, aged 70 years. At one time he was in receipt of $10,000 a month for royalty on his machines, but after selling the patent rights his money was soon spent, and for some years he wandered about California in a destitute condition. About six years ago he was admitted to the almshouse.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Dec. 28.--The mercury marked 12 below zero this morning. There was a strong wind from the west, and the snowdrifts in the streets were three feet high in places. Despite these obstacles the parade of the Iowa Traveling Men's Protective Association was a marked success.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Dec. 28.--The temperature was 10 below this morning. Trains were late in all directions, and the passenger train on the Illinois Central from the West due at 9:30 last night arrived at 7 this morning. No trains are running between Waterloo and Sioux City.

The so-called Discipline Committee of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, which is to investigate the charges of alleged treachery in several Democratic ward associations at the recent election, met again yesterday in Jefferson Hall.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club held a conference at the club rooms, on Thirtysecond-street, last night to discuss the subject of a national naval reserve. Commodore Canfield introduced Senator W.C. Whitthorne of Tennessee, author of the National Reserve bill of the last session of Congress.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment will to-day take the final vote on the approval of the estimates for the support of the City Government during the second year of Mayor Hewitt's term.

Joseph O'Donnell, who keeps a saloon and hotel at Twenty-fourth-street and Sixth-avenue, and who was bondsman for Alderman Jaehne, was at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer charges of keeping a disorderly house and violating the excise law.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., Dec. 28.--For several days reports have reached here from the White River country that the Utes are off their reservation east of the Utah line, and that they are buying all the rifles and other firearms that they can obtain. Is is feared that an outbreak will soon occur.

ALBANY, Dec. 28.--Fremont Cole arrived at the Delevan House to-night and opened his headquarters in Parlor No. 450. Senator Frank Hendricks of Syracuse will join him late tonight. Assemblyman Ernest Crosby of NewYork will be a third member of the party which will hold the Cole fort till Bald Eagle ...
The second performance of "Euryanthe" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was attended by an audience of goodly numbers.
"F.D.J."--The Crystal Palace in this city was destroyed by fire on Oct. 5, 1858.

LONDON, Dec. 28.--A dispatch from Berlin to the Exchange Telegraph Company says it is stated that Austria, yielding to the pressure of certain friendly powers, has made advances to Russia by which continued peace is assured.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 28.--Race troubles seem to be growing up again. From Lawrenceville and Carrollton comes news which show a bad state of affairs. In the latter place two men made their appearance yesterday, one of whom had the complexion of a Spaniard.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 28.--The State Prohibition Convention closed to-day. Not over 30 persons were present outside of Topeka last night or to-day. About the only thing talked about by St. John and others was abuse of the Democratic and Republican Parties. An effort was made to raise $10,000 to start a Prohibition paper in this city, but it failed, and the subject was referred to the Executive Committee.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 28.--The outlook for a shut-down among the larger steel mills is now very probable. The new scale of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers was received by the Pittsburg manufacturers on Tuesday, and they were very generally discussing it yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28.--George W. Meade Co., one of the largest exporting firms on the Pacific coast, made an assignment this afternoon to Frank Dalton, President of the Produce Exchange, for the benefit of creditors, without preferences.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 28.--Gov. John S. Marmaduke died at the Executive Mansion in this city at 9:40 o'clock to-night after a brief illness. His private secretary, Mr. Yantis; his brother, D.W. Marmaduke, and W.W. Ramsey were at his bedside, with Dr. Young and Dr. Griffin.

It was a bad day for the German Emperor yesterday; Wall-street killed him three or four times; he had too much Teutonic pugnacity to stay killed, however, and the sensational reports that filled Wall-street in the guise of "cable dispatches" served only a passing purpose in scaring some short-waisted speculators into selling stocks and precipitating a little slump.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 28.--It has been satisfactorily proved to Coroner Corwin of this city that the death of Mrs. J. Cassidy was from the effects of a wound she received from the accidental discharge of a pistol in the hands of her son, and not illness, as was stated to the authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--The Daily News, commenting on the reduction of judicial rents in Ireland, says that by one stroke the Government has offended all the landlords and has done nothing to conciliate the tenants.
FARGO, Dakota, Dec. 21.--A few days ago the divorce of Mrs. Pierre Noel of New-York was noted in these dispatches.
ALBANY, Dec. 28.--The Lathrop Memorial, a home for children whose mothers are compelled to work, and a babies' nursery combined, was dedicated to-day.

HAVANA, Dec. 28.--Senor Leon Torres, who was seized by banditti and held by them for a ransom, has been released on the payment of $3,000.

If the Law and Order League had gone about to render the Sunday law ridiculous by enforcing it they could not have chosen an instance more favorable for the purpose than the exhibition of the Architectural League.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 28.--O. Haskins, chief night watchman at the Reformatory, was murderously assaulted in that institution at 5:30 o'clock Monday morning, but the facts were kept quiet till to-night.
Fire broke out early yesterday morning in an unfinished frame building on Orient-avenue, Jersey City, occupied by Miss Jane Brown.

The Police Commissioners are not pleased with civil service reform. Being asked by the Civil Service Board to state how the present system has worked, they have instructed their Secretary to say that they can see no improvement over the old one.

All the trunk lines were represented at yesterday's meeting of their Executive Committee at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday, and Commissioner George R. Blanchard was there for the Central Traffic Association.

Howell, Son Co. of this city have obtained an attachment from Judge Donohue of the Supreme Court against Haynes Rogers, dealers in sugar, molasses, and rice at New-Orleans, for $51,000 for money advanced. Dispatches from New-Orleans say that the Haynes Rogers house has suspended.

The legality of entertainments and exhibitions of pictures on Sunday was considered yesterday by Justice Duffy, in the Jefferson Market Police Court. There were five cases of alleged violation of the law. The first heard was that of the Eden Musee, represented by Frank Reynolds and defended by James W. Monk.
PARIS, Dec. 28.--The Soir says that Gen. Logerot, the Minister of War, is likely to resign soon, as he longs for active military life.
Dr. Ormsby, living at West Houston and Macdougal streets, reported at Police Headquarters yes- terday the particulars of a bold burglary which had occurred at his residence on the previous evening.
ORMOND-ON-THE-HALIFAX, Fla., Dec. 25.-- Perhaps to the average New-Yorker, Ormond-onthe-Halifax is about as familiar by name as the capital of Beloochistan.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 28.--The Stafford Mill was shut down to-day owing to the strike of spinners, but through the efforts of Senator Howard, a promise was obtained from the mill management that the pay would be made right, and the spinners to-day voted to go back to work to-morrow, so the mill will resume in the morning.
BOSTON, Dec. 28.--There was a large gathering of prominent gentleman at the Vendome to-day who had come to attend the annual banquet of the Boston Merchants' Association.
Judge Donohue has "closed out" the last of the elevated railroad schemes which he has fostered, three days before he goes out of office for good.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28.--The Andrew Jackson League, which includes in its membership some of the leading and most respected Democrats in Chicago, proposes to read Samuel J. Randall out of the Democratic Party.
LONDON, Dec. 28.--The Stock Exchange during the afternoon became panicky under persistent reports of the death of Emperor William. This and other bear rumors knocked foreigners down 1 to 1 .
Two hundred young girls, who are attached to the Wilson Industrial School, were made happy yesterday at that institution, in Eighth-street, near Tompkins Park.

Miss Elizabeth M. Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Hill, was married last evening to Thomas F. Somers of this city in St. Francis Xavier's Church, West Sixteenth-street, by the Rev. Theodore Thiry, S.J.
The Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday opened bids for food and fuel to be supplied the department for the coming year.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 28.--The political campaign is waxing warmer every hour. No men have been shot or killed for several days, but the orators of the rival factions indulge in the most acrimonious personalities.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The Ulster County Court has affirmed a decision that a liquid known as "hop bitters" will intoxicate. The case came before the County Court from a Justice's court in the town of Olive.

STILLWATER, Minn., Dec. 28.--While engaged in scraping the ice off the lake on Eau Claire River eight valuable horses belonging to Musser, Sauntry Tozer of this city broke through and seven of them were drowned. Malloy Brothers and McClure have lost three horses by drowning on Snake River, and William Hanson lost four horses near Hayward, Wis. The total loss is not far from $3,000.
ROME, N.Y., Dec. 28.--The trial of Fred Leib for the murder of John Kienlin at Stittville last July, is in progress here. The prosecution has been putting in testimony to-day.

John Smith, 28 years old, employed at Smyth's leather factory, Central-avenue, Newark, was attacked with vertigo last night. He fell into a tanning vat and was drowned before assistance arrived. Smith was unmarried.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 28.--Benson Sewall, only son of Prof. Sewall of the Theological Seminary, was drowned this morning while skating on the Penobscot at Hampden. He was a graduate of Bowdoin College and a student of the Bangor Seminary. He was a young man of much promise, and was known in this State as a lecturer on travels in Europe.
Among the various forms of extravagance that are encouraged by the existence of surplus revenues is that of providing costly buildings for the public service in places where they are not needed.

PARIS, Dec. 28.--The weather of holiday week has turned sharp and very cold, with the effect of clearing the boulevards of cafe loungers and rendering the appearance of the town rather dull. At least it would be were it not for the swarm of toy sellers who are thronging everywhere with the funny puppets of the season.

LIVINGSTON, Ala., Dec. 29.--A landslide on the Queen and Crescent Railroad near this place this morning caught and buried eight cars of a freight train. Two minutes later the south-bound express came dashing along, struck the debris and wrecked two passenger cars, iujuring 16 persons.

Mr. JOHN DILLON, the Irish member of Parliament, has declared in a speech that the reduction of rents made by Lord SALISBURY's commission fully justified the policy of the Nationalists and the plan of campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Mrs. Eunice Bosworth Taylor, wife of Congressman E.B. Taylor of Ohio, died this afternoon of apoplexy at Providence Hospital, where she had been removed on being found unconscious in the street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--An interesting feature of the report of the United States Consul at Sidney upon the rich silver mines of the Barrier Ranges, New South Wales, relates to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company's claim to its mine, now said to be valued at 25,000,000.

CETTINIE, Dec. 30.--The inhabitants of the Zeta Valley are suffering from a famine. The prevalling distress has never been equaled in that part of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--The Modern Language Association held its closing sessions to-day. The morning was taken up with the reading of the more technical papers. Among these was one by Prof. Collitz of Bryn Mawr College, and another by Prof. Sheldon.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--The Albany County Bar held a memorial session out of respect for the late Judge Rapallo to-day, and named Heram E. Sickles, Nathaniel C. Moak, Simon W. Rosendale, Frederick Harris, and Peyton F. Miller a committee to attend the funeral.

Simon Cohen, a City Marshal, was complained of yesterday to Mayor Hewitt by C.H. Merritt, a restaurant keeper at 793 Broadway, for having obtained $10 from him under the threat of having him arrested for selling cigars without a license.
The funeral services of Judge Joseph Bell were held yesterday morning at the Church of the Incarnation, Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifthstreet.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 30.--At 3 o'olock this morning Joseph Seigler, a policeman, shot and killed Abraham Smock, another policeman. Officer Seiglet was patroling his beat when he saw two men leave a residence in the northeastern part of the city, and upon seeing that the officer saw them, the started to run.

PARIS, Dec. 30.--Ex-Colonial Secretary Etienne has written a letter in which he says that the plan for a mixed Government over the New Hebrides is impracticable. A division of the archipelago between France and England he declares to be the only logical solution of the matter.

LONDON, Dec. 30.--Dr. Mackenzie has returned to London from San Remo. He is inclined to take an optimistic view of the German Crown Prince's case.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 30.--A fire which started yesterday afternoon destroyed one-half of the town of Houma, in Terre Bonne Parish. It is believed the conflagration was caused by a defective flue.
Every Brooklyn Mason who dances will don his best clothes next Thursday evening, and, in company with his wife or his best girl, help the members of Kismet Temple make merry.

LONDON, Dec. 30.--To the stories of the concentration of Russian troops in Poland, of which the Times to-day is filled, there are now added circumstantial accounts of a great movement of troops into Bessarabia, all along the Roumanian-Turkish frontiers.

A very peculiar accident caused the derailment and precipitation down a 20-foot embankment of a through freight train of the New-York and Northern Railroad soon after it passed the Lake Mahopac station at 11:20 o'clock Thursday night.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--Judge Amasa J. Parker, as Trustee under the will of Hermanus Bleecker, gave the estate of the deceased, amounting to $130,000, to the Young Men's Association of this city, provided $50,000 additional was raised and a public hall erected.

MARIANNA, Ark., Dec. 30.--Albert Peters was hanged here at 11 o'clock this morning for the murder of William Johnson, near Trenton, this county, in April, 1885. Peters had twice escaped and was recaptured.
WEST CHESTER, Penn., Dec. 30.--Several burglaries have been committed in a mysterious manner in Oxford, this counts, and vicinity, during the past few months.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30.--The merchants of the city held a memorial meeting on 'Change to-day and adopted resolutions expressing the grief of the business community at the death of Gov. Marmaduke.
The Associated Pioneers of the Territorial Days of California will give their annual dinner Jan. 18.

Secretary James S. Lehmaier of the Republican League of the State of New York has sent a letter to the Secretaries of the Republican clubs represented at the recent convention containing copies of the constitution of the League adopted at that convention.

ST. FRANCIS, Ark., Dec. 30.--William Herrig, who murdered his young wife and her paramour near here, Thursday, was hanged last night by a band of vigilantes, who have been on his trail since he fled to escape punishment for his crime.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Dec. 30.--At a special election yesterday it was decided by a majority of 18 votes that Manasquan should be incorporated. The result causes general dissatisfaction among large property owners.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 30.--At a meeting this evening of delegates from all the Democratic committees and clubs of this city and county, called together to discuss improved methods of conducting campaigns, a resolution was unanimously adopted indorsing President Cleveland's recent message to Congress. Official notice of this action was ordered sent to the Senator and Representative from this district and to President Cleveland.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--Superintendent of Insurance Maxwell speaking of the insurance business said to-day: "The past year has been a very disastrous one to the various insurance companies, and the losses have crippled more than one. Very few, if any, companies will show a surplus. The dividends will be small. The year has been a very bad one indeed, the losses being exceptionally heavy."

While Wall-street men were talking yesterday of the books fished ont of the Hackensack River a few days ago Whitehead Suydam, the counsel for E.T. Simpson, sent a statement to President Smith of the Stock Exchange in explanation of the reports that have been circulated in the Street.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30.--The war on the gas trust took a new turn to-day. The attention of the President of the Board of Assessors was called to the fact that gas trust certificates were not exempt from taxation.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 30.--J.A. Hallock of New-York has written to St. Paul parties asking for information concerning William Pritcherd.

Reid, $6,900; Robert Kerr, $2,500; A. Wallace, $4,680; William T. Morgan, $500. He has been in business about 17 years, and in the trade his capital was supposed to be about $20,000.

John Y. McKane, boss of Gravesend and Coney Island and the Kings County Board of Supervisors, is no longer a Democrat--officially. The Kings County Democracy will no longer recognize him or associate with him.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 30.--Music Hall was crowded to-night by Catholics assembled to celebrate Pope Leo's golden jubilee. In addition to Bishop Gilmour's address, speeches were made in English, German, French, Bohemian, Polish, Italian, Hungarian, and Irish by priests in charge of local congregations of those nationalities. A 20word message of congratulation in Latin was cabled to Rome.

ALBANY, Dec. 30.--Robert Burns, manager of the Wheeler Wilson Sewing Machine Company of Gloversville, has eloped with Mrs. Sarah Herrick, employed in the office as bookkeeper. They are believed to have gone to Canada. Burns leaves a wife and five children in destitute circumstances. He was a noted Prohibitionist, and came to Gloversville from Manchester, England, about 15 years ago. Burns is about $1,000 short in his accounts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31.--The situation in this city has radically changed during the night, and it now seems probable that very few Knights fo Labor will return to work on the Reading Railroad this morning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 30.--A terrific snowstorm is racing all over the Northwest today. It started west of Bismarck, Dakota, early this morning, and by noon trains at that place were all behind time, and this afternoon word came that all trains on the Northern Pacific had been abandoned.
OTTAWA, Dec. 30.--At a meeting of the Cabinet to-day it was decided to postpone the date of the opening of the Federal Parliament from Jan. 31 to Thursday, Feb. 23.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30.--The furnace men of this city posted notices today ordering a reduction in wages of 12 per cent. to take effect next month. About 2,000 men will be affected. They are pre paring to resist the reduction and a strike may result.

PARIS, Dec. 30.--To say that all Paris went to the marriage of Maurice Beruhardt with the young and very beautiful Princess Terka would give but a feeble idea of the elegant throng that crowded to overflowing the Church of St. Honore d'Eylan.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 30.--Gov. Beaver to-day issued a proclamation announcing that the total amount of the State debt canceled for the year ending Nov. 30, 1887, amounted to $1,418,511.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 30.--The people of the town of Clarksville, Ind., which is situated about midway between Jeffersonville and NewAlbany, on the Ohio River, are just at present in a great state of agitation from various causes.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 30.--A ministerial blizzard has struck Francis Murphy's temperance ship, but the craft has so far weathered the blast. Mr. Murphy is confident that he will override all opposition.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Dec. 30.--The northwest gale still prevails to-night. The steamer Storm King of Boston carried mails and passengers of Vineyard across the Sound this afternoon, the regular steamboats not being able to run.

Wilburt F. Trevett, manager of a furniture concern at Thirteenth-street and University-place, was summoned to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by John McGinniss, who complained that he was swindled out of $25 in Trevett's place.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30.--Schiessinger, the defaulting manager of the firm of Moss Co. of NewYork, has, it appears, been staying at the Windsor for weeks. About a fortninght ago he was joined by a young lady who is said to be his wife. She left for Toronto a few days ago, and he intended to join her last night, but missed his train.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30.--The book and job printers' strike has terminated, and the defeated strikers are slowly returning to work.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30.--President Corbin was in the city to-day attending to business as a Receiver of the Reading, and getting matters in shape to turn the affairs of the company over to the stockholders.

A post-mortem examination was made yesterday on the case of Jessie White, who died in the house of Mrs. Thomas Smith, a midwife, at 189 Stagg-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District. Coroner Lindsay decided that death was caused by malpractice.
A young lady residing up town in one of the cross streets near Fifth-avenue lost $15, which dropped from her pocketbook one afternoon last week.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 30.--George E. Gardner was killed in a horrible manner yesterday. He had driven into town from his place at Springdale, and in the afternoon started to drive home.

NEWPORT, Penn., Dec. 30.--A few days ago Frank Hess, Assessor of the Second Ward, York, came to this village to visit Miss Mamie Kauffman, to whom he was to be married on New Year's Day. Yesterday he was hitching up a horse to take Miss Kauffman out driving. The horse kicked him in the breast, killing him almost instantly.

The city demands $45 from August Plath for obstructing the streets. Plath had two iron posts in front of his place, and persisted in keeping them there until five complaints were made. Corporation Attorney Boyd took the case before Justice Claney 10 days ago.
LONDON, Dec. 30.--For a fortnight past Mr. P.T. Barnum's agent, Mr. Starr, has been in close communication with the Directors and managers of the Paris Hippodrome, now at the Olympia, London.

OIL CITY, Penn., Dec. 30.--This evening at 7 o'clock a mixed train on the Pittsburg and Western Road, composed of seven freight and two passenger cars, went through a trestle near St. Petersburg and was precipitated to the bottom of a gully, a distance of 30 feet.

Assistant District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll took official leave of his chief, District Attorney Martine, yesterday, and removod all his personal effects from his office in the General Sessions building.

Yesterday's session of the court of inquiry at the Brooklyn Navy Yard proved to be a field day for Pay Inspector Stevenson. He was on hand himself with evidence which rudely disturbed for the time being the sleepy serenity of the court.

There has been little to disturb the peace and prosperity of the churches, either at home or abroad, the past year. The only controversy which attracted general attention in this country was that which has been going on several years among the Congregationalists respecting the teachings at Andover Theological Seminary.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 31.--Arrangements are under way for celebrating the centennial of the county of Madison in June next.

Dr. Justin Herold, who has been deputy to Coroner Messemer for three years, retired yesterday and will devote himself to his private practice. His place will be taken by Dr. W.A. Conway of 157 East Broadway, who was deputy under Coroner Kennedy up to three years ago. The reason assigned for the change is that Tammany Hall wanted the place for Dr. Conway, Dr. Herold was the youngest Deputy Coroner who ever held the office.

Here is a Bob Toombs story: There was a Democratic caucus one night when he was on top of the heap here, but, having been intoxicated with the exuberance of his own verbosity or something else, he was unable to stay till the end.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 31.--Michael Kiss, a Hungarian, was run over and fatally injured just below the South Norwalk station at 5 o'clock this afternoon. One leg was cut off and several bones were broken. He resided in Whistle Valley.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 31.--In the Fifteenth Senatorial District, in the last election, Senator Cassatt was found to be elected by 9 votes over ex-Secretary of State Young. A total error of 13 votes was soon after discovered and the Governor ordered a new election in the tainted precinct.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 31.--The failure of McCartney, Kenny Co., upholsterers and furniture and carpet dealers, this city, is announced Judgments amounting to $15,000 were entered this morning. There are other liabilities, chiefly to Philadelphia creditors, of several thousand dollars. The firm hones to settle with its creditors in full.

The Board of Excise Commissioners has just completed its annual report. It shows a large apparent decrease in the number of drinking places in the city. A great many reformative suggestions of both a liberal and restrictive character are made, in which President Woodman differs materially from his two colleagues.

Henry Lockwood, aged 75 years, was found by Mrs. Julia Hart of 143 West Fourthstreet dead on the lower steps of the house 141 West Fourth-street about 9 o'clock Friday night. He had evidently succumbed to heart failure, consequent upon old age.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31.--Col. McCaull's friends here were very much annoyed when they learned to-day that there had been printed in New-York this morning a sensational dispatch from Chicago in which it was alleged that the Colonel came very near dying yesterday from an overdose of bromide.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The Hon. Douglass Boardman of this city retires from the Supreme Court bench to-day, as his term of office expires. He was first elected to the Supreme Court Nov. 7, 1865, taking his seat Jan. 1, 1866.

The Erie Railway will change the time of several of its trains, both local and through, at noon to-day. The most important through change is the adoption of a fast Rochester express, which will leave this city at 7:45 P.M.,

Ex-Senator Platt is figuring in the courts of New-Jersey as a neglectful Executor. The estate involved is that of his sister-in-law, Mary E. Platt, who was the wife of his brother, William H. Platt of Metuchen. She had property worth about $25,000.

PARIS, Dec. 31.--France continues to keep very calmly occupied with her own knitting, and, to read the papers and listen to general conversation, one would scarcely dream of these furious threatenings and war alarms across the Rhine and Alps. How long this placidity can be...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--The report of the Pacific Railroad Commissioners had been nibbled so thoroughly before it was published entire that little surprise was manifested over its contents here. The vigorous assault upon the management of the roads by ex-Gov. Pattison was considered more spirited, however, than the hitherto published sketches had led people to believe that it would be.
William Steinitz, the chess champion of the world, will give a simultaneous exhibition against all comers at 3 this afternoon at the rooms of the Columbia Chess Club, 1 Second-avenue.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31.--The floor of the Corn and Flour Exchange to-day was the scene of a mask carnival, which afforded lots of fun to the frolicsome young brokers and their lady friends, who occupied seats in the centre of the room.
The Bench and Bar were largely represented at the funeral services of Judge Rapallo, in the Forty-second-Street Presbyterian Church yesterday morning.

Experience at Fleetwood Park during the past week has been varied with the America's Winter carnival people. Since their opening the misunderstandings with the weather have been mended. The storm did not ruin the slides, and the condition of the toboggan chutes is such that the managers of the enterprise are satisfied with their undertaking.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 31.--North and south bound Cannon Ball trains on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad collided to-day at 1 P.M. at Summit, Ky., about 20 miles north of the Tennessee and Kentucky State line.

HICKSVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 31.--Fire broke out this morning in the centre of town, in one of the frame business blocks, and before it could be checked at all had wiped out the greater part of the the town.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 31.--Immanuel Presbyterian Church, one of the finest edifices in this city, was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. Nothing but the bare stone walls are left. Loss, $100,000; insurance, $85,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--Capt. Rudolph G. Ebert, Assistant Surgeon, has been relieved from duty at Fort Custer, Montana Territory, and ordered to report for duty at Fort Pembina, Dakota Territory.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 31.--The cold wave reached this section early last night. This morning the temperature is reported below zero...

At about 7 o'clock on Thursday evening four coal barges at the foot of East Seventyfourth-street and East Seventy-sixth-street were broken loose from their moorings by the Sound steamer City of Brockton, which was passing on her way up the Sound. Barges No. 1,802 of the Pennsylvania Coal Company and No. 2,151, belonging to the Delaware and Hudson Company, broke loose first.

Every Carthusian is, in fact, practically a hermit, with just a little more accommodation than the traditional hermit usually had.

The death of William Hude Neilson, which occurred Friday at his country seat near Far Rockaway, is widely lamented in this city. In whatever he undertook he became prominent. His business life was exceptionally active and he enjoyed great popularity and esteem in the commercial and financial world.

Henry E. Gregory of New-York City has been appointed Secretary and Treasurer of the State Board of Niagara Park Commissioners. He takes the place of David Gray of Buffalo, who has been made Secretary of the Park Commission of that city.

QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 31.--When the British steamer Lord Gough was tugged into the harbor to-day, she listed so heavily to port that the onlookers were in terror lest she should capsize.

At the annual meeting of the Ohio Society, held on Nov. 29, a subscription list was opened for the purpose of securing money for a building to be fitted up with clubrooms, restaurants, , to take the place of the cramped quarters occupied by the society at present at 236 Fifth-avenue. At once $10,000 was subscribed, and much has been added since then.

The New-York Live Stock Mutual Benefit Association is in difficulties. It is not an organization of quadrupeds, as its name would imply, but of the owners of live stock, who are banded together for the purpose of insuring themselves and each other against loss by the death of their live stock.

ALBANY, Dec. 31.--The Bald Eagle has been angry ever since he read the morning newspapers. He seldom loses his temper, but to-day he boiled over. He had seen in them some unpalatable truths, which at this stage of the canvass were damaging.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 31.--There were two things in connection with the will of Mrs. John Jacob Astor of New-York, viz.: The fact that she did not remember any Newport churches or societies in her will, and also the disposal of the Astor villa at this place, which occasioned no surprise.

ALBANY, Dec. 31.--Gov. Hill will receive the public generally in the Executive Chamber between 12 and 1 o'clock Monday, and personal acquaintances at the Executive Mansion from 2 until in the afternoon.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 31.--Mrs. James Brown Potter appeared here this evening to a crowded house. The play was "Romeo and Juliet." The audience was very enthusiastic and called her before the curtain several times. Mrs. Potter is socially very popular here, having very many friends in Plainfield's upper society.
The annnal meeting of the National Rifle Association takes place Tuesday evening, Jan. 10, in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory.

When Mortimer Thompson, familiarly known in the journalistic world a few years ago as "Doesticks," died he left among his effects a number of interesting souvenirs in the shape of engravings and photographs of distinguished actors and other notable people.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31.--In accordance with the instructions of their local assemblies at their meetings Friday night the majority of the Knights of Labor, freight handlers, stevedores, and trainmen on the Reading lines in this city, which had not already struck, refused to go to work this morning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 31.--It has been snowing here all day with a strong wind blowing and the result is a bad blockade. The worst of the storm is in Southern Minnesota and Dakota, and northwest from here there is very little serious delay of trains.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 31.--On Saturday, June 20, 1884, a son of Michael Eagan, who was watching some cattle pastured on the Cornell place, Darien, removed a board which covered an old well, and peering down discovered a pair of boots protruding from the water.
William H. Kelly, who up to to-day was Civil Justice in the Sixth Judicial District, yesterday appointed Philip Abern to be Clerk of that court, and Abram Bernard to be assistant clerk.

During the year there have been begun in the United States Circuit Court 125 common law suits, exclusive of the suits against the Collector of the Port. Of these 109 have been tried and disposed of. In the equity branch 281 suits were begun and 61 heard on motions for injunctions.

Bernard Nussbaum, of 244 East Seventyfirst-street, went home to his dinner at noon on Wednesday, and having disposed of it, kissed his wife and his 10-year-old boy a cheerful goodbye, going back, as they supposed, to his place of business at 1,492 Second-avenue, where he has been engaged for six months bottling beer and selling it to a large number of customers.
The celebration of the golden jubilee of Pope Leo XIII. in the priesthood was begun yesterday, the exact date of the anniversary, in a few of the Catholic churches belonging to religious orders.

The Fire, Health, and Police Departments were stirred up yesterday by Capt. Thomas Ryan of the Twenty-first Precinct in regard to the propped-up building 449 Third-avenue, which is next door to the Third-Avenue Theatre, and is occupied by Patrick Meaney, a liquor dealer.

Dr. Thomas E. Cone, a well-known Brooklyn physician, and his wife Mary, the daughter of the late William Gray, a wealthy sulphur manufacturer, were in Justice Courtney's court yesterday, the former as a defendant and the latter as a plaintiff in a charge of assault. Dr. and Mrs. Cone live in the large brownstone house 271 Ninth-street, and have three children.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Dec. 31.--Two men were killed in the Jackson mine at Negaunce this morn ing by being blown up with a charge of blasting powder. They were working near an old charge which had been put in a week ago and failed to ex- plode, when it went off without warning, killing both instantly. The men were James Knucky and George James. Knucky's head was blown off completely.

NOGALES, Arizona, Dec. 31.--News has been received stating that a small band of Apaches are roaming in the mountains in the Moctezuma district, killing and stealing. A number of travelers have been waylaid and shot on roads entering Bavispe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1.--Speaker Carlisle hopes to be able to announce the standing committees of the House on Wednesday, when Congress reassembles. He has been hard at work upon them, and has some of the places still to fill, but the most difficult part of his task has been completed.

Bishop Potter visited Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning, preached to the patients and employes in the amphitheatre, and confirmed six persons. The Rev. Henry St. George Young, the Chaplain of the hospital, read the morning service.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association has prepared a new proposition, or rather revamped an old one, on the mileage question, and has sent it out to the managers of the association lines for their vote on its adoption.

The children of the Sunday school of the Five Points House of Industry held their New Year's services yesterday afternoon. On one side of the platform the little girls sat on tiers of low seats, and on the other were the small boys, clean, bright, and neat, with a special snowy gloss on their wide turn-down collars.

For the first time in a year and more Jorome-avenue was practically deserted yesterday, even by the oldest drivers. Col. M.J. O'Brien, Superintendent of the Southern Express Company, gave an elaborate dinner at the St. James Hotel Saturday evening in celebration of his fifty-third birthday.

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--The publication in THE TIMES on Dec. 13 of the names of 2,600 persons who were entitled on unclaimed dividends from certain of the failed savings banks formerly in New-York City has resulted in directing the attention of a large number of those persons to the fact that there were sums of money ...

The review of the work within the churches of the various denominations during the year just passed, which we printed on Sunday, may be properly supplemented by a survey of the tasks achieved or attempted and the tendencies shown by the Christian Churches as a whole.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1.--Stephen Conroy and Patrack O'Donnell were drinking together for some hours last night at the home of the former, and about midnight a quarrel took place, in which O'Donnell was badly beaten and thrown out of the house. Shortly after he was found unconscious in the street and taken home, when he charged Conroy with assaulting him.

Hugo Ohlhorst of 331 East Sixth-street was in a very unhappy frame of mind yesterday. He was to have been married at his father's house on Saturday night to Miss Rose Scherer, the pretty daughter of Christian Scherer of 319 East Sixty-first-street.

VIENNA, Jan. 1.--The Official Gazette is of the opinion that the Czar's consenting to the publication of the forged documents sent to him relative to Germany's policy tells mightily in favor of the maintenance of peace.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 1.--Shortly after 7 o'clock this evening, while two men were crossing the Dodgetown Bridge, in this city, they quareled, and one of them pushed the other into the flood, which was quite high at the time.

LONDON, Jan. 1.--During the past week there was an active demand for discount at 2 to 2 . The Stock Exchange loan rate to the next account is 4 to 4. Business on the Stock Exchange was very limited. The tone was good, except for foreigners, which were dull under the political outlook.

Through the generally prohibition weather yesterday afternoon enough believers in cold water traveled to the meeting of the Manhattan Temperance Association to fill the big hall of the Cooper Union, where the Rev. Joseph Cook of Boston was to talk about "Sunday or the Saloon; Which Must Go?"

There were several fires in New-Rochelle on Saturday night and early Sunday morning, one or two of which are believed to have been of incendiary origin. One house, owned by A.B. Hudson and occupied by the Rev. Robert Patterson, of the Baptist denomination, in Webster-avenue, took fire from a defective fine on Saturday night and was burned to the ground with most of its contents.

While a Fourth-avenue car was passing the corner of Fourth-avenue and Fourteenthstreet at 9 o'clock last night one of the horses became entangled in a length of telephone wire which had fallen from its fastenings on the roof of the German Savings Bank across the electric light wires.

At the Columbia Chess Club last night 18 men sat side by side in front of as many chess boards. Their brows were wrinkled and their hair rumpled, and while they studied and made moves cautiously a little man, about 5 feet high, would walk from one table to the other and, playing against each man with rapid moves, would pass on to the next.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1.--The bark Carlton, which arrived yesterday from Maryport, England, reported the rescue of the Captain, mate, second mate, and five of the crew of the German bark Johanna, who had been three days and four nights in an open boat. Last Friday there appeared in one of the morning papers the following announcement: "The engagement is announced of Mr. Walter Phelps Dodge to Miss Lily Stokes."

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 1.--A special from Sedalla to-night says that an order has been sent over the entire Gould system requesting that the force of employes in all departments be reduced 10 per cent. at once.

The golden jubilee of Pope Leo XIII., the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood, was celebrated in all the Catholic churches of the city yesterday, except the few that held the observance Saturday evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1.--Baseball circles are much interested in the efforts being made by the American Association to fill out its circuit with an eighth club. President Pennypacker and the Directors of the Athletic Club are in favor of having a club in New-York City, to be run by the Association, ...
With a merry chime, one that came not from Trinity bells, but from clinking glassware, the Veteran Firemen welcomed the new year at their rooms in East Tenth-street Saturday night.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 1.--When the present campaign opened and the office holding section of the Democratic Party set about securing their tenure for another four years by re-electing the incumbent Governor they found themselves weakened by an important defection.

Something very like romance was crowned yesterday by a marriage in Brooklyn. For some years the name of William Morris Davene has been well known in the circus arena as belonging to a trapeze performer and athlete of unusual grace and agility who was invariably accompanied in his "acts" by one whom every one supposed was his sister.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 1.--Dispatches from points along the Hudson Valley to THE TIMES'S correspondent state that the storm of the past 24 hours is one of the severest experienced in years.
