One of the New-York friends of Secretary Lamar has received a letter from that gentleman relating to the approaching dinner of the Southern Society in this city and incidentally referring to various matters of mutual social interest. Mr. Lamar touches lightly on the violent opposition manifested in some bloody shirt quarters to his confirmation as a Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

The Rev. Hugh O. Pentecost, who resigned from the Bellevelle-Avenue Congregational Church, Newark, because the congregation were not ripe for his advanced ideas on the issue of the day, opened his Unity Congregation in Library Hall, Newark, last night.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 1.--The New Year smiled upon the rivermen. For many months they have been waiting and hoping for a rise that would permit them to supply the cities down the Ohio with coal. When, a few day a ago, the rivers began to freeze over they almost gave up hope.
The fourth anniversary of the night work in Manhattan Chapel of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission was held yesterday in the chapel on Twenty-sixth-street, opposite Bellevue Hospital.

On last Wednesday evening a family reunion took place at Hampton, Ontario, in which there were present both patents, Mr. and Mrs. Ruse, hale and hearty, and their 13 sons and daughters, the youngest of whom is 22.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1.--Trouble is brewing among the interested lines over the recent transportation of the National Opera Company eastward from Chicago.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 1.--The Sixtyeighth General Assembly will convene to-morrow morning, and the indications strongly foreshadow a big political wrangle at the opening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--Ex-Gov. Joel Parker of New-Jersey, while visiting friends at 1,019 Mount Vernon-street, this city, yesterday, was stricken with paralysis and died at 1 o'clock this morning.
The funeral services of Charles B. Gedney were held at 1,564 Broadway yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Stephen Merritt of James-Street Methodist Church officiated.

ROME, Jan. 1.--The pontifical mass to-day was a great success. Thousands of people thronged St. Peter's-square early in the morning awaiting the opening of the Cathedral. Sixty thousand admission tickets had been issued, and the cathedral was packed.
The tug Cynthia No. 2, Capt. Haines, of Philadelphia, arrived here yesterday from Savannah with the schooner Helon A. Chase in tow.
The immigrants at Castle Garden received their New Year's dinner yesterday, at the expense of the Commissioners.

Many lives were imperiled in a beer hall on Third-avenue Saturday night. As it was a number of people were injured, one probably fatally.
BOSTON, Jan. 2.--About a year ago the Boston Cremation Society was formed. A capital stock of $25,000 was to be raised for the purpose of constructing a crematory.

A large crowd surged about the entrance to the Equitable Gas Works all yesterday afternoon, being kept out only by the vigilance of several policemen. A half score of men were busy clearing away the wreckage and replacing broken windows, and by to-day most of the evidences of the explosion will have disappeared.

Several hundred shivering mortals went to Coney Island yesterday. They wanted to take a look at the work of removing Brighton's big hotel from the embrace of the greedy ocean. Only about 50 men were found at work, and these did not seem to be doing much.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 2.--Early yes terday morning the dead body of Harry Freeman was discovered by Charles Jones lying near the Connecticut Valley Railroad track in Cromwell. Dr. Calef, being summoned, removed the body to Freeman's home.

LONDON, Jan. 2.--The cable dispatch which Dr. McGlynn read at the Anti-Poverty meeting in New-York last night, surprising as it may seem, did correctly report Cardinal Manning's words. They occur in a little article at the end of the Fortnightly, sent in answer to some recent stricture by the London Times on recent utterances of his Eminence.

There were only two classes of people in town who did not have a chance to get a square meal without cost yesterday. They were the tramps and prohibitionists.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 2.--The Journal will announce to-morrow that Mr. M.A. Low has been appointed President of the Rock Island system west of the Missouri River, and that this appointment is a recognition of Mr. Low's earnest work to increase the mileage of the system in Kansas and Nebraska.

Augustus Lauterbach, who resides at 69 East Sixty-sixth-street, was riding an 8-year-old horse of reputed quiet disposition, from Cohen's Riding Academy, upon the bridle path on the west side in Central Park yesterday, when the horse took sudden fright and started on a run.

A Connecticut girl who went to Southern California early in the Fall for her health's sake writes home that she is well again, and, what's further cheerful news, she has, by a real estate investment near Los Angeles, netted a profit of over $5,000.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 2.--The annual election for Directors of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia was held today. Fifty-six thousand shares in the total of 75,000 were voted.

District Attorney Martine entered his office for the last time 10:45 yesterday morning and found his successor, Col. Fellows, and the latter's staff, together with nearly all the attaches of the Generel Sessions building, in possession.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 2.--Until this afternoon it was decided that Eugene Higgins would be the next Clerk of the House of Delegates.

Mrs. Lucy A. Saveant, 6 Alling-street, New-Haven, through Judge Sheldon, appears before the Tax Commission to have $257.75 taxes paid refunded. She is a Pequot descendant, and the Legislature said in the fifties that all such should be exempt from taxation.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 2.--John Blythe, a prominent Baltimore and Ohio Railroad coal operator, notified his managers this morning of a reduction of 5 cents per ton, to take effect at once.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--United States Senator Philetus Sawyer of Wisconsin, who was in Chicago to-day on his way to the Capitol, said: "Lamar is a much better man for a Supreme Justice than any one else that could be gotten from his district.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The third New Year in the term of the present Administration has come and gone, and, like the two which preceded it, it was in all respects a notable holiday. Fair weather, extremely fair even for Washington, followed two of the most dismally-unpleasant days of the season.

PESTH, Jan. 2.--Herr Trefort, Minister of Public Instruction and Ecclesiastical Affairs, has sent a letter to the Catholic Primate of Hungary advising that radical reforms be made in priests' seminaries, and that the smaller seminaries be abolished.

Those who do not like Wagner are loud and frequent in their denunciations of "Tristan and Isolde." They say it is not pretty, and this is obviously true. But so is "Medea" not pretty, and "Hamlet" and "King Lear;" yet men have gone to see them acted and have been the better for it.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 2.--Robert Hamilton, an old resident of Long Branch, was found Sunday morning lying in an outhouse, terribly beaten and bruised.

A new theatre is in process of construction in Brooklyn, Eastern District, and will be ready for opening some time next month, when it is expected, that the National Opera Company will be its first tenant, if that organization manages to weather the storms which are constantly besetting it until that time.

On Sunday, Jan. 1, the new schedule of rates adopted by most of the large livery stable men of this city, in consequence of the demand for increased wages on the part of their employes, went into operation.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 2--To-day the City Government which is to have charge of the city's affairs during the coming year was inaugurated. The new City Council was qualified shortly after 10:30 A.M., and the Mayor proceeded to deliver his address.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--During the rush for front seats in the gallery at the Arch-Street Theatre to-night Thomas O'Brien, a 22-year-old resident of Germantown, fell over the rail of the gallery. He landed on the back of a chair in the parquet circle, and was fatally injured.
The steamship Chatean Leoville brought to this port on the 24th ult. forty-two Arabs who were genererally admitted to be paupers.
Walter Damrosch will gave a symphony concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this evening.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2.--The largest and most impressive funeral procession which this city ever saw escorted the remains of the murdered Commissioner of Police, Patrick Mealey, this evening from his home on Annunciationstreet to the tomb on Metarie Ridge.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Fremont Cole of Schuyler County was formally nominated for Speaker of the Assembly of 1888 by the Republican caucus this evening. Contrary to general expectation, ex-Speaker Gen. James Husted of Westchester was a candidate against him in the caucus.
The Fleetfoot Harriers held their twelfth paper chase of the season yesterday from the clubhouse, on Ninth-avenue, Brooklyn.

The old and the new Aldermen met yesterday, the former at 10:30 A.M. and the latter at noon. The last act of the old board was to receive a veto from Mayor Hewitt of a resolution authorizing the payment of $225 for engrossing the resolutions of regret on the death of the late Peter B. Masterson, who represented the Nineteenth Assembly District in the board.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 2.--In Mayor Winslow's inaugural address to-day reference was made to the prospective establishment of a college for women in this city near the site of Clark University.

NEW-BRIGHTON, Penn., Jan 2.--One of the most daring robberies ever perpetrated in Beaver County occurred this morning about 2 o'clock, at the residence of the Rev. Father Bigham, Pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church of this place.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 2.--A general courtmartial order has been issued from the headquarters of Gen. Miles fixing the sentences of the five regularly enlisted Indian scouts who mutinied at San Carios last June, and fled to the mountains, where they remained until returned by the troops. They are sentenced to two, ten, fifteen, and twenty years' confinement at hard labor at Fort Leavenworth.
The meetings for the week of prayer, which are under the auspices of the Evangelical Alliance, were exceedingly well attended yesterday afternoon.

After a visit to Paris of six months, the poet Louis Frechette returned last week to his home at Nicolet, Quebec. We gather from French-Canadian journals that his last reception in France was of the warmest nature.
Frau Hedwig Niemann-Raabe began a series of 14-performances at the star last evening. She appeared before a large and friendly audience in "Dorf and Stadt," by Frau Borch Pfeiffer.

Politicians and ministers were about the only people in Brooklyn yesterday who received callers in anything like the old-fashioned general way. The houses in all the fashionable quarters were closed and little baskets were tied to the bell handles by bands of ribbon.
We publish this morning a letter from "a citizen of Michigan," that contains in compact form a most vigorous and conclusive argument against the present tariff system.

S.C. Reynolds of Toledo, whose firm is the largest of all the Western shippers of grain to this market, has been spending the holiday season in the East, having just ended a personal inspection tour over most of the Winter wheatgrowing section of the country.

ROME, Jan. 2.--The Italian papers say that Mr. Gladstone will treat with the Vatican for its support in the efforts being made to obtain autonomy for Ireland, Mgr. Persico having begun the negotiations.

LONDON, Jan. 2.--The British ironclad Hercules touched a reef off Ferrol, Spain, today and knocked a hole in her side. All efforts to stop the leak failed, and the ship with difficulty reached the harbor of Ferrol, where she is gradually sinking.

New Year's Day, contrary to all precedent, was bright and sunshiny, instead of muggy and miserable. This, however, was probably due to the fact that yesterday was not the 1st of January, but the 2d, and being Monday besides, the sky was bound to be blue in order to remain in harmony with tradition.
Boarding Officer James O. Ellery has compiled a list of vessels of various nationalities that arrived in this port during the past year.

VIENNA, Jan. 2.--The Fremdenblatt denies on authentic information that the movement of Russian troops and war material to the frontier continues. The latest news shows that the recent reports concerning the Russian movements referred mainly to displacements effected within the frontier provinces.
The New-York Historical Society will hold its annual meeting this evening at the library, at second-avenue and Eleventh-street.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 2.--The brigantine Alice, Capt. Saunders, arrived at Locke Port from Turk's Island to-day with nothing but her lower masts standing.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 2.--A large number of New-York society people are now enjoying a round of Winter sports at Lenox.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Jan. 2.--At Lebanon, Linn County, Saturday night, John, age 9 years, and Mabel, age 7, the only children of John Ralston, a banker, were burned to death in the bathroom of the family residence. The mother had just left them, when a lamp exploded, filling the room with flames. The mother, in attempting to rescue the children, was badly burned, but it is believed she will recover.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 2.--To-day was a big day for Ohio sporting men, who were here in large numbers to witness the grand live bird tournament at the fair grounds, between AlBandle of Cincinnati and Rolla Heikes of this city and Capt. Bogardus and Jack Winston.

The Federal Republican Club, an organization of young men formed about three months ago, with George Kenneth as President, opened its new clubhouse, at 284 Court-street, Brooklyn, yesterday.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 2.--The question as to whether the miners would go to work tomorrow or remain idle until a new basis could be formulated was the chief topic throughout the coal region to-day.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 2.--Judge D.P. Vinton of the Tippecanoe Circuit Court to-day rendered a decision in favor of the plaintiff in the case of Falley against the Central Union Telephone ...

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--It is reported that Gov. Hill will appoint Judge Cullen of Brooklyn to succeed the late Judge Rapallo of the Court of Appeals. F.R. Coudert, E. Ellery Anderson, and Judge Brady have all declined the appointment, just as the Governor expected and hoped they would.
Capt. Boringe of the ship Antoinette expected to pass New Year's Day on the seas, but instead spent the major portion of it in the United States Marshal's office waiting for ball.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 2.--A gang of Lane County Kuklux has just been broken up by the arrest of all but one. James Vanderine, Nelson English, and P.S. Galloway were brought to the city by a United States Marshal and lodged in the county jail.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--Without any formalities whatever the Reading Railroad Company to-day passed out of the Receivers' hands and into the control of the stockholders.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday made public a voluminous report on quarantine abuses, the report having been made by a committee of physicians of the New-York Academy of Sciences, appointed at the suggestion of Health Commissioner Bryant.

There was a lively party Saturday night in the rooms of Mamie Whalen in the tenement house 500 West Thirtieth-street. Patrick Donohue and Patrick Shaughnessy were very persistent in their attentions to their hostess.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 2.--Judge Irwin of the County Criminal Court to-day charged the new Grand Jury in the tally-sheet forgeries, for refusing to investigate which he so sharply scored the late jury.
STRAUSSTOWN, Penn., Jan. 2.--So many school children of this village are prostrated and have died with diphtheria that the schools have been closed. The disease is epidemic here.

Miles, the Rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Reformation, at 130 Stanton-street, who disappeared mysteriously last Friday afternoon, and was last seen wandering aimlessly along Essex-street later in the day.

MARLBOROUGH, Mass., Jan. 2.--The Boston Ideal Colored Troubadours and Jubilee Singers troupe gave a sacred concert at the Town Hall in Hudson last evening, and took up a collection in order to enable its members to get out of town. They claim that their manager, S.A. Prince, has departed and left them without funds. The troupe has been on the road about two months.

Lord and Lady Dalhousie were buried in the beautiful churchyard at Cockpen, Midlothian, which is within a short distance of Dalhousie Castle, which has belonged to the Ramsays since the twelfth century. Col. Ramsay was chief mourner for his nephew and Lord Bennet for his sister.

Jerome B. Wheeler, who has just retired from the firm of R.H. Macy Co. in order to give his personal attention to his interests in the West, last evening entertained at his residence, 47 East Fifty-seventh-street, the buyers and heads of department of that house.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Jan. 2.--A sharp shock of earthquake was felt here this morning at 7:30 o'clock. During the last three months there have been seismic disturbances throughout the country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2.--The sixtyeighth General Assembly of Ohio convened today, with the Republicans in full possession by a large majority in both branches. In the House the work of organization passed off in the best of order and general good feeling prevailed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--The report of Mr. C.B. Morton, Commissioner of Navigation, is a compendium of information relating to the shipping not only of the United States but of the world.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2.--The possibility of a shortage in supply of coal and consequent increase in prices to be demanded by the Chicago Coal Exchange prevented the happy inaugural of the new year in the mind of many a householder which the season demanded.
The eccentric engineers and other Knights of Labor have circulated a story about careless management in the insane asylum on Ward's Island.
ATHOL, Mass., Jan. 2.--C.W. Knowlton, a real estate broker of Brooklyn, N.Y., was to-day held in $5,000 for the alleged embezzlement of $2,600 from Eva. Grace, and Samuel Simmons.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2.--The death of ex-Gov. Parker was unexpected in this city, and there is general sorrow over the event. Gov. Green is in communication with his family regarding their wishes concerning the funeral, and if they wish the body will lie in state at the State House and a military escort will be furnished to the grave.

Charles Regansberg, a truckman, and Dennis Galvin, a longshoreman, engaged in a drunken quarrel at 7:30 o'clock on Sunday night, during which Regansberg drew a penknife and cut Galvin's right ear off. Galvin was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital, where his remained but a short time after his wound was dressed. Yesterday morning Regansberg was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court. Justice Smith held him in $300 bail for examination.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 2.--The answer of W.R. McKeen in the Vandalia, Hamilton and Dayton deal was filed in the United States court to-day. It is very voluminous, and sets forth in detail the negotiations between himself and Mr. Ives, and flatly denies the most important assertions made by the Hamilton and Dayton people.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2.--Four men were seriously injured by an explosion in B.H. H. G. Cramp's brass foundry, at the northeast corner of York and Thompson streets to-day.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 2.--Coroner Irving has just received word from the Captain of Little Beach Life-saving Station that the body of the mate of the steamship Tonawanda, who with a seaman was drowned yesterday, was found on the beach there to-day. No mention was made of the steamship, and it is believed she has proceeded to New-York under sail.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--Gov. Hill's reception to the public to-day was attended by a larger number of people than that of a year ago, and was nothing extraordinary at that. When the doors were opened a delegation of the Washington Rifles, a remnant of the old Twenty-fifth Regiment, filed in, and drawing up in line before the Governor, who were his accustomed black, bore down upon him with a flank movement.

SAN REMO, Jan. 2.--The Crown Prince of Germany shared in the amusements of his family circle yesterday. Private theatricals were given, in which Prince Henry and Princess Victoria, his childen, took part.

WINCHESTER, Va., Jan. 3.--Lieut. Charles C. Rogers, United States Navy, was married this morning in the Episcopal church in this city, to Miss Alice Walker, daughter of Gen. John G. Walker, ex-Confederate, late of Texas, and now in South America. The family resides near Winchester.

LONDON, Jan. 3.--The Admiralty contradicts the report that the iron-clad Hercules struck a reef at Ferrol, Spain, and was sinking in that harbor. The Hercules is stationed at Portland, and she has suffered no injury of any kind.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3.--A few months ago Mr. "Sam" Allerton, the big packer, grabbed 20 feet of the Chicago River and to-day Judge Garnett decided that he had a right to it.

The New Year's Subscription Ball at Delmonico's last evening was one of the most successful of its kind. The limiting of each of the 100 subscribers to seven invitations apiece made it exclusive, considering its size.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 3.--Up to 11 o'clock this morning Gov. Hill could, independently of the Senate, have appointed a successor to Judge Rapallo on the Court of Appeals bench. He did not do so, and he authorizes the statement that he will not nominate Judge Rapallo's successor until next week.
PROSPECT, Ohio, Jan. 3.--Col. J. Holmes Grover, who has been advertised to deliver his war lecture in the Opera House here to-night, narrowly escaped instant death this afternoon.

VIENNA, Jan. 3.--Official declarations of a decidedly pacific character are expected at an early date. Col. Zuleff, who has returned to his duties as military attache to the Russian Embassy, says he found the Czar absolutely opposed to war. The Emperor will receive Col. Zuleff to-morrow.

Jacob Sharp retured from his health trip to the country yesterday. It has evidently been decidedly beneficial to his somewhat feeble health. On arriving here he went to his resi dence at 354 West Twenty-third-street. Though somewhat fatigued by the journey, he was feeling quite well last evening.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Jan. 4.--The lowering of the mercury in thermometers late last night and early this morning caused ice men to have fresh hopes. NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 4.--The steam yacht Mohican, bound for the Bahama Islands, encountered a gale off the Virginia capes Monday and put in for Hampton Roads. WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The President has sent to the Senate the following nominations: Postmasters.--Melville M. Folsom, Old Town, Me.; William G. Stone, Machias, Me.; Charles R. Jameson, Antrim, N.H.; Alfred E. Jaques, Wilton, N. H.; Joseph W. Goodwin, Wolfborough, N.H.;
The New-York City Woman Suffrage League met last night at the residence of John W. Lovell, 4 Lexington-avenue.

Dr. James 0'Reilly of 247 West Fiftyninth-street was deprived of his right of membership in the New-York County Medical Society last November because of practices that the members of the society deemed unprofessional. He didn't like being bounced, and says so in a legal fashion.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5.--Intelligence was received in the city to-day of, a disastrous railway accident on the Canadian Pacific Railway, a few miles west of White River.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 5.--The Marie Greenwood opera company played "Faust" at Massillon, Ohio, last night and disbanded. The members left for New-York City.

John Gray, a builder, living at 272 Thirteenth street, Jersey City, complained to Chief Murphy yesterday morning that he was beaten and robbed of all his money Monday evening by an gang near the corner of Grove and Fourteenth streets.

The charges of swindling made by the Swedish lad, Frederick Frederickson, against W.S. King and William Moore. Jr., of Alice King's United States Employment Agency, were carefully examined into yesterday by Justice O'Reilly.
Among the passengers by the Cunard steamer Etruria, which arrived on Sunday from Liverpool, was J.W. Emerson, a young Englishman.
LONDON, Jan. 5.--It is now known that the wreck near Waterford was the American ship Alfred D. Snow, Capt. Willey, which left San Francisco Aug. 31 for Liverpool.

The Western railroad companies have raised the basis of their share of passenger rates from NewYork to San Francisco from $50 to $6O on limited tickets. This will cause an advance of $10 in the through rates taking effect on Jan.15. Nevertheless the through rates to Portland, Oregon, will be reduced $5.

Twelve lawyers rose and bowed to Surrogate Ransom yesterday when he called for the appearances demanded by Rosalie Butler in,opposition to her claim that the will of Mrs. Cornelia M. Stewart be revoked and a new apportionment of the great estate be made in accordance with the petitioner's ideas of right.

PARIS, Jan. 5.--The Bourse was utterly upset to-day owing to the failure of a large operator who had been a persistent bear in Rio Tinto mining shares and had a large account open for a rise in other stocks.

Nicholas W. Peacs, formerly in the employ of the Old Dominion Steamship Company and a class leader and Sunday school teacher in the Duane Methodist Episcopal Church, who has been in Ludlow-street Jail since Nov. 29, having been arrested ...

Mayor Hewitt has been looking up temporary quarters for the city's Chief Magistrate preparatory to turning his rooms in City Hall over to the plumbers, sewer builders, gas fitters, carpenters, painters, and renovators.

Terence J. Murtha, a detective in the Cashier's office at the Custom House and a brother-in-law of ex-Collector--Murphy, was suspended yesterday by Collector Magone on charges which amount to overoffiiousness.

Leonard Kaber, an aged German tailor, and his wife were found yesterday in the bed room of their little house, at 94 Harmon-street, Brooklyn, almost dead. Both had been beaten with an iron bar which lay on the floor, and blood covered everything.

The Bachelor Circle of the Liederkranz gave its annual ball last evening at the ball of the society. It was the first German-American society ball of the season, and was an unusually brilliant affair.
Aldermen Divver, Storm, and Fitzsimmons for Tammany, and Aldermen Oakley, Clancy, and Mooney for the County Democrats met yesterday to settle the patronage question.

BERLIN, Jan. 5.--The exchange of views between the Austrian and Russian Governments continues. The aim is to arrange a concurrent declaration of the pacific policy of both Governments. Official circles are more hopeful for the maintenance of peace.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 5.--A man giving the name of O.L. Hackett, and about 35 years of age, was found dead in bed in a room at the St. Charles Hotel yesterday.
The trial of the case of Annie Real against Adam Wagner for $10,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage oocupied the time of Judge Depue, in Newark Circuit Court, yesterday.
The long-expected presentment of the Kings County Grand Jury was handed in to Judge Moore in the Court of Sessions, Brooklyn, yesterday.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Jan. 5.--Owing to the ice in the Danube and the heavy snowfall in Bulgaria the European mail due here on Monday has not yet arrived.

John Y. Mckane, who was recently expelled from the Kings County Democratic General Committee for treachery to the Democratic candidate for Assembly in the Twelfth District at the last election, took his second dose of medicine yesterday when the now Board of Supervisors assembled.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 5.--The House and Senate met at 11 o'clock this morning, and the two branches went into joint convention at 12 M.Gov. Oliver Ames and Lieut.-Gov.
Miss Sadie C. Preston, daughter of William R. Preston, was married last evening, at the residence of her father, 27 West Forty-eighthstreet, to Dr. H. Seymore Houghton.

The Board of Managers of the Produce Exchange yesterday appointed a committee to consider plans for the new building which is to be erected on land owned by the Exchange adjoining its present structure.
Nineteen passengers on the steamship Ludgate Hill had reason to feel grateful when that vessel was made fast at her pier at Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.
W.H. Chippendale, the actor of old men in the old Park Theatre, New-York, and the old Haymarket, London, died in London yesterday aged 87. "Old Chippendale," our grandfathers called him.
The inaugural dinner of the new Reform Club will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on Jan. 21. Covers will be laid for 400, and already more than half of the tickets have been taken.

Sanitary Inspector Moreau Morris, who is especially detailed to look after schools and institutions, called the attention of the Board of Health to the fact that he finds that from some cause there is always a certain percentage of absence from the various schools on account of illness of the pupils.
George Work and several of his friends were discussing athletic matters in the corridor of the St. James Hotel the other evening, and the talk turned upon running.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 5.--Intelligence received at the rooms of the American Board here shows that the Turkish Government is revising its school laws, with the aim of suppressing American and other foreign schools.
The steamer Tonawanda is not yet in port. The report that she had been towed in on Wednesday night by the tug B.T. Haviland, which had been sent in search of her, was erroneous.
The anniversary of the battle of New-Orleans is to be made the occasion for a demonstration by the County and District Committees of the County Democracy.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 5.--Levi S. Fulton, Superintendent of the New-York State Industrial School, formerly the Western House of Refuge, today tendered his resignation of that position, which he has held since 1870, to take effect April 1.
LONDON, Jan. 5.--The steamship Persian Monarch, (Br.,) Capt. Bristow, from New-York Dec: 18, arr. at Hull to-day.

The Board of Electrical Control, which is charged with the work of placing the telegraph, telephone, and electric light wires of this city under ground, will meet in the Mayor's office at noon to-day to discuss and adopt the first annual report of the commission since its reorganization under the Subway act of 1887.

The navy yard court of inquiry resumed the taking of testimony yesterday. Jules Remond, a clerk in the General Storekeeper's office, testified that the commandant of the yard had appointed a commission to estimate the weight of 400 old tanks which were sold at one of the auction sales in question.
An actor's duty isn't always the pleasant and jolly one it seems to be. Peter Goldrick of Harrigan's company found that out last evening.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 5.--The order of the Minnesota Railroad Commissioners touching the matter of sleeping car berths has not amounted to very much up to this time.
Treasurer John V. Scott, at the Coffee Exchange's annual meeting yesterday, in his report for 1887, put the regular receipts for the year at $18,246,19.
There his long been an opinion in maritime circles that steam or some other motor will eventually supplant or drive sail craft to the wall to transatlantic business.

A little treatise, but an interesting one, was issued yesterday by President Orr and the Lord Committee of the Produce Exchange. It was due to a communication from the Societe Commerciale, Industriele, and Maritime of Antwerp, complaining of the quality of the lard received from this country.
The following additional amounts from the hospital collection were received yesterday by the Treasurer, Charles Lanier of 17 Nassaustreet:

ROME, Jan. 5.--The Pope said mass at St. Peter's to-day for the benefit of the pilgrims remaining in the city. Thirty-four Cardinals and 189 Archbishops and Bishops were in attendance at the service, while the congregation consisted of 20,000 persons.
BOSTON, Jan. 5.--A call is issued to-day for the sixth annual meeting of the National Law and Order League, which will be held in Philadelphia Feb. 21 and 22.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--Speaker Carlisle to-day announced the committees of the House. They are as follows:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 5.--William P. Howells, one of the oldest mine bosses in the Wyoming region, was killed in Murray shaft this morning. In trying to save a miner from a falling roof he was caught himself and buried beneath a mass of rock and coal.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5.--The eight Senators that bolted the caucus nominations made last Saturday night have issued a lengthy address, in which they defend their course in smashing the caucus slate by combining with their political opponents.

John E. Moors, Landing Agent at Castle Garden, has issued the following annual table showing the number of immigrants landed at Castle Garden during 1887, and also the number of cabin passengers brought to this port by the different transatlantic steamship lines:

On the suspicion of being implicated in the death of William J. Hanna, who returned intoxicated to his home, 493 West Twenty-secondstreet, last Monday night, and died shortly after of wounds about his head, five boys were arrested on Wednesday night by Inspector Byrnes'e detectives.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5.--Two daring highwaymen knocked down Miss Harper, the daughter of a prominent resident of the east end, and relieved her of her pocketbook this morning in open daylight and in sight of at least a dozen people.
The Societe Francaise L'Amitie gave its fifteenth annual masquerade ball at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House last night.

NYACK, Jan. 5.--"Prof." James Ettinger is a fraud, a swindler of the worst type, who is operating in towns along the Hudson River. He struck the northern portion of Rockland Counts this week, but was not successful in anything except in getting discovered and than "skipping" out in the quickest possible time.

Dutch methods of doing things are regarded by some people with undeserved contempt. But there is one thing that Dutch people have accomplished to perfection, and that is the subjugation of an ocean whose level, in some places, is 40 feet above that of their country.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 5.--Gen. W. T. Withers of this city has sold Tom Hutchison of Veedersburg, Ind., the bay stallion, 5 years, Tecoma, by Alecto, dam Sally Jenkine, by General Knox, for $1,750.
A reception and review were given last evening by the Forty-seventh Regiment at its armory, Marcy-avenue and Rutledgo-street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The Speaker announced the standing committees of the House to-day, and then the House adjourned once more, with the expression of a hope by Mr. Randall that it would on Monday be prepared promptly to take up business of importance to the public interests. Congress has been in session a month.
TORONTO, Jan. 5.--An action to recover $20,000 for alienating the affections of the wife of a prominent young officer in a volunteer corps here is set down for trial to-morrow.
NEW-ORLEANS, La, Jan. 5.--The Democratic primaries in the city today resulted in the election of 56 Nicholis delegates and 48 McEnery delegates.

Central has started the ball rolling among the roads in the Western States Passenger Association. It has always been claimed that the withdrawal of the roads from the association would not result in any change or demoralization in rates so far as the St. Paul roads were concerned.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 5.--A brakeman named Pearson of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad was summoned before General Superintendent Shepard yesterday and accused of stealing railroad tickets.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan 5.--The leading ladies of this city organized a movement for the establishment of a State nurseryp for dependent and destitute children under 2 years of age.
WILKESBARRE,Penn., Ponn., Jan. 5.--A shocking accident occurred at noon to-day on Section 3 of the Pittston branch of the Lehigh Valley Railroad now being constructed.

John P. Foley of 553 West Twenty-sixthstreet, called "Mud" by his intimates, who confesses to having killed Dennis Carney on Dec. 24, 1886, was arraigned before Coroner Levy yesterday, along with the witnesses Martin Curley of 542 West Twenty-seventh-street and John J. Muruhy of 457 West Twenty-seventh-street.

Certain persons who are at present directing the course of the Republican Party should be reminded that the young men who will this year for the first time take part in a national election are not fools.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 5.--A freight train on the New River Division oh the Norfolk and Western Railroad ran into a rock slide 27 miles from Central last night. The engine jumped the track and ran into the New River and disappeared. The engineer was drowned at his post. The fireman was also killed.

LONDON, Jan. 6.--A dispatch from Rome says that advices have been received there from Massowah to the effect that Ras Alula has offered to join the Italians, with 40,000 of his followers, on the condition that he be created King of Abyssinia in the event of the defeat of King John.

A convict named John Kent attempted to escape from the prison at Sing Sing yesterday afternoon as his company was marching in from work. He dropped out of line and stowed himself away in the south foundry, but was found in about an hour and returned to his cell.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 5.--The city lately began the work of building an elevated iron truss roadway 3,000 feet long and 100 high across the Cuyahoga Valley, from Ohio-street to the south and west sides.
BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 5.--Society has for some time been looking forward to the day for the wedding of Miss Edith Johns and Mr. Jesse Tyson.
Arabs were plentiful in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, but they were out of their element. There wasn't a desert in sight in any direction.
Henry Adams of Boston is at the Brevoort House. Mrs. J. Donald Cameron of Harrisburg is at the Clarendon Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--The relations of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen to the Knights of Labor engaged in the strike against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Compang have been definitely explained in a dispatch received in this city from F.S.Sargent, Grand Master of the brotherhood, who resides at Terre Haute, Ind.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 5.--About 8 o'clock last evening the pilotboat Theodore H. Allen was run into and sunk by the British bark Sir William Wallace, at a point nine miles southwest of the Golden Gate.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Jan. 5.--There were no further arrests in the Hamilton murder case to-day. Coroner Vanderveer says he expects important news from his detectives before night.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 5.--C.J. Hamlin, owner of the fast trotting mare Belle Hamlin, with a record of 2:13 today refused an offer of $30,000 for her, made by a party of Cuban gentlemen.
OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 5.--This morning an injunction was served on the State Board of Transportation, issued from the Circuit Court of the United States, in favor of the Union Pacific Railway Company.

Joseph D. Francis, for 13 years in the employ of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company as a special detective, stationed at the company's station in Jersey City, has resigned the position in consequence of his failure to prove a charge of theft which he preferred against John Brennan, the chief doorkeeper at the station.
Entries for the various stakes which closed on Jan. 1 continue to arrive at the Coney Island Jockey Club's rooms in goodly numbers, and the total for the Suburban has now reached 77.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 5.--The Northern Pacific officers are daily receiving complaints from the farmers of Manitoba of their inability to ship wheat to Eastern Canada via the Northern Pacific Road.

BOSTON, Jan. 5.-The Republican State Committee for 1888 organized today by the re-election of the following officers: Chairman-The Hon. Frederick L. Burden of North Attleborough Secretary --The Hon. Robert A. Southworth of Boston; Assistant Secretary--J. Otis Wardwell of Haverhill, and Treasurer--The Hon. Henry. T. Wells, of Cambridge.
DUBLIN, Jan. 5.--At National League meetings throughout Ireland the reductions of judicial rents announced by the Land Commission have been declared insufficient.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The resignation of Cadet Joseph E. Adair, Fourth Class, Military Academy, has been accepted.

The nomination of Mr. Secretary LAMAR to the Supreme Court is one that could be fairly criticised. Whether or not it was the best that the President could make under all the conditions that he felt called upon to observe is a question that is open to discussion.

Archbishop Corrigan has appointed the Rev. Christopher B.O'Reilly of St. Cecilia's Church, in East One Hundred and Sixth-street, Catholic Chaplain to the navy, in place of the Rev. Hugh J. Kelly, who resigned, and is now at Castle Garden.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 5.--The little village of Williamston, situated 12 miles from Lansing, the State capital, is the centre of a most exciting case of family difficulty in which a sick woman is being subjected to a most astonishing and dangerous game of the battledore and shuttlecock variety.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Jan. 5.--The great barbed wire fence monopoly has fought its hardest battle. The patent of Joseph T. Glidden, No. 157,124, issued Nov. 24, 1874, has hitherto been sustained in all legal contests, and the Washburn Moen Company has been enabled, through the aid of the courts, to rule with an iron hand the production of the improved barbed wire in the country.

A public meeting of the National Women's Christian Temperance Association, Department of Sailors and Soldiers, was held at 8 West Fourteenthstreet yesterday.
Something over $130,000 shares of stock made up yesterday's total of transactions on the Stock Exchange. Fluctuations were slight, though there seemed a perceptible tendency to better prices.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5.--The Republican State Committee decided this afternoon that the next State Convention shall be held at Harrisburg on Wednesday, April 25, at 11 o'clock in the morning.

Officers and marines of the navy yard were thrown into a state of excitement at 12:45 this morning by cries fire. They sallied out in a state of undress uniform, and, with buckets, pails, and a few short ladders, went to work to put it out.
The Old Dominion Company's new steamer Manteo left Wilmington, Del., for Norfolk, Va., yesterday and will be put in commission Monday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 5.--Hiram Lodge,No. I.A.F, and A.M., which has attracted so much attention owing to its flight with the Grand Lodge of Connecticut, held its annual banquet and installation of officers to-night.

SACO, Me., Jan. 5.--Harry McNeally took another trip to the provinces to-day. Frank C. McNeally, the fugitive, has not been heard from by the bank officers since his release at Halifax, and they say that they do not know where he now is. It rumored that Harry has also lost track of Frank, and that to discover him to the object of the present trip.
BOSTON, Jan. 6.--Financial and railroad men are confident that something in the line or a big railroad deal is being planned in this city.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 6.--The Receivers of the Charter Oak Life Insurance Company of this city, I.W. Brooks and E.A. Stevens, have been allowed $10,000 as salary for their first year's services.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 6.--Last night burglars broke into Thomas Stack's house at Cumberland Mills. In prowling about the house they awakened Mrs. Stack, who was asleep on a sofa and sick.

NOGALES, Arizona, Jan. 6.--A band of thugs have been operating for some time in Powas Village, Sinaloa. Their last act was the strangling of Senora Vicenta Hernandez, an old lady of that town, for her money. After she had been choked to death the thugs stabbed her twice and crushed her head with an axe and robbed her house of $1,000 the accumulation of 18 years of hard labor.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Jan. 6.--The preliminary examination in the case of the officers of the Yarmouth ship Vancouver, who are charged with brutality to sailors, was begun here to-day.
Herman Boerckel, 22 years old, who lived at 25 Tompkins-avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and instantly killed by Herman Glottschalk at 1 o'clock yesterday morning.
ALBANY, Jan. 6.--A strong pressure has been brought upon Gov. Hill to nominate John Clinton Gray for the Judgeship of the Court of Appeals, made vacant by Judge Rapallo's death.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 6.--It has just been made public that there is at least one person in Minnesota who prefers that the prison should be his home.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Assemblyman Hadley and the clerk of the committee of the Legislature to investigate the alleged excessive rates by telephone companies of this State are here drawing up the committee's report, which will be submitted in 30 days.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 6.--A special panel of 40 was to-day drawn in the United States court of persons reading outside of Marion County, from which to select, the jury to try the "tally-sheet" forgers, who will be called for trial on Jan. 16. The persons whose names were put in the box were equally divided in politics, and of the 40 drawn the slips show 13 Republicans, 12 Democrats, and 15 not indicated.

Capt. Gerry of the bark Levanter, which arrived yesterday from Darien, Ga., sighted the disabled steamer Tonawanda last Tuesday evening. The steamer lay at anchor off the Northeast Lightship, bearing southwest by south 62 miles. She was 80 miles off the coast and dragging her anchor slightly.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Albert T. Flogans, a young man prominent in business and social circles in this town, disappeared last Tuesday night, and is believed to have absconded with quite a large sum of borrowed money and trust funds.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 6.--Harry Hall, a life convict at the State Penitentiary, escaped from that institution last evening and is supposed to have taken the Missouri Pacific train south. He has been an inmate of the institution for several years and has always been considered a "trusty."

ALBANY, Jan. 6.--In the matter of the application to Superintendent of Public Instruction Draper for the removal of Henry Corkey and James Cox as Trustees of Union School District No. 1, town of West Chester, for illegally voting money on a contract for building a schoolhouse before due, the Superintendent has directed that the Trustees named refund to the district $650 within 20 days from Jan. 4, or be removed from office.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 6.--Suit was instituted here to-day against the Louisville, NewOrleans and Texas Railroad for $430,000 damages, claimed to have been sustained by several insurance companies by the loss of over 500 bales of cotton burned in the compresses here about one year ago.
John Mara, policeman of the Thirty-second Precinct, charged by Capt. Cortright with being drunk and mutinous on Jan. 2, was on trial yesterday before the Police Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--There was a full meeting of the House Committee on Elections to-day to agree upon a line of procedure in the Thobe-Carlisle contested election case. The contestant, Thobe, was present with his counsel, Messrs. ...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Yesterday afternoon the community was shocked by the death of John Selfridge, who broke his neck in a fall from a building, and to-day Mrs. Rolland Lee was found in a cistern, where she had committed suicide.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6.--Young Walter Phelps Dodge has left Yale without waiting for the Faculty to act on his case. He has gone home, and it is understood here that he will start for Europe at once.

The County Democracy primaries were held last night in all the 812 election districts in the county. One thousand four hundred and twenty-six members of the County General Committee were elected, every one of them without even the form of a contest.

OTTAWA, Jan. 6.--Inquiries have been made at the Department of Railways and Canals to ascertain what authority there was for the statement upon which Congressman Dingley supported his resolution of inquiry in the American House of Representatives as to the alleged discrimination against American vessels trading through the Welland Canal.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 6.--The Court of Appeals to-day rendered a decision in the appeal of Biscoe, colored, convicted of murdering Capt. R. Dixon in the Potomac River in August, 1886, affirming the judgment of the court below. Biscoe was granted a new trial after conviction and was convicted a second time. After sentence the Governor will appoint the date for his execution at Leonardtown, St. Mary's County.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 6.--The Washburn Moon wire fence people do not seem at all disturbed by the Iowa decision, which an Associated Press dispatch announces will result in all the manufacturers of barbed wire at the West refusing longer to pay royalties to the Worcester corporation.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 6.--Solomon Jacobs, a Hebrew broker and photographer, left this city this noon for New-York to hunt up $4,000 worth of property which has disappeared with his wife and clerk.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6.--George Parkinson, an old soldier, who fought for the Union during the rebellion, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself to a rafter in the woodshed at his home, 3,917 Nice-street, Nicetown.
There is a convent not very far from the heart of New-York City which has always had a select Jewish patronage, the young ladies paying each $1,000 yearly for board and tuition.

Mrs. Frank Dodworth, wife of Frank Dodworth, the proprietor of the dancing academy on Washington-street, Brooklyn, who lives at 536 Clinton-avenue, met with severe injuries as she boarded, Wednesday morning, a car of the Sixth-avenue elevated railroad.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Jan. 6.--The Warren County Grand Jury broke up last night, after a session of four days. During this time the complaints against a number of persons for illegal liquor selling were heard, resulting in the finding of 17 true bills.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 6.--The Tilden Club, the leading Democratic organization in this part of the State, largely composed of active workers and prominent citizens, to-night unanimously indorsed President Cleveland's message, and ordered notice of the action sent to the President and the Senator and Congressmen from his district.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 6.--In Trinity Church this morning the Rev. J.S. Johnston was consecrated Missionary Bishop of Western Texas. The church was crowded to overflowing, and the services were impressive.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 6.--The citizens of Rochester, almost with one accord, hung up their telephones a your ago the 27th of last November and resolved to go without that modern convenience unless the Bell Telephone Company would listen to reason in the matter of charges.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Flora Samuels, the mother of a large family and a dealer in groceries and jewelry, is missing from her home in this city. She is supposed to be in Canada, and is wanted here for forgery. Mrs. Samuels has also lost debts behind her amounting to about $5,000.

NYACK, Jan. 6.--The Grand Army men in this region started in the new year with a reunion that will long be remembered by them. The occasion that called the veterans together was the installation of officers of John Hancock Post of Nyack, and every post in the county was represented.

LAKE CITY, Minn., Jan. 6.--Mrs. Letitia Boves died Wednesday night at her residence in Sugar Loaf Valley, aged 99 years. In her youth she was betrothed to a young man near her Pennsylvania home, whom her parents for bade her to marry, they favoring James Buchanan, afterward President of the United States. It is inferred that Buchanan remained a bachelor on her account.

ROME, Jan. 6.--The Pope has announced that he will receive the Presidents of the English and American Colleges in Rome and the British pilgrims on the 10th inst. Mgr. Clifford will make the necessary arrangements for the reception.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 6.--The dissatisfaction among all classes of operatives over the failure of the manufacturers to grant the advance expected under the promise made over a year ago, although the price of print cloths is considerably above the figure promised in the agreement, is intense, and there is trouble every ...
CATSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 6.--At a number of points along the Hudson River operations on the ice were begun to-day.

The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn's friends in St. Stephen's parish threw down the gauntlet before Mgr. Preston and Pope Leo last night, and resolved that they would never render allegiance or obedience in matters pertaining to politics to any anthority other than the Constitution and laws of the United States.

TRENTON, Jan. 6.--The funeral of ex-Gov. Joel Parker took place at Freehold this forenoon, and the great gathering of people present to pay the last tribute of respect to the dead was evidence of his extraordinary popularity.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Jan. 6.--Hugh R. Robertson, the projector of the big timber raft, arrived here this morning. He says there will be no more timber rafts constructed, but a timber ship will be built, with spars and steering apparatus and provisioned for 60 days. Work on the ship will be begun at once at Joggins.
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 6.--The last wards to be heard from were counted by daylight and the result of the Democratic primaries in this city was found to be 65 for Nicholls and 39 for McEnery.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 6.--While the westbound express on the Lake Shore Railway was running at a high rate of speed about 25 miles east of Erie this morning, a boy, who started to go from the sleeper to the dining car was blown from the platform by the gale then prevailing.

ALBANY, Jan. 6.--Daniel Manning's will was admitted to probate to-day by Surrogate Woods. It was made July 2, 1886, when Mr. Manning was here attending the bi-centennial celebration of Albany as a city, and bequeaths all his property to his family.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 6.--During the past few days fruit growers along the Central Hudson have been exercised over letters received by prominent Hudson River horticulturists from Delaware peach-tree cultivators, seeking the support of all small-fruit cultivators along the Hudson Valley in forming a permanent organization of a National Fruit Growers' Trust."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Arnold G. Harris dropped dead last night. He was a veteran, and had a most adventurous career.

HYANNIS, Mass., Jan. 6.--The United States Lighthouse Board steamer Verbena arrived here to-night from South Shoal Lightship, Nantucket, with the Captain and crew of the steamer Newcastle City which was wrecked on South Shoals about a week ago.

Most boys and girls do not like sermons-- they say that they are too long for their highnesses. Perhaps they may like these short sermons. They will give food to think over, and must not be read too hastily.

ONANCOCK, Va., Jan. 6.--William C. Duer yesterday cut the throat of his wife, killing her almost instantly, while riding with her and their two children. He is said to have been insane for some time, but was supposed to have recovered. Duer was committed to the Eastville Jail.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6.--The billiard tournament in progress terminated in a riot this afternoon. For several months there has been ill feeling between Richard Roche, the backer of Schaefer, and John F. Donovan, one of the players in the tournament.

Mr. Joseph Dorion, one of the oldest residents of the County of Two Mountains, whose death at St. Augustin was recently mentioned, at the advanced age of 82 years, leaves a widow aged 81 years and 16 children, 101 grandchildren, and 83 great-grandchildren, making in all a family of 200 persons. He had been married 64 years.

READING, Penn., Jan. 6.--There are some 40 furnaces situated along the line of the Reading Railroad, and to-day, after much correspondence, the Reading Coal and Iron Company supplied some of the most needy furnaces with coal, but at an advance of 80 cents per ton, delivered at Schuylkill Haven.

Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN has returned from his visit to Canada, and the joint commission for the settlement of the fisheries question will to-day resume its effort to find some basis of agreement.

Col. Fellows enjoyed a more or less agreeable call yesterday morning made by a committee of the Society for the Prevention of Crime and a committee of the Church Temperance Society. Ex-Judge William H. Arnoux was the Chairman of both.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6.--The latest move in the rebellion among the Knights of Labor is the organization of a provisional committee of rebels in the city of Washington, D.C., and a circular has been issued by them and received by the Secretary of the National Provisional Committee in this city.

MILFORD, Mass., Jan. 6.--Arthur H. Ball, pay roll clerk of the Hopedale Machine Company, has been arrested and held in $3,000 for the Worcester Grand Jury for the embezzlement of about $2,000, which he had been taking from time to time since 1886. His plan was to put up extra amounts in pay envelopes and before actual payment abstractthem and increase the pay roll to correspond.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 6.--Large gangs of men are scraping, marking, and cutting ice on the river, and already a considerable quantity of ice has been stored. The ice, which is from six to eight inches thick, varies in quality, in some spots being of the best, while in others it is dirty and very poor.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 6.--News reached here to-day that B.J. Stimpson Co. of Parma had made an assignment of all their real and personal property to George P. Glazier, a banker at Chelsea. Stimpson Co. have been the leading general merchants at Parma for years. Glazier is a son-in-law of Stimpson. The assets and liabilities are unknown at present.

ATCHISON, Kan., Jan. 6.--The Atchison Union Railway Station took fire at 2 o'clock this afternoon and in about three hours was entirely destroyed. POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 9.--There was a worse prospect before the people of Pottsville when they awoke this morning than they had anticipated. The work of banking the fires of the Pioneer furnaces was under way and 150 men were preparing to take a rest until the coal strike is over.

Joseph Becker, a German shoemaker of 215 Division-street, aged 58 years, committed suicide yesterday morning early by drinking oxalic acid. He had been a heavy drinker for two years, and had led his family a miserable life during that period, frequently striking his wife and once attempting to choke her.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan, 9.--The McCaull Opera Company made their first appearance in Pittsburg to-night for more than a year, presenting the Hindoo comie opera "The Begum," with the original cast, which includes many local favorites, together with some new faces, all of whom after this evening's performance can be sure of a hearty reception whenever they may return.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 9.--The report sent from Washington a week ago that Eugene Higgins would be made a Deputy Auditor of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad provoked many smiles and much sarcasm in this city, and nobody for a moment looked upon it in any light except as a joke; but as the report is being seriously accepted by many papers in other States it may be well to state that it is entirely imaginary.

The Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company yesterday had another accident on its Third-avenue line. Although the damage resulting was insignificant, it occurred at a busy time of day and blockaded traffic on Third-avenue for over an hour.

One of the most luxurious railroad trains that ever rolled away from the metropolis was the initial Florida special, which started south from the Pennsylvania Railroad station yesterday morning at 9:43.

Mayor Hewitt was busy the greater part of yesterday in getting out his annual message. Long strips of printed proof of the document occupied his attention, and changes and transpositions were occasionally directed to be made in it.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 9.--An important suit, conducted by nearly all the leading lawyers of the city, and involving 217 people as plaintiffs and defendants, was begun in the City Court today.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9.--A peculiar romance, which embodied a peculiar courtship, a secret marriage, irate parents, and a separation, has just culminated in a reconciliation. Last February Miss Fannie C. Howe, daughter of Henry Howe, an old settler, was married to Edward J. Sheehan, a machinist.

Rudolph, Baron von Hollenstein, resumed his tramp at the Windsor Theatre last night in the presence of a good audience. He will finish it there Saturday night, and on Monday the Hanlon's "Voyage en Suisse" will be seen there.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9.--The Rev. Spencer H. Bray, who recently resigned the pastorate of the Humphrey-Street Congregational Church in this city, has received a call from the Bethany Church, Tenth-avenue and West Thirty-fifth-street. New-York City, and the chances are that he will accept it. The salary offered is said the be $2,500. He has been very successful in his work here, and is an interesting speaker.

Snow began to fall last night about 10:30 o'clook and soon every house in New-York was masquerading under a white domino, the combined gift of the temperature and the humidity. Official thermometers, however, absolutely refused to register less than 29 at midnight, 10 more than were recorded for the corresponding hour of 1887.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 9.--This is the eve of the great political battle which is to determine who shall be the candidate of the Democratic Party for Governor of Louisiana, and which ordinarily would settle the question of political control for the next four years.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 9.--The Casing Rink was packed to-night with spectators to witness one of the best gaines of polo ever played in the State between the New-Yorks and the Casinos of this city.

At 9:30 yesterday morning the Board of Inspection went aboard the Enterprise, Commander Bowman H. McCalla commanding, and almost immediately afterward the vessel left the navy yard and steamed up the East River for her speed and turning trials in Long Island Sound.

There was a quiet wedding in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth-avenue near Fortyfifth-street, at noon yesterday. The bride was Miss Susan Isabel Gardiner, and the bridegroom Henry Belknap of Boston.
It is a serious reproach upon the Legislature of this State that whenever a session begins there is a general apprehension that its course will be marked by jobbery and corruption.

The salaries paid to Judges of the Federal courts in this State have for some years been inadequate, and Congress has been asked to increase them. A bill providing for the additions that ought to be made was reported in the Forty-ninth Congress, but it died on the calendar.
Rollin M. Squire, through William F. Howe, his counsel, put on a bold front before Judge Barrett yesterday and protested against the injustice of having to wait forever for a trial.
BOSTON, Jan. 9.--The Bricklayers and Masons' International Union opened its twentysecond annual convention this morning at 176 Tremont-street. Nearly 300 delegates were in attendance.

BOSTON, Jan. 9.--It is reported that Archbishop Williams has bought a lot of land at the corner of Scotia and Bothnia streets, on the Back Bay, as a site for a Roman Catholic Church. The lot contains 18,000 square feet. Scotia and Bothnia streets are south of the Boston and Albany Railroad, near Westchester Park Bridge. This church will be the first Catholic church on the Back Bay.
MADRID, Jan. 9.--The Chamber of Deputies has rejected the proposal of sefior Canovas del Castillo to increase the transit duties on imported cereals and flour.

J.F. Baldwin, a Cincinnati lawyer, startled Deputy State Treasurer Danielwitz last week by making a demand on him for $200,000. The surprised deputy asked for an explanation, when Baldwin exhibited a package of bonds issued in 1869 by Sutter County Levee District No. 5, calling for many thousand dollars.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 9.--The officials of the Canadian Pacific and of the "Soo" roads arrived in Minneapolis last night.

"Snapper" Garrison, the famous and popular little jockey whose dashing finishes have won for him no end of fame, money, and applause, made his first appearance on any stage at Niblo's Garden last evening in "A Run of Luck."
CHATHAM, Ontario, Jan. 9.--Mrs. Goose and a man named Leguie were run into by a train to-night while crossing the track. The woman was killed and the man fatally injured.

William Ritchie of 122 East Twentyseventh-street, an auburn-haired young Englishman of 21, was before Justice Murray in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday charged with swindling, larceny, and forgery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the habeas corpus case of the Mayor and City Council of the city of Lincoln, Neb.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 9.--The apple-drying and fruit-evaporating industry of Western New-York developed with astonishing rapidity last year.
CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Jan. 5.--The people of Prince Edward Island are excited over the provisions of the late Owen Connolly's will.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9.--Provisions were well supported to-day. No new feature was developed in the light business transacted, yet the market showed a comparatively strong front. The day's changes in prices, however, were unimportant.

CONNEAUT, Penn., Jan. 9.--The Commissioners of Crawford County were called upon recently to pay a peculiar claim against the county, and one which probably has no precedent in this or any other State. The law compels the owners of dogs to pay a per capita tax on all such animals.

BERLIN, Jan. 9.--An official bulletin says: "Emperor William's catarrh continues, rendering further care necessary."

TALEQUAH, Indian Territory, Jan. 9.--The Cherokee National Council was finally organized today after one month's wrangling. The investigation of the contest for seats resulted in the seating of two members of the lower house, making the House now stand Nationals 20, Downings 19.

MONTREAL, Jan. 9.--George Daveling and Mr. Riverin, two Montreal agents of the NewYork Life Insurance Company, are accused of inducing people to sign blank applications for insurance policies and then filling to much larger amounts than were ever thought of by the signers, and finally taking legal proceedings without authority in the name of the company to compel payment of the premimus.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 9.--E. Brown of Philadelphia, a student of Cornell University, while coasting here was thrown from his sled and had his skull fractured against a telegraph pole. He is still alive, but there are no hopes of his recovery.

A seat in the New-York Stock Exchange sold last Wednesday for $18,000. The last seat sold in the Boston Stock Exchange is reported at $15,500, or within $2,500 of the price of seats in the New-York Exchange.
Mr. A.J. Cassatt's entries to the stakes of the Coney Island nud Brooklyn Jockey Clubs reached here yesterday on the French steamer Normandie.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9.--Gen. Washington Seawell died at his apartments, at the Berkshire Hotel, early this morning. His disease was enlargement of the liver, which, combined with a weight of years, caused his death.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 10.--Mayor Male, in his message last week advised that the license fee of hotels and saloons be raised to $1,000, and that all barrooms be closed by 10 o'clock. The Common Council to-night adopted an ordinance placing the license fee at $500, thus giving Plainfield high license. The 10 o'clock closing suggestion was not adopted.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11.--S.B. Chittenden of Brooklyn, N.Y., who recently gave Yale University $100,000 for an addition to the library building, has just added $25,000 more to the fund. The new building will be commenced early in the Spring. The plans are already out for the structure, and it will he a handsome ornament to the campus.

CHICAGO, Jan, 11.--Provisious suffered a severe break to-day, Ream in Pork, Kirkwood in Lard, and Warren in Short Ribs leading a strong bearish movement. The amount of property sold by these traders was not particularly heavy, but their influence was nevertheless felt, and being on the side of lower prices resulted in bringing out large quantities of long holdings. From the start the amount of production sold exceeded the demand, and, with very limited reactions.
ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 11.--The Novosti says that Russia proposes to place an export duty upon platinum of 15 gold rubles per pood.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--Some wise man in St. Louis has discovered that the Western railroad war is on the verge of settlement, though he neglects to mention the terms. There are no terms and no prospect of settlement. Each day brings some now development in the downward course of rates.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 11--In the case of Todd against Dun, Wiman Co., the Court of Appeals today decided that communications between its correspondents and the mercantile agency were privileged, and, further, that reports from the agency to its subscribers, conveyed on its sheet of corrections, were entitled to the same protection of law. The verdict reverses two decisions in the courts below.

Newman of the Northern District, are just the opposite in their decisions on the loans made by foreign companies on farming lands in Georgia. Judge Newman holds with the decision of the Supreme Court of the State.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 11.--The failure of the management of the Pennsylvania Railway system of Pittsburg to reply to the petition of the employes of the various lines has created a good deal of dissatisfaction, and from present indications a strike seems imminent. The men have been waiting for two weeks for an answer to the petitions, and they think it is about time they should receive one.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 11.--Henry Lockert entered suit to-day in the District Court against the New-York Cable Construction Company to recover $3,000 on a promissory note given by Charles D. Ingersoll, President of the company, to G.P. Bozer, and subsequntly transferred to the plaintiff.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--Mrs. Edward F. Chapman, otherwise known as Annie Summerville, the burlesque actress, to-day secures a divorce from her husband. The jury in the suit was out five and a half hours on a case it was thought they would settle in 20 minutes. It is a complete victory for the actress, and grants her a divorce with the custody of her child.

In the possession of Thomas Brierly, who told the Jersey City police that he had been garroted and robbed of $1,800 by footpads in Jersey City during Sunday night, were found two pictures. He said that the garroters had given them to him.
The third annual dinner of the Theta Delta Chi Fraternity will be held under the auspices of the New-York Graduate Association at the Brunswick Hotel on Wednesday evening, Jan. 25.

William McPherson, a Pennsylvania Railroad shopman on the Meadows, was struck by a train in Newark yesterday morning and instantly killed.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 11.--A movement is on foot in Western Texas and Southern New-Mexico to secure Federal aid, it possible, in building a monster irrigating canal from 200 to 230 miles long, for the purpose of reclaiming vast tracts of land that are now arid wastes.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 11.--In August last the village of Iron Mountain, in the Upper Peninsula, was ravaged by typhoid fever, epidemic in its nature. It was suspected that impure drinking water was the cause of the trouble, and to settle this point a sample of the water was sent to Dr. Vaughn of the School of Hygeine at the State University for an analysis.

EL PASO, Texas, Jan, 11.--Eight armed men stopped a Mexican Central passenger train last evening, 800 miles south of El Paso, and robbed the express car. Nobody was hurt.

The appointments foreshadowed by the Eagle yesterday are announced by Mayor Chapin to-day. The first comment upon this list is that the Independents, whose votes turned the nicely-balanced electoral scale in favor of Mayor Chapin, and who may have expected that he would cut loose from the regular organization, are now completely undeceived.

The inquest in the case of Frank C. Plaisted, the engineer of the Equitable Gas Company's works at Fortieth-street and Firstavenue who was killed in an explosion there on the night of Dec. 21, was finished yesterday.

On just what days the Rockaway Steeplechase Association will have their Spring meeting the officers have not yet decided, as much will depend upon the dates selected by the Brooklyn Jockey Club. The meeting will, however, be during the last two weeks in May. For the meeting the club announces five stakes, all but one of which, the club steeplechase, are renewals.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11.--Last Friday three New-Yorkers came to this city and tried to pass a forged check on A.W. Howells of the Elm City Wood Yard. They then went to Birdgeport, and Detective Reilly went down there to-day and secured their arrest.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11.--The long-continued drought of last Summer and Fall was sufficient cause to greatly reduce the acreage usually put into wheat. This reduction in area, it is estimated, will reduce the yield of wheat next year not less than 5,000,000 bushels.

Judge Albion W. Tourgee is at the Everett House. Bluford Wilson of Springfield, Ill., is at the Hoffman House.

MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 11.--At 11:55 last hight fire was discovered in the barn of the horse railroad company, and the entire main barn was burned, with 80 horses and 14 cars. It was the most disastrous fire here for years. The origin of the fire is a mystery. The loss will amount to $75,000; insurance, $20,000.

OTTANA, Ontario, Jan. 11.--A shock of earthquake was felt throughout the city this morning at 4:50 o'clock. The vibration was quite distinct, and seemed to be traveling westward. It was felt at various points in the Ottawa Valley.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 11.--The Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad held their regular monthly meeting to-day and were in session three hours. LANCASTER, Penn., Jan. 11.--The community was startled this morning when the announcement was made that one of Lancaster's best known citizens had proved faithless to trust imposed in him. The corporation affected is the Union Building and Loan Association and the defaulter is Ambrose H. Ball, its Secretary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11.--Judge Fenn of the Superior Court, sitting in New-London County, has just sentenced Francis Gerard to serve a term of night years in the State prison. This winds up for the present the career of one of the most daring burglars in this part of the country. Gerard has had a remarkable career.

Kremer, a painter. It was found that to get the lead he had out away pipes through which water was conveyed to the top of the house, and that the damage done was great. Justice white committed him for malicious mischief.

ALBANY, Jan. 11.--The fifth annual report of the Board of Railroad Commissioners reviews to some extent the operation of the inter-State commerce law. Great apprehension had been felt by the railroads, the report says, lest the operation of the law would lead to embarrassment, if not loss. These apprehensions, however, have not been fulfilled.

The 13 gas companies that now supply the Bostonians with light by night are in process of consolidation into a gigantic trust organization covering property of the value of $14,000,000. Until about a year ago coal gas of about 16-candle power had been disposed of to the people of Boston at prices ranging between $1.40 and $2.50 a thousand cubic feet.

William Mason, one of the Dobbs Ferry burglars, pleaded guilty to burglary in the first degree at White Plains yesterday, and Justice Dykman sentenced him to 14 years in Sing Sing Prison.

John Swinton is lying in a critical condition at his residence, 151 East Forty-eighthstreet. He had an attack of erysipelas a week ago this morning. He went down town, but the next day was so much worse that Dr.R. McDonald was called in.
George Becker delivered at Chickering Hall last night, before an appreciative audience, a brilliant lecture on Sir Walter Ralergh. He presented a vivid picture of the England of Elizabeth.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11.--At a joint meeting of the Legislature held this morning John J. Toffey of Hudson was re-elected State Treasurer and E.J. Anderson of Mercer was re-elected State Controller. Samuel W. Stilsing and Peter T. Wanzer were elected Police Justices for Jersey City, and ex-Speaker Armstrong was elected Judge of the District Court of the city of Camden.
VIENNA, Jan. 11.--A council of the Austrian and Hungarian Ministers was held to-day, the Emperor presiding. The subject under discussion was the report of the Frontier Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--The getting rid of Law Clerk Le Barnes of the General Land Office by Secretary Lamar just before his term ended, according to the arrangement made with the President, is being discussed with some animation as having a bearing upon the question of Mr. Lamar's confirmation as Supreme Court Judge. Mr. Le Barnes has been in office since 1875, and his last appointment was dated in 1884.

The strike of the steampipe and boiler fitters was still continued yesterday, and the union men reported that six more of their number had secured work directly from proprietors and not through the mediumship of their bosses. DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 11.--A somewhat pathetic incident occurred at East Saqinaw to-day, showing the devotion to the Crown Prince of Prussia, of the old Germans. A German woman went into the express office there and sent a package of medicine to the Prince to help cure his throat. It was addressed to San Remo, Italy, and on it she paid $6 expressage.

It was announced in this column some time ago that the Stock Exchange Governors were contemplating action to prohibit the running of any telephone or telegraph wires from the Stock Exchange Building to the new building of the Consolidated Exchange, the purpose of the Stock Exchange being to make the 120 offices in the new building of the rival institution valueless to stock brokers.

Judge Audrews being in some doubt as to whether the Supreme Court has jurisdiction over the application for a new trial for Dan Driscoll, the murderer, which William F. Howe of Howe Hummel made to him on Tuesday, consulted yesterday with Presiding Justice Van Brunt and Judge Brady of the General Term of the Supreme Court.

BILLINGS, Montana, Jan, 11.--Local passenger train No. 6, Northern Pacific Railroad, bound east, while making regular time, was derailed by snow drifts near Grey Cliff, Montana, last evening, the entire train running free from the track upon the prairie, where it now stands, leaving the road unobstructed. The engine careened upon its side, the tender piling upon it, Engineer Hugh Monroe and Fireman Eric Gustovson being killed. No one else was injured.
