The Harlem Democratic Club has unanimously adopted the report of its Committee on Political Reform pledging continued support to President Cleveland, and indorsing his policy of tariff reform as being in the best interests of the toiler, the artisan, and all who struggle for daily subsistence.

At the annual meeting of the Association of Union Ex-Prisoners of War, which was held in the Second Battery Armory last evening, Gen. Alexander Shaler was re-elected President, Thomas W. Jones Vice-President, Frederick A. Rowe Secretary, George W. Farr Treasurer, and the Rev. David H. Hauneberg Chaplain.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11.--Three rinks, composed of members of the American and St. Andrew's Curling Clubs of New-York, played a like number of the Albany City Curling Club today on Washington Park lake.

Frederick Schaeffer was yesterday held for trial in the Yorkville Police Court for stealing a sack of coal from Barbara Hamberger, who lives at 1,105 First-avenue. Barbara is old and poor, and has for some weeks received the necessaries of life from a German charitable society. Justice Murray informed Schaeffer that he was the meanest thief on record.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 11.--The members of the Grand Army of the Republic are making preparations for the national inspection of posts to occur during the months of January and February. A circular was issued to-day from the Grand Army of the Republic headquarters to all the posts asking them to get ready for the inspection.

Archibald M. Henry, as successor to Henry Sonnenberg, wholesale dealers in jewelry at 493 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Thomas S. Holmes, Jr. They began on June 1, 1887, with a capital reported to be $6,000. The business was not successful, and the firm dissolved recently.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 11.--The Democratic State Convention, waiting on the Committee of Credentials, met at noon, and at 6 o'clock adjourned till to-morrow. The McEnery men caucused to-day on the question whether to vote for Nichols on the first ballot or cast their votes in blank. They adjourned without action.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.Judge Gresham, in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon, rendered a decision in the famous Vandalia case. The court room was filled with railroad magnates and the lawyers of national reputation who have been engaged in the litigation from time to time. The decision affirms the validity of the lease to the Terre Haute Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11.--A meeting of the managers of the Southwestern lines is to be held tomorrow at Chairman Midgley's office. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan., 11.--At noon to-day the two houses of the Kentucky Legislature in joint session elected Mr. Back for a third successive term in the United States Senate. Should he live to serve out his next term his continuous service in the senate will be extended through a period of 18 years, from March 5, 1877, to March 3, 1895.

Meeter, of the State Dairy Commission, took board at the house a few days ago and introduced a friend to dine with him there.

SAGUA, Jan. 14.--The schooner Luis G. Rabel, Capt. Murphy, from Boston Dec. 29, picked up and brought to this port seven sailors of the American bark D. Chapin, which foundered on the voyage from Turk's Island to Boston. The survivors say that the Captain, one sailor, and the cook died of thirst and hunger after 10 days' exposure in an open boat. The Chapin left Turk's Island Dec. 13 for Boston.

Alonzo N. McCann, a floor walker in a West Twenty-third-street dry goods store, who lived at 13 West Twentieth-street, is recorded as a mysterious disappearance. He was last seen by his friends on Wednesday in a saloon in Fulton-street, Brooklyn.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan.14.--A very interesting case has just come to light. In October, 1879, Louise Beauvals, daughter of Mr. J.A. Beauvals, was married at New-Bedford to Max von Schmaedel, a German, artist of Munich.

T.F. Grover, engineer at the insane asylum on Ward's Island, was recently charged by some eccentric engineers of the Knights of Labor with incompetency and carelessness to such an extent as to endanger the lives of prisoners and other inmates by allowing nearly all the water in one of the boilers to boil out and thus render the boiler liable to explode.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 14.--The railroad trouble was reopened this morning. To-day the Krie Railroad Company put a force of laborers on and built an extension switch. It was curved at the end in such a manner that if straightened the track would be across the street in dispute.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14.--No business will be taken up in the Court of Appeals on Monday. The court will pay its tribute to the memory of Judge Rapallo and then adjourn. No other memorials will be received on that day.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 14.--The Grand Jury of Hinds County, after an investigation lasting several days, says of the recent city election: "After a most diligent search we learned of no intimidation or frands at the late city election excepting the 'red circular,' which seems to have been the work of some irresponsible anonymous people, and was without effect."

--Edward Everett Hale and his son have about completed their work on the second volume of their history of Franklin's career in France. It will probably be issued before Spring by Roberts Brothers. The first volume of this history scarcely realized the expectations that had been formed of it.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 15.--The experiments at the Magnolia plantation of Gov. Warmoth, conducted by Prof. Wiley of the Department of Agriculture were resumed yesterday at 6 A.M. In the 24 hours the battery was in operation for 22 hours, working up 110 tons of cane.

The Boston Ideal Opera Company, of which W.H. Foster is manager, arrived from Washington yesterday and will begin a four weeks' engagement at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre to-night. The star is Miss Zelie de Lussau, already well known in musical circles, but who has not as yet made her debut in opera in NewYork.
The twentieth anniversary of the EleventhStreet Methodist Episcopal Church was celebrated yesterday.

Capt. McCullagh of the Sixth Precinct surprised the inmates of the Chinese gambling house at 10 Mott-street last night. Lee Hen, the proprietor, and 10 Chinamen were arrested. The opium joints at 13, 16, 17, and 18 Mott-street were also visited, but the alarm had been given and the inmates got away before the police appeared.
The grand concert given last night at Steinway Hall by the combined Liederkranz and Arion vocal societies for the benefit of the German Hospital and Dispensary was a great success.

A woman with three little children, the oldest of them 5 years of age, sat on the Court House steps, Jersey City Heights, on Saturday afternoon, and told a pitiful story to a crowd of Court House officials who gathered about her.
PARIS, Jan. 15.--Stephen Heller, the distinguished planist and musical composer, is dead, aged 75 years.
UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 15.--William S. Milligan of Little Fails has been elected President of the Herkimer County National Bank of that place, to succeed the late Gen. Priest.

While drunk, at 11:30 o'clock last evening, Frank Coleman, 55 years old, of 156 Ainsliestreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, forced his way into te home of Robert Belden at 182 Ainslie-street by mistake. Mr. Belden thought the man was a burglar and shot him in the right side with a ravolver, inflicting a dangerous and probably fatal wound. Belden was arrested and his victim taken to his home.

READING, Penn., Jan. 15.--The strike of Reading railroaders and miners is still on, and there are no indications that the lines of the rebellious employes are wavering. The Reading Railroad employes' convention, which met here two weeks ago last Thursday, reconvened here this afternoon and reiterated its faith in the justice of the strike.

There was an Italian quarrel at 153 Twenty-fifth-street, Brooklyn, last night, which was attended with serious results. Rosa Rugo had, among visitors in her room, Valentine Confreo, Gesu Mario, Franci Rosi, and Cosletto Unfro, who all lived in the same house.
Last night the train for Florida by way of Albany, Conductor Dasher, was detained in Macon five minutes over the leaving time by a bridal couple.

The steamship Trinidad, which arrived yesterday from Hamilton, Bermuda, brings intelligence of the wrecked raft of logs. From three diffrent vessels which had recently arrived in Bermuda reports had been received of the whereabouts of the raft, describing it as an immense sea of logs.

CHURCH'S FERRY, Dakota, Jan. 16.--Neal McKeague, well known in Chicago, was shot and instantly killed last night by F.A. Hillerman, a saloon keeper. McKeague has had a bad name since his arrival here.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 15.--The Military Committee, comprising Gov. Ross, Col. Steever of the United States Army, Adjt. Gen. King, Major-Gen. Roberts, and others, yesterday formulated a programme and a list of prizes to be awarded at the grand inter-State encampment and celebration to be field to this city May 14 to 17 in connection with the dedication of the new Capitol building.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15.--President Stern of the Cincinnati Baseball Club is in town, and states that if Kansas City makes the Association the offer it made the League last year, when it made the bid for the franchise of the Maroons, it will secure the eighth Association club. "I am for Kansas City." said Mr. Stern, "because it is a good drawing town, and has strong financial backing."

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The Knights of Labor District Convention, composed of representatives from local assemblies in the counties of Cortland, Oswego, Madison, Cayuga Seneca, and Onondaga, convened at Knights of Labor Hall at 8 o'clock last evening. One hun dred delegates were in attendance.

Residents of the Twenty-sixth Ward in Brooklyn have been annoyed for some time by saving their door bells rung at early hours in the morning. Sometimes the offender would visit the same houses twice in one morning. The nuisance became general, but the man managed to escape every time.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Jan. 15.--Bishop William H. Rickelooper died Saturday, aged 83. He was the oldest Bishop in the Mormon Church, and for over 40 years held the position now made vacant. He had two wives, and at the time of his death his living posterity numbered 12 children, 36 grandchildren, and 52 great-grandchildren.

COXSACKIE, N.Y., Jan. 15.--The down-pour of rain to-day on the ice fields on the Hudson River pleased rather than displeased the "bosses" and Superintendents of the various large ice companies. The reason for his action is life poor health, Dr. Walker is a member of the corporation of Yale College, and is one of the most widely known Congregational clergymen in the State.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 15.--About 8 o'clock this morning fire was discovered in the Chucrch of the Redeemer (Universalist) and the entire department was called out. The church is of stone and was built 10 years ago, and cost $80,000.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 15.--The crisis in Manitoba politics has arrived. The announcement of the resignation of the Harrison Government was made at 2 o'clock at the conclusion of a Conservative caucus.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15.--Several days ago the President of the Chicago Board of Trade received a communication from F.F. Dufais, the United States Consul at Havre, calling attention to the prohibition of the importation of American salt pork and other products still existing in France.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 15.--The coal famine, the ever-recurring troubles in Pennsylvania, and the prominence of "free coal" in tariff discussions make the coal fields within easy reach of the United States objects of unusual interest.

WATERTOWN, Jan. 15.--Certain movements by the political friends of Roswell P. Flower seem to indicate that it is their intention to carry the caucuses and procure his election as a delegate to the National Convention from this Congressional district.

Dates have been fixed for concerts by the boy pianist, Hofmann, in this and and the immediate neighborhood up to and including Feb. 4. The afternoon he will appear at a matinee in Boston, as also on the afternoons of Jan. 23 and 30.

What might have been a very serious explosion was just averted by the merest chance in the apartment houses, 3 and 5 East Eighty-fourthstreet, on Saturday night.

LONDON, Jan.15.--There was no demand for discount during the past week. Money was in unusual abundance at 2@1 . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 3 @3. Business on the Stock Exchange during the week was moderately active.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 15.--The storm which has been blockading the railroads in five States, and which has been the means of great lose of life, recalls former blockades and terrible blizzards that have swept over Minnesota in the past.

The Gaelic Society met at its rooms at 17 West Twenty-eighth-street last evening, where Judge A.L. Morrison delivered an address on "Young Ireland," in which he sketched the various steps which led to the great rebellion of 1798, tracing the growth of the Appeal Association and its culminating influence.

The readers of THE TIMES will recall the account, published exclusively in its columns two months ago, of a foot race in Brooklyn between Murray and Adams, on which the backers of Adams, who was beaten after a very close contest, wagered every dollar in their possession, besides their gold watches and diamond ...
Napier Lothian of Boston is at the Gilsey House. Bishop McNeirny of Albany is at the Park-Avenue Hotel.
The new Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, in seventy-first-street, near the Boulevard was dedicated yesterday morning by Archbishop Corrigan.
The students' religious meetings were renewed at Dockstader's last night, the out-oftown speakers being a delegation of Williams College students, F.C. Graves presided.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Jan. 15.--No opposition was made to-day to the exercise of his priestly functions by the Rev. Dr. Mytton Maury of St. James's Episcopal Church, who has been removed by the Bishop, but against whose authority in the matter Dr. Maury has appealed to the courts.

An exciting and peculiar flight and pursuit ended yesterday afternoon on the Red Star steamship pier in Jersey City. Mrs. Margaret Cospatrick Phillips, after following her recreant husband, John, across the Atlantic, captured him as he was leaving the ship and gave him such a talking to as would delight any despiser of men who desert their wives.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 15.--Even here, the stronghold of an industry that is, in part, protected beyond a point which prohibits foreign competition, it is an easy matter to find not only advocates of tariff revision, but of the most pronounced character of tariff reform.

In the fate of complaint before the Inter-State Commerce Commission at Washington a large part of the country is deeply interested. This complaint is made by the Board of Trade and the Merchants and Manufacturers' ...
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 15.--Mrs. Martha Fayard died near this plane yesterday, of cancer. She was 106 years old and had 90 living descendants, some of whom are prominent men in this place.
Frank Siddall of Philadelphia has sold his interest in Dockstader's Minstrels to Lew Dockstader, Burt Sheppard, and a Western man, J. C. Graus.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 16.--In the Legislature to-day the Senate passed a concurrent resolution relative to the determining of the boundary line between New-York and New-Jersey, and asking the Secretary of the Navy to appoint Lieut. G.C. Hanus of the Navy Department as Commissioner to act with the Commissioner in behalf of New-Jersey.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan, 16.--An interesting case, involving what United States pension officers believe to be extensive pension frauds, was tried in the United States court here to-day, and one of the indicted culprits was found guity.

The steamship Amsterdam of the Netherlands-American Steam Navigation Company, which arrived yesterday from Rotterdam, brought a party of 24 Arabs. They were not allowed to land by the Emigration Commissioners, who were not satisfied that the Arabs would not become a charge upon the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.--The Democratic primaries were held to-night to elect delegates to the conventions which will elect delegates by Representative districts to the State Convention, where the delegates to the National Convention will be chosen by Congressional districts.

The candidates for the Columbia College 'Varsity crew began training at Wood's Gymnasium yesterday under the eye of Sidney Harris, '87, the coach. None of last year's crew appeared. The new men are: E. Klapp, '89, (Captain:) F.W. Denton, '89; C.K. Beekman, '89;...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.--Josiah W. Leeds, a tall, thin man, with a prominent nose and receding chin, who wears the coat and broadbrimmed hat of the Orthodox Quakers, is the Anthony Comstock of Philadelphia, with this difference: Mr. Leeds is a self-appointed conservator of public morals, while Mr. Comstock has a society behind him.

Roscoe Conkling has been added to the company of lawyers who represent the various interests in the effort to secure the revocation of the will of Mrs. Cornelia M. Stewart. Mr. Conkling made his first public appearance in this case at the opening of the probate calendar...

NYACK, Jan. 16.--The Methodist Episcopal church of Spring Valley, rent in twain two years ago by the Bristor episode, celebrated an event last night which made the hour the happiest and proudest in the history of its existence. This event was the burning, in the presence of a very large congregation, of the bond...

Gen. Stewart L. Woodford's two pretty daughters, Jennie and Minnie, had a narrow escape from death yesterday afternoon. While out driving they crossed the tracks of the Long Island Railroad at Atlantic and South Portland avenues, Brooklyn.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 16.--Rudolph Aronson's "Erminie" Company No. 2, with new costumes and new scenery, the latter by Henry E. Hoyt, presented that popular opera here to-night with a chorus of 60 voices. The curtain in the Kingston Opera House and the curtain in the Casino in NewYork were raised at the same time. There were seven encores here. The company will sing in Utica to-morrow evening.
Miss Jennie Chamberlain of Cleveland is at the Victoria Hotel. Congressman Thomas C. Catchings of Mississippi is at the New-York Hotel.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 16.--The local leaders in the strike returned to-day from the Reading convention, except such of the amalgamated men as had been engaged throughout the region.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 16.--The terrible storm which has swept over the Northwest, blockading railroads in five States, is now over, and the victims of its fury are now being counted. The pitiful list is growing almost every hour.
The cotillion given by Mrs. Ogden Mills at her new house, 2 East Sixty-ninth-street, last evening, was attended by about 200 people.
BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 16.--At a meeting of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Finance Committee to-day the financial situation with the Drexel-Morgan syndicate was discussed.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 16.-The members of Premier Norquay's Government placed their resignations in the Governor's hands this morning and they were accepted, and Greenway, leader of the Opposition, was called upon to form a Government, and Parliament adjourned till Thursday to give him time to form his Cabinet and announce his policy.

The main room of the Grolier Club, 64 Madison-avenue, was filled last evening with ladies and gentlemen versed in matters of art, who had come to hear Russell Sturgis lecture on "Turner's Liber Studiorum." Mr. Sturgis gave a comprehensive history of the art work of Turner, with a short blography of the great artist himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Capt. Chandler P. Eakin, First Artillery, having been found incapacitated for active service on account of disability incident to the service, has been retired. The leave of absence granted Second Lieut. Francis D. Rucker, Second Cavalry, has been extended seven days.

A summary is given in the news columns of to-day's TIMES of the report sent to the Legislature by the Commissioners appointed to ascertain "the most humane and practical method of carrying into effect the sentence of death in capital cases." It is a very sensible and straightforward performance.
A man of 30, apparently a laborer, of medium stature, was found drowned last evening in the North River at the foot of Fifty-fifth-street.

A cold-weather octopus, which had been lying dormant for several weeks among the pretty little lakes of Wisconsin, near the city of La Crosse, came forth from its lair on Friday night and stretched out its invisible tentacles of cold toward the East and the West and the North and the South, and particularly toward the East.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16.--Hecht Putzel, shoe dealers, to-day made an assignment to Jacob Hecht for the benefit of their creditors. The bond of the Trustee is $150,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16.--The solid steel gun cast at the foundry of the Pittsburg Steel Casting Company last Wednesday was taken from the mold to-day, and after a careful inspection pronounced perfect by Superintenddent Hainsworth and the representatives of the Government--Ensign Fletcher and Lieut. Forse...

The perennial "Erminie" returned to the Casino last evening amid public rejoicings. All the old favorites were welcomed with applause when they appeared, and Messrs. Wilson and Daboll as Cadeaux and Ravennes were vociferously cheered.

Moritz Gross, manufacturer of furs at 101 Spring-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edward Levine, giving preferences for $3,000. He has been in business 20 years, failed in 1877, with liabilities of $28,000, which he compromised at 30 cents on the dollar, and in 1885 claimed a capital of...

The results are embodied in a pamphlet of 98 pages, which will be...

PARIS, Jan. 16.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Sarrien, Minister of the Interior, replying to an interpellation, refuted the charge that the Paris Municipal Council had been guilty of organizing a revolt during the recent Presidential crisis.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 16--What promised to be a serious trouble between the city and the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railway over the attempt of the latter to throw a track across a street will be settled amicably.
The January meeting of the Congregational Club of New-York and vicinity was held last evening at Clark's restaurant in West Twenty-third street.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 16.--The Rev. Dr. Walker's resignation of the First Church Pastorate in this city is deeply regretted by the representatives of advanced Congregationalism in the State.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 16.--The annual meeting of the New-Jersey Editorial Association was held at the State-Street House to-day, where a banquet was partaken of after the transaction of the business.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 16.--The funeral of James Lockwood of the Lockwood Brainard Publishing Company was attended this afternoon from the Asylum-Avenue Baptist Church here.

DUBLIN, Jan. 16.--A reporter of the Freeman's Journal has had an interview with Mr. Parnell. Mr. Parnell believes there is no doubt that grave dissension exists among the members of the Cabinet and that a Government party crisis may occur at any time next session over some English question.
It is said that a petition in favor of a Government telegraph, bearing upward of 500,000 names, is soon to be sent to Congress from the headquarters of the Knights of Labor in Philadelphia.

"Kid" Miller, the bunko steerer, who had his skull fractured with a slungshot some time ago by Julius Hailard, an ex-convict, is now able to be around again, but his facial muscles are paralyzed, and his physicians predict a sudden and early death. Hailard fled to Baltimore, but returned to this city a week ago and was arrested in Sixth-avenue on Sunday night. He was identified yesterday by Miller.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The money expended in 1887 under the supervision of the Department of Public Instruction, according to the report of Superintendent Draper, which will be sent to the Legislature to-morrow, was $14,461,774.94, of which $13,760,669.75 was for the common schools.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16.--Mr. Thomas Wallace, the chief promoter of the Capital Gas Company, has returned from a trip through the natural gas producing regions of Pennsylvania and Ohio. A vast reservoir of natural gas lies near this city, and the company has ordered machinery for boring, which will be commenced at once.

BOSTON, N. Y., Jan. 16.--Ice boats here and north of here were run on the ice on the Hudson River this afternoon, which in stretches up north is in fair condition for ice boating. Several races were sailed near Barrytown. New boats have been built at Hyde Park, Marlborough, New-Hamburg, and elsewhere. A spirited series of races has been arranged.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Jan. 16.--At 5 o'clock this evening Cain's Winter Garden, a variety theatre, situated on Lower Market-stret, was entirely destroyed by fire, together with its contents. Miss Annie Devoe, a variety actress from Pittsburg, perished in the flames.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 16.--Charles L. McDermett, who for some time past was in the employ of the Columbus Brass Works as bookkeeper, committed suicide at noon to-day by blowing out his brains in the store of the company. McDermett severed his connection with the company on Saturday night and during the forenoon took out an insurance policy upon his life.

Mrs. Mary T. Keep, widow of Charles D. Keep, proprietor of the Wall-Street Daily News, who died at Elberon on June 9, 1887, has made application to Coroner James Robinson of Long Island City to have the grave in Calvary Cemetery opened and the body examined. She says she believes that a dummy was buried in the coffin, or, if Mr. Keep is dead, that he was murdered.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16.--All idea of uniting with the Republicans to-morrow in an attempt to defeat Senator Wilson was practically abandoned by the Democratic caucus to-night, and, after a long discussion, Major Anderson, the nominee for Governor last Fall, was nominated unanimously.

Jacob Kapp, aged 55, who lived at 140 East One Hundred and Fifteenth-street, and whose place of business was at 322 Canal-street, shot himself in the left temple yesterday afternoon in Mount Morris Park, about opposite One Hundred and Twentysecond-street. No cause is assigned by his friends for the suicide.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 16.--The body of a man was found in a squalid back room at 193 Bealestreet this morning. From papers found it proved to be that of a man named A. L. Davis, recently of Sardas, Miss. Davis had formerly been a Postmaster, Deputy Sheriff, and Deputy Chancery Clerk.
TEXARKANA, Ark., Jan. 16.--Dr. John Gordon died here this morning at 1 o'clock. He was at one time a prominent merchant of St. Louis, doing a wholesale business on Morgan-street.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Jan. 16.--Benjamin Sawyer, one of the young men injured in the coasting accident Saturday evening, is dead, and one or two others are liable to die.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 16.--Judge Jackson rendered a decision in the United States court to-day in a case representing about $100,000 of claims against the Fidelity Bank, which was wrecked by the Harper wheat deal.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 16.--The manufacturers succeeded to-night in obtaining a conference with the spinners and postponing for a few days any definite action on a strike.

Amasa Lyon, manufacturer of umbrellas and canes at 684 Broadway, made an individual assignment yesterday to George M. Brockway, without preference. It is positively stated that his assignment does not affect the corporation of Amasa Lyon Co., of which he is President,...

Peter Peters, a Danish longshoreman living at 33 North Moore-street, committed suicide yesterday. He was engaged to marry Mrs. Mary Kuhl, and was waiting for her husband, who was a cripple, to die.
At the annual meeting of the Republican Club of the city last evening, after the reports of committees were disposed of, President James P. Foster made an address in giving up his position.
Like a very large but harmonious family was the gathering of Presbyterians which opened the new Presbyterian House with a "house warming," at Fifth-avenue and Twelfth-street, last evening.
SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Jan. 16.--The canal of the Albuquerque Land and Water Company, known throughout the Territory as the "Guy Robertson-Mesa Canal," will be commenced in 10 days.

The funeral of Franklin Osgood took place yesterday morning at 10 o'clock at Grace Church.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The President has sent the following nominations to the Senate:

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan, 16.--The trial of the tally-sheet forgers began this afternoon in the United States court, Judge Woods presiding. This trial is of but four of the eleven persons under indictment--Coy, Mattler, Spaan, and Beruhamier--and is upon another indictment than the one before tried, but for the same offense.

The Court House was so cold all day yesterday that it was with great discomfort that business was done, and Judge Barrett was obliged to adjourn his court for two hours to see if the temperature could not be somewhat moderated.

According to Charles Bassett, one of the leading tenors of the National Opera Company, that organization has only been saved from utter disintegration during its recent tour by the magnetism of its manager, Charles E. Locke. Mr. Bassett has been alternating in leading roles with Herr William Candidus during the season.

BUFFALO, Jan. 16--The Church dignitaries in the large Catholic Diocese of Buffalo, which includes nearly a quarter of New-York State, have for some years been excited over a scandal concerning one priest and fomented by another.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Mr. William E. Chandler's first attempt to play the part of boss of the United Sates Senate has come to an end, and L.Q.C. Lamar of Mississippi is to-night an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, while William F. Vilas of Wisconsin...

BOSTON, Jan. 16.--The first Josef Hofmann matinee of the new series to-day was even a greater success than any entertainment yet given by the lad, and proved effectually how the public, from all stations and conditions of life, have recognized the genius of the boy.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the American Press Association was held at the company's offices, 32 Vesey-street, yesterday morning, when the following Trustees and stockholders were present: O. J. Smith, New-York;...

The prompt confirmation of the nomination of Mr. LAMAR as Justice of the Supreme Court so soon as the question could be brought to a veto is a severe blow to the petty politicians who have been trying to revive the war feeling in connection with this appointment.

Paulo Puzzelo, Pasquale Depasanade, Emanuello Culos, and Dominico Corcorano, four welldressed Italians who had been imbibing rather freely, took possession of the lower end of Sullivanstreet yesterday.

VENICE, Jan. 16.--Mr. James G. Blaine has arrived here. He will remain for some time. CAIRO, Jan. 16.--Mr. W.K. Vanderbilt of New-York has chartered the steamer Prince Abbas for a trip up the Nile. The trip usually occupies about three weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16.--Ex-Gov. Pattison made a sweeping donial to-day of the story published by the Press that he had suddenly approved the South Penn and other railroad bills after the late Jeremiah S. The Rev. W. H. Boole is Pastor of the Willett-Street Methodist Episcopal Church. He is not in perfect accord with his congregation and for the last two weeks has fouud himself antagonized by a large part of his flock.

William P. Corney, Frank Halls's representative, arrived here yesterday on the Umbrla. He is accompanied by four English pedestrians who are to take part in the six-day race which is to begin in Madison-Square Garden on Feb.5.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16.--The concert that is given by the Yale Glee and Banjo Club at the Hyperion Theatre on the evening preceding the Junior promenade, was attended by a brilliant audience.

Col. Frederick D. Grant spent a few minutes in the Republican Club headquarters last night. He said that he had received yesterday afternoon an offer of the place of Quarantine Commissioner from Gov. Hill, but had sent the Governor a letter declining to accept it.

LONDON, Jan. 16.--This is the worst day of the new year, so far as the prospects for peace are concerned. The papers literally swarm with reports of Russian movements of troops. The Manhattan Railroad Company seems bent on keeping up its record of accidents, and yesterday what might have proved a serious disaster was only averted by the coolness and promptitude of an engineer. The western branch of the elevated system has a connection at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street and...

Frederick Miller, who on Friday was arrested with Henry Kline and Fritz Brown as suspicious persons, and who, with them, has been arraigned daily at the Jefferson Market Police Court, Inspector Byrnes says, told him something which throws some light on the Lyman S. Weeks murder.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--The annual report of Commissioners Purcell, Robinson, and Donovan, composing, the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration, was presented to the Legislature to-day. The Commissioners believe that the act of 1887 vesting the power of mediation and of investigation at will in the board has exercised...

The Executive Board of Ocean Associations has issued a call to all local assemblies of the Knights of Labor whose members are either longshoremen, riggers, stevedores, or dock laborers, to send representatives to a convention that is to be held in this city March 1 at 134 Canal-street, for the purpose of forming a national trade district of men belonging to those branches of industry.

ALBANY, Jan. 16.--G. S. Massey, of Colorado City, Texas, died in the City Hospital to-day from exhaustion. Massey was fleeced in New-York by sharpers, and then sent here. On Dec. 30 he cut his throat in Cox's eating house, and was found the next morning insensible. The loss of blood was so great that it was impossible for the man to recover.

Frank Coleman, who on Sunday night mistook the dwelling of Robert Belden at 182 Ainslie-street, Brooklyn, for his own, and was shot by Mr. Belden while trying to force an entrance, was very low yesterday, and the surgeon at St. Catherine's Hospital thought he could not possibly recover.

The upper lake of the Park, or Harlem Mere, presented a very animated appearance yesterday afternoon, as between 400 and 500 skaters threaded their way amid the crowds and when the sun began to set every car brought fresh loads of those who were impatient to join in the sport.

The things which cheer the physical man and those which delight the mental man were side by side on the programme of the meeting of the Conmonwealth Club at the Metropolitan Hotel last night. But with all justice to the excellent dinner, the greater attraction was the intellectual bill of fare, which, brief as it was...

The inquiry into the cause of death of Thalberg Von Bledenfeld, druggist, of 3 Second-avenue, who died on Jan. 8 from a fall in a scuffle with his clerk, Anders Holm, early on the morning of Jan. 7, was closed yesterday.
The striking carders at Clark's Kearney Mills at Newark are still firm in their refusal to return to work.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16.--The McCaull Opera Company arrived in this city yesterday from their Western tour, and to-night presented their latest success, "The Begum," at the Holiday-Street Theatre before an immense audience.
The Carri brothers will give a concert at Chickering Hall to-night. Messrs. Booth and Barrett began their Southern tour at Richmond, Va., last night.

Manager Abbey does not share the popular superstition about Friday being an unlucky day, and he will tempt fate next Friday evening by producing "L'Abbe Constantin" for the first time in this country at Wallack's. The play has been thoroughly rehearsed, the artists are heartily in sympathy with their characters, and the management confidently expect the piece to...

Warren D. Hedden, a resident of Jersey City, who owns a smoke house at 514 Washington-street, this city, summoned a policeman to his place of business early yesterday morning and showed him a pistol-shot wound in his left breast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The Collector of Customs at New-York has been instructed to prevent the landing of a consignment of pork shipped from Copenhagen to New-York on the Thiugvaila Dec. 21. This notice is based on information that an epidemic prevails among hogs in portions of Denmark and Sweden.

Laughter pays nowadays more than ever, if one may judge from the numerous efforts that are constantly made to produce mirth on the stage. The great success that has attended the production of Mr. Hoyt's skits has inspired many others to follow in his footsteps.

After holding the matter many days, during each of which he added $10 a day at the expense of the city and county of New-York to his aunual salary of $6,000 paid by the State, Judge Potter has at last decided to send the elevated railroad tax cases to a Referee, his intimate friend, George F. Martens.

ALBANY, Jan.16.--It is difficult for the Legislature to settle down seriously to work. The Senate met to-night and adjourned after a session of less than 15 minutes. In that brief period the report of the Tenement House Reform Association and a resolution by Mr. Vedder were presented.

MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 16.--L. J. Curtis, the millionaire manufacturer of this city, has left $750,000 by his will to the Curtis Home for Old Women and Orphans, which he built and maintained at his own expense.

"Shall the United States have a naval station in the West Indies?" was the question presented to the Academy of Political Science at its regular meeting last evening in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, by Stephen G. Williams, Ph.D. Mr. Williams thinks it is a fact that the United States should have a naval...

The 15-ball pool tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Athletic Club was begun last night. The first series, between W. True, a pupil of Frey's, and B. G. Sanford resulted in a victory for True by 6 to 1. There is some talk of a match between the winner of the tournament and Billy Raynor, the champion of the New-York Athletic Club.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 16.--Jeffrey McColl, member of the Provincial Legislature for Pictou, in a speech to his constituents today advocated the immediate abolition of local Legislatures and the annexation of Nova Scotia to the United States.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan, 16.--The Buffalo Lubricating Oil Company, headed by C.B. Matthews, have gained fame, if not wealth, by their plucky fight against the Standard Oil concern.
ALBANY, Jan. 16.--When the six remaining Judges of the Court of Appeals filed into court and quietly took their seats to-day, there was one vacant chair, and this was shrouded in mourning.
Only about 115,000 shares of stock were dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but there was a noteworthy firmness and steadiness in prices, considering the low ebb of the speculative spirit.

Recorder Smyth yesterday denied the application of William F. Howe for a new trial in the case of Daniel Driscoll, who is sentenced to be hanged on Friday for the murder of Beezie Garrity. The evidence alleged to be newly discovered evidence, he said, was not such in the legal meaning of the term, and it attacks only...

The acting of Miss Marie Burroughs, who has been kept in the background lately by force of circumstances, would have made it worth while to sit out the first performance of "Heart of Hearts" at the Madison-Square Theatre last night, even if the work of her associates had not been of much merit, and the play itself had been found valueless.

Collector Magone yesterday received from the Civil Service Commission the eligible list of clerks who had passed the last examination for promotion from the sixteen-hundred to the eighteen-hundred dollar grade, or from the third to the fourth class.

Mrs. A. A. Stuart, the mother of Stuart Robson, the comedian, celebrated her eightyfirst birthday last Saturday evening at the residence of Dr. Charles C. Cranmer, South Washington-square. Mrs. Stuart is a charming old lady and holds her age well, and she received her guests with the grace of a young girl.

The advance of 25 cents per ton on all grades of coal decided upon at the meeting of the Retail Coal Dealers' Association went into very general effect throughout the city yesterday, those who had abstained from attending the Grand Opera House meeting because they did not like its animating principle putting its decision into practice.

According to Charles A. Davenport, schoolmaster on the united States ship Enterprise and clerk of the recent court of inquiry which investigated the charges against Storekeeper Stevenson, some one has been attempting bribery in order to obtain in advance the verdict in that case.
The differentials in freight rates fixed some time ago by the trunk lines promise to stir up a good deal of trouble among the roads over the question to just what points they shall be applied.

TENTON, N. J., Jan. 16.--The case of the State against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has been appealed to the United States Supreme Court, where the question of the right of Congress to grant the privilege of building the bridge over the Staten Island Sound will be considered.

The family of Giuseppe Columbo, an Italian living at 68 Sedgwick-street, Brooklyn, partook of some liver on Sunday and yesterday all were sick. Gaterno, a son aged 5 years, died in great agony. County Physician Shepard made a post-mortem examination yesterday and found that death resulted from inflammation of the bowels, but he was not certain that the liver caused it.

PARIS, Jan. 16.--The Bourse was depressed at the close to-day owing to rumors that M. de Giers, the Russian Premier and Foreign Minister, had resigned. PARIS, Jan. 3.--Twenty years ago if the question had been put to any one with even an elementary knowledge of Parisian society, Which is the gayest, most brilliant drawing room in all Paris? the answer would have been, At the Austrian Embassy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 18.--The strike among the several hundred ice harvesters on the Hudson River in this vicinity for an advance of 25 cents a day, to $1 75, has been ended by the big companies acceding to the demand. Several of the individual harvesters refused to comply with the request and their men are still out.

CARLISLE, Penn., Jan. 18.--The female employes at the Carlisle Shoe Factory are out on strike. Twenty-six out of thirty have stopped work. The grievance is the conduct of Kelter, a male foreman. The girls insist on his removal. The company have given them until Friday to return, or have their places filled. The male operatives contemplate striking to assist the girls.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20.--The trial of Peter Coffey for the murder of Charles I, Way was completed to-day except for the Judge's charge. PITTSBURG, Jan. 20.--John Palmer, assistant mill wright at Oliver Brothers Phillips's Tenthstreet iron mill, was dragged into the rolls this morning and crushed to death. Palmer was oiling the pinion bearings, when his feet slipped, and before he could recover himself he was caught in the rolls and drawn through feet foremost. His body was horribly mangled, and his head was mashed almost to a jelly. The deceased was 60 years of age.

JANESVILLE, Wis., Jan. 20.--The boiler in James Gagon Co.'s feed mill exploded this morning, completely wrecking the establishment. Byron Kennedy and James Bracken were instantly killed. Several warehouses adjoining were damaged by the force of the explosion. No estimate of the loss can be given.

DETROIT, Jan. 22.--Richard V. Trevellyck of this city, the Grand Lecturer of the Knights of Labor and a specially candid, intelligent, and observant man, has returned from a trip to the far West, where he has been engaged among his fellow-workingmen for several months.

NEWTON, N.J., Jan. 22.--Sidney Smith of Swartswood, in this county, a farm hand employed by Mrs. John C. Lewis, retired rather earlier than usual last night, and occupied a room on the second story of the house with windows at least 20 feet from the ground.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22.--Letitia McCullough, widow of the tragedian, John McCullough, died this morning at 9 o'clock at her residence, 219 East Thompson-street, after an illness of three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22.--Last week was a carnival week of conventions in the Nation's capital. There has been more than one convention for every day, and each convention has had an object in hand which was regarded as of supreme importance to every man, woman, and child in the whole country.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 22.--The cold in the Hudson River Valley at 6 o'clock this morning was intense. In this city the thermometer indicated 18 below zero, at Vasaar College 23 , and at Rhinebeck 27 below.

Col. Spencer Wallace Cone, father of Miss Kate Claxton, died at the residence of Mr. Stevenson at 5 o'clock Saturday afternoon. Miss Claxton will be obliged to postpone the production of her new play in the city until Wednesday night. Col. Cone was the son of the noted Baptist preacher, Spencer H. Cone. He commanded the New-York Sixty-first Regiment during the war.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 23.--J.N. Ferguson of Conway, one of the largest dry goods and general merchandise dealers in Western Arkansas, was attached to-day by a Cincinnati firm for a debt of $2,000. Other attachments will be served to-morrow by Eastern creditors. Liabilities are said to be $20,000; assets more than double.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23.--As the result of practical joking Henry Carmody of Danbury, Conn., a member of McNish, Slavin Johnson's Minstrel Troupe, went insane in this city last evening and to-night was sent to his home by the authorities.

LONDON, Jan. 23.--Mr. Gladstone will return to England on Feb. 6. On Wednesday next the party chiefs will issue circulars requesting the early presence of members in Parliament.

Daniel Driscoll, who shot and killed "Beezie" Garrity on June 26,1886, was hanged in the yard of the Tombs Prison yesterday morning. His death was swift and his execution was well managed.

The Trustees of the Mercantile Benefit Association have placed C. C. Stevenson, an expert accountant, in charge of the office at 319 Broadway, and yesterday morning he begun a rigid examination of the books.

READING, Penn., Jan. 23.--President Corbin's circular in the Reading Railroad troubles has created a profound sensation here. Many pronounce it a masterly presentation of the facts and say they cannot see how the company can do otherwise than adhere to the course which has thus far been pursued.

The Sanitary Aid Society hold its annual meeting last evening at the residence of Mr. Kohns, at 23 West Fifty-sixth-street. Kiliaen Van Rensselaer presided.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 23.--A contest was commenced in the Surrogate's Court of this city over the will of Tamma Sutherland, who died here recently.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 23.--Mr. Michael Shea, a well-known citizen, still resides with his son here, who is a member of the police force. He is an Irishman, and was born on St. Michael's Day, November, 1781.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--Receiver McNulta of the Wabash Railroad Company to-day submitted his report of operations for the year 1887.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan, 23.--The committee in charge of the investigation of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad ticket accounts did not make its report before the stockholders' meeting this morning, as was expected, and it now rests with them to makr the report whenever they are so inclined.

PLYMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 23.--The "Shoo Fly" train south on the Boston, Concord and Montreal Railroad ran off the track at Warren Summit at 3 o'clock this morning, demolishing one car and badly shaking up the passengers. No one was hurt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the case of Hugh M. Brooks, alias W.H. Maxwell, against the State of Missouri.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 23.--The bondsmen of Frank Patterson, who has been under bonds awaiting the action of the Court of Errors and Appeals upon 43 indictments for forgery found against him nearly four years ago, to-day surrendered him. Patterson was sent back to the county jail at Freehold, where he was confined for two years actor his first arrest.

LONDON. Jan. 24.--The steamship Bothnia, (Br.), Capt. Dutten, from New-York Jan. 14 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 6:35 P.M. yesterday.

Dr. George S. Meigs, a dentist, committed suicide yesterday at his office, 133 West Thirtyfourth-street. His partner, Dr. Evans, entered the office shortlty after noon and fouud Dr. Mergs lying dead on the sofa, with his overcoat on and his hat on the floor beside him.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 23.--Owing to a poor supply of water the Bridgeport Fire Department were unable to save the parsonage of St. Augustine's Catholic Church, which slowly burned up to-night at 11 o'clock.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 23.--The bank statement for December, issued on Saturday, shows that five chartered banks are bankrupt, The Maritime Bank of New-Brunswick and the Central Bank of Canada are reported in Irquidation.
George Schwab was convicted in Part Ill., General Sessions, yesterday of a felony in practicing medicine under an assumed name.
A large party of children were among the spectators at the performance of "Mazulm" in the Academy last night. Mr. Kiralfy's spectacle is as popular as ever.

BUFFALO, Jan. 23.--William W. Lawson, a prominent Republican politician of Erie County, and brother-in-law of Congressman Weber, fell down a ladder in the cellar of a brewery to-day and was killed, He had been an Assemblyman, was Sheriff of this county one term, and last year was Postmaster of the Assembly. He leaves a family of children.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23.--Legislative work opened at the State House to-night with the reception of a numbur of nominations from Gov. Green, as follows:

Some time ago some moldors who are Knights of Labor struck at Kelly Jones's foundry, at Erie and Tenth streets, Jersey City. New hands were sought, and the strikers appointed a committee to picket the factory and keep new men away.

It leaked out yesterday that Albert M. Frey, the pool champion, had taken unto himself a wife in the person of Miss Geneieve C. Corr, the pretty daughter of Detective Corr of the Brooklyn Central Office squad.
Mrs. Antoinette de Meli's will, which was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday, leaves the income of her estate for life to her son, Henry A. de Meli, whose divorce case, ...

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 23.--A large and responsive audience greeted Henry Irving and Ellen Terry at the Boston Theatre to-night when Goethe's tragedy, "Faust," was presented for the first time in this city. The stars received an enthusiastic welcome, and the various members of the supporting Lycenm company were generously applauded. The piece was superbly mounted.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23.--The first Winter meeting of the Athletic Association of the University of Pennsylvania was held at the Academy of Music to-night in the presence of a large number of spectators that packed the great building to the top tier.

Frank A. Robbins's Winter Circus in the American Institute Building, in Third-avenue, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth streets, entered yesterday evening upon the fifth week of its successful career.

The Cigarmakers' International Union caused a strike in two more factories yesterday. The Strike Committee first called at the factory of kerbs Spiess, at Second-avenue and Fiftyfourth-street, where they had an interview with Messrs. Kerbs Haas, whom they asked to restore the old rates of wages.
An autopsy was held yesterday Dr. Shepard on the body of William Dempsey, who died on Sunday after being "knocked out" in a prize fight by Simon Besser, alias "Tom White, the newsboy."
At to-day's meeting of the Tariff Association a motion will be made to suspend the rules, except with reference to the rate upon fibre goods in storage.
With the death of Walter Murray Gibson, in San Francisco, Saturday evening, ended a career which rivaled in interest many of those conceived in the fertile brains of the romancers.
The congregation of the Hebrew Temple Israel, on Greene-avenue, Brooklyn, has decided to hold services on Sunday mornings in addition to those held on the present Hebrew Sabbath.
When it was announced that a special meeting world be held last night at the Willett-Street Methodist Episcopal Church it was supposed that the ...
John Bourman, a very old and very testy man, was annoyed on Saturday by a knocking which came from a room above his, at 408 West Sixteenthstreet.

The ball given by Mr. and Mrs. CorneliuVanderbilt at their residence, West Fifty-seventh-street, corner of Fifth-avenue, last evening, was, both from the beauty of its surroundings and from the number of prominent people who attended it, one of the most notable of the social events of the Winter.
The Mayor's expected message on rapid transit, street improvements, and docks and wharves will not be presented until next Tuesday.
ALBANY, Jan. 23.--The report of Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, for the year ending Sept. 30 last was forwarded to the Legislature to-day.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has always unhappily been as deficient in "harmony" as if it were a political party with ten offices to dispose of and ten thousand office seekers to be appeased.
The travelers in Messrs, Raymond Whitcomb's second tourist party through Mexico will leave this city Monday, March 12, and will speed 47 days in the trip.

Vice-President C. C. Burke presided at a meeting of the petroleum trade of the Petroleum Exchange yesterday afternoon, called to act on the question of excluding refined Lima oil from deliveries on contracts.
Henry H. Van Dyck, President of the American Safe Deposit Company, at 501 Fifthavenue, died on Sunday at his residence 5 Spencer-place, Brooklyn, aged 79 years.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 23.--Mr. Edwin Booth has purchased from Mrs. Owens, through Manager Albaugh of this city, thr dramatic portrait gallery of the late John E. Owens.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 23.--About 5 o'clock this afternoon two mounted police officers located James Burrows, the desperado who shot Neil Bray last night, in a cabin on the mountain plantation, 10 miles from Montgomery.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23.--Judge Waterman, in the case of Mrs. Alice A. Crocker against her husband. Ausel L. Crocker, a wealthy-furniture dealer, to-day decided that a woman cannot sue her husband for slander or assault.
On the strength of a warrant issued by Justice Walsh yesterday the search for John Wright, an ex-policeman employed by the Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, was continued.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--Leave of absence for four months to take effect Feb. 10 has bean granted First Lient. Theodore Mosher, Twenty-socond Infantry.

PATCHOGUE, Long Island, Jan. 23.--The great South Bay is completely frozon over and ice yachting is being extensively indulged in. From other parts of the county come the reports that the bays which have not been frozen over for years are solid now, and that the extreme cold of the past few days has caused considerable, suffering among the farmers and cystermen.
BUFFALO, Jan. 23.--The pretty little village of Sinclairville, in Chautauqua County, has been famed heretofore only for the excellence of its dairy products.
Edwin Y. Ide, the energetic advocate of temperance, has resigned the Presidency of the Brooklyn Temperance Union, on the ground of engrossing business duties.

The firm of M. E. Salomon, importers of tobacco at 85 Water-street, has failed, with liabilities of about $350,000 and assets $250,000. Emanuel Salomon and Henry Adler, who compose the firm, made an assignment yesterday to Gustave Salomon.
ROME, Jan. 23.--The Opinione says that if disorders should occur in Morocco Italy would prefer the intervention of Spain tothat of any other power.

SAN FRANSISCO, Jan. 23.--Several months ago a bold attempt was made to kidnap little Birdie Fair, youngest child of the bonanza exSenator, from the palatial residence of her divorced mother on Pine-street.

LIMESTOVE, Indian Territory, Jan. 23.-- Four masked men, all heavily armed entered the Citizens' Bank Saturday and, presenting a pistol at the head of the Cashier, W.T. Reynolds, demanded that be turn over the cash on hand.

The Rev. E. Walpole Warren, Rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity, and President Gates of Rutger's College, were the "star" speakers at the celebration of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association last evening.
HAVANA, Jan. 23.--Martin Losada has been kidnapped near Santa Clara by bandits, who demand a ransom of $3,000.

George Beier, the German saloon keeper who killed himself Sunday while at the Odd Fellows' Home at Fordham, Westchester County, by shooting three bullets into his side, was a rich man of Greenville, N. J.
Mayor Hewitt ans the heads of departments conferred yesterday in reference to bills relating to the city now pending in the Legisluture.

Collector Magono yesterday had a conference with Charles Edward Tracy of Bangs, Stetson, Tracy, McVeagh, the attorney for the firm of importers charged with large indermeasurements in a number of consignments of Frebch woolens.
On the face of it President CORBIN's statement of the case in regard to the strike of the miners of the Reading Coal and Iron Company is unanswerable.
Columbia Freshmen were angry looks yesterday. Thry talked of holding a class meeting to adopt resolutions calling upon the Sophomores to make them a public apology.

Her friends are trying to get the young woman who, under the name of Miss Stafford, has been pestering Kyrle Bellew with her demonstrations of love into a lunatic asylum. Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court has appointed Dr. Matthew Chalmers and John H. Judge, counselor at law, Commissioners to sit with a Sheriff's jury and determine the condition of her mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23.--The advocates of a high protective tariff have few more earnest allies than Senator Frye of Maine, and the Senate has few members who command more attentive listners to a set speech.

Charles W. Bryan of Ashland County, Ohio, will soon bring proceedings to try to prove his title to real estate in this city bounded by One Hundred and Thirtieth and Seventy-fourth streets and the North and East Rivers, which he or his ancestors were in some way entitled to under letters patent of May, 1666, by Richard Nichols, Governor of NewYork County.
Charles F. Roper's Co., printers at 157 William-street, were sold out by the Sheriff yesterday, judigment having been entered against them for $4,143 in favor of J. H. Bonnell Co.

The Rev. Frank M. Clendenin, Rector of St. Peter's Church at Westchester, N.Y., against whom charges have been preferred by the Senior Warden and six of the Vestry with a view to ousting him him from his position, was indorsed last night by an enthusiastic greeting of about 200 parishioners, at Bowne's store.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 23.--The pitch of the great organ in the Springer Music Hall, the largest organ in the country, is being lowered a little less than half a tone.
The bookmakers' cushion-carroms billiard tournament, a sweepstakes of $100 each, was begun at Joe O'Conner's Columbia Rooms on Broadway yesterday.
A musical and dramatic performance will be given at the Lyceum Theatre on the afternoons of Feb. 23 and 24 for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms and Hospital fund.
Lizzie Smith, aged 2 years, the youngest child of Charles Smith, a plumber, died in a fireman's arms yesterday after being rescued from the second story of 16 Pike-street, where the parents lived.

Financial difficulties caused Charles F. Tonjes, a former member of the Brooklyn Board of Education and of the Produce Exchange of this city, to stoop th such measures that prudence has dictated his withdrawal from public gaze for the last two weeks and has caused much trouble to his family.

The article of Senator EDMUNDS in the January number of Harper's Magazine on "The Tariff" is extremely interesting as showing in what a fog of general fallacies and with what a profound and grotesque ignorance of facts the distinguished Republican leader deals with the one question of supreme importance to his party.

ALBANY, Jan. 23.--Senator Pierce of Brooklyn wants some information in regard to the fees of Quarantine to enable him "to vote intelligently," as the legislative saying is, upon the Fassett bill for the reduction of these fees.

The statements that the mortality among horses had been increased to a frightful extent during the past week by a mysterious disease, which was described as baffling the skill of the veterinary surgeons, does not appear to be justified by the facts.
At the Metropolitan Opera House last evening an audience of comforting proportions listened to a moderately disturbing performance of "Lohengrin."

BERLIN, Jan. 23.--The Bundesrath today considered the estimates of the Military bill.
None of the strikers at the Clark Thread Works in Newark went to work yesterday morning, though they had been told that their places would be filled by others if they were not on hand.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 23.--The remains of Eliza Ballou Garfield were placed this afternoon beside those of her son, James A. Garfield, in the receiving vault at Lake View Cemetery. Funeral services were held at the Garfleld homestead, in Mentor.

An auctioneer occupied the platform at the Brooklyn Tabernacle last night, and instead of the stirring utterances with which the Rev. T. De Witt Talmago is wont to address his congregation, the words which rang through the sacred building were, Going at five hundred dollars, at five hundred and fifty, at six hundred do I hear it?" and so forth.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Jan. 23.--Three shocks of earthquake were reported about midnight last night. Houses four miles from town and four miles from each other were violently shaken.

Foreign dispatches yesterday announced that German telegraph officials had been instructed to receive no cable dispatches from this country by way of the Commercial Cable, and it was added that the American Minister at Berlin had had his attention called to the matter.

The Brooklyn Union for Christian Work has been in existence for 21 years, and its members and friends celebrated that fact last night by formally opening the new building lately erected by the union on Schermerhorn-street, near Court, Brooklyn.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23.--The second election of the Board of Editors of the Yale Lit. was held last night by the Junior Class in the Academic.

The tramp steamer Laju, loaded deeply with a general cargo and ready to sail for London this morning, lay at Pier 20 North River yesterday afternoon getting up steam and taking the last packages into her hold.

The steamer Frank Preston arrived from Pikeville yesterday afternoon and brought intelligence of an encounter between the pursuing party and the Hatfields on last Saturday. PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--The disastrous conflagration in the retail millinery and ladies' furnishing district at Eighth and Arch streets last night was gotten under complete control at about 2 o'clock this morning, after a half dozen firms had been completely burned out and some 15 or 20 other establishments had been seriously damaged by fire and water.

Joseph Q. Laws, merchant tailor at the FifthAvenue Hotel, one of the oldest and best-known tailors in the city, made an assignment yesterday to George J. Vestner. He is about 62 years old, has been in business nearly 40 years, and succeeded Childs Laws 22 years ago. He has had no rating at Bradstreet's for two years on account of his slowness in payments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24.--Frederick C. Brightly, the author of "Brightly's Digest" and other notable law books, died this afternoon at his residence, 29 Harvey-street, Germantown, at the age of 76 years. On Aug. 14, 1886, his wife, Sarah Brightly, died, at the age of 81, being his senior by six years. At that time Mr. Brightly himself was lying very ill from Bright's ...

Spurred by reports in the local newspapers and by the widespread uneasiness thereby created the Grand Jury of Kings County yesterday made official inquiry in regard to the condition of smallpox in Brooklyn. Dr. Otterson, the Health Commissioner, and members of the sanitary staff were questioned, and imparted their opinions freely.

The kitchen arrangements of an up-town boarding house were aired yesterday before Judge Pitshke and a jury in the City Court, and, according to some witnesses, were not of a savory kind. Arthur M. Hunter is a stock broker who does not weigh 100 pounds. S. Morris Pryor is a stock broker who weighs twice as much. Arthur Hunter is a member of the Stock Exchange and a pet of Wall-street. He is a lightweight athlete, a rider to the hounds, and known in all the fashionable sporting circles as a "gentleman jockey" almost without a peer.

Asbury H. Perkins is a typical specimen of the verdant countryman, who enjoys the distinction of being a wealthy farmer and County Commissioner of Lancaster County, S.C. Nevertheless, these dignities have failed to save him from a folly bordering upon crime. Last Christmas Eve he left home with $200,000 in township bonds, which he intended depositing in the vaults of the Boston Safe Deposit and Loan Company.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 24.--The accident yesterday afternoon on the Rutland and Washington Division of the Delaware and Hudson system, near Baxterville, proves to have been even worse than was at first anticipated. At least 16 persons were injured, and of this number 4 were so seriously hurt that their recovery is considered a matter of doubt. The ill-fated train left Rutland at 10:40 o'clock and was to have ...

The lecture room of the Young Men's Christian Association was well filled last evening by members of the literary society connected with the institution, who had gathered to discuss the question of "Ballot Reform." In order to have the subject placed well before them they had invited Allen Thorndike Rice to address them upon the subject before they expressed their own views.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--Mr. Cox, Nationalist member of Parliament for Clare, who was arrested in London yesterday after leading the Irish police such a long chase, has arrived at Ennis, where he will be tried for addressing proclaimed League meetings. He was remanded without bail. The council of the Liberal Federation to-day condemned the Government for the ...

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 24.--There are no new developments in the First National Bank matter to-day. The whereabouts of the bookkeeper and Cashier are still unknown. The investigation is still being pushed, and it may be a week before anything official is announced. It is a settled fact, however, that the bank vault was not cleaned out, as bundles of currency were found there and counted this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--After yelling and screaming for six or seven hours in a way that would have been funny if it had not been disgraceful the Republicans of this district, represented by a convention almost wholly composed of colored men, have elected two sets of delegates to the National Convention at Chicago. One of the delegations is for Blaine and one is for Sherman.

At yesterday's session of the Board of Aldermen there were received, through the Mayor, resolutions from the Board of Supervisors of Richmond County, Staten Island, inviting the co-operation of the cities of New-York and New-Jersey in arranging an international exhibition on Staten Island to celebrate the fourth centenary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus. It was referred to the Committee on Law.

The Trustees, friends, and pupils of the Association for the Improved Instruction of Deaf Mutes celebrated the opening of the annex of their large and handsome institution on Lexington-avenue last evening. The annex is on the Sixty-eighth-street side of the building, where it has a frontage of 42 feet. Its depth is 38 feet.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24.--The Rev. Hiram C. Haydn, D.D., was installed to-day as President of the Western Reserve University, which at the present time includes Adelbert College and a medical department. His advent to the Presidency was signaled by the Trustees abolishing co-education and announcing the project of a separate college in the university for women.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday said that the objections urged by him against the Elm-street improvement in his interview of the preceding day were intended to be understood as objections to the plans thus far proposed and the manner of carrying them out rather than against the improvement in general. A flag floated at half mast over the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, Myrtle-street, near Myrtleavenue, yesterday, and a large crowd was gathered about the building. A long procession, bearing furled flags draped with crape, made its appearance on its way down Myrtle-avenue, followed by a hearse and carriages, and drew up at the Lyceum.

READING, Penn., Jan. 24.--The reply of the miners' joint committee to President Corbin's statement is now being discussed in business and labor circles. The opinion gains ground that there is no prospect of an early settlement of the strike, and that the statements and counter-statements now being given to the public accomplish nothing.

An almost successful attempt on the part of three prisoners to break jail was discovered and frustrated yesterday by Warden Baker of the Essex County Jail at Newark. For some weeks past William Smith, a notorious burglar who broke from the penitentiary at Caldwell when Convict Williams was shot by a keeper, has been confined in the jail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24.--By the very decided majority of 39 in a vote of 69 the Senate decided to-day to take the subject of the Governmental debt of the Pacific Railroads away from the Committee on the Judiciary and put it in charge of a special committee. There was some opposition and a good deal of debate before the action was taken.

A colored man with a soft voice and pleasant face riveted attention in Judge Lawrence's part of the Supreme Court yesterday as a witness in the Paine-Dunn suits, which were called for trial Monday. He impressed the jurors and lawyers, interested and disinterested, as a remarkably good witness. He was the personal attendant and nurse of Grandfather Paine for several years and became greatly attached to him.
BELGRADE, Jan. 24.--The Chamber of Deputies has been dissolved. Elections for new members will be held on March 4.

LONDON, Jan. 24.--The lull in war alarms which began on Saturday has now become so marked that everybody is congratulating himself on the war scare having permanently ended. This it has by no means done. It may be a week and it may be longer, but a grave recurrence of the panic is sure to come. It seems to be true, however, that the tone of official Russia, for the moment, has become very peaceable.

PANAMA, Jan. 16.--The rainy season is now considered pretty well over, and great joy prevails in consequence, for hopes are widely entertained that work will now be resumed in the line of the canal generally. The funeral of Warren R. Hedden, whose sad death occurred in the early part of the week, was held last night in the Grand Lodge Room of the Masonic Temple.

The American Jockey Club's Executive Committee, at its meeting yesterday afternoon, accepted the resignation of Capt. J.H. Coster, Secretary of the club, offered some time ago, and elected Frederick A. Lovecraft to succeed the Captain, Mr. Lovecraft was recently elected Treasurer in place of Judge A.C. Monson.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 25.--A shooting affray occurred here at 7 o'clock this evening, County Clerk Ham O. Williams being shot fatally by Alderman Sam Willes. The cause of the trouble was a dispute about some unimportant matter. Both men are well known. Williams has been taken home. He is alive, but unconscious.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25.--The storm which prevailed in Dakota yesterday has not yet subsided, and is advancing eastward, as the temperature in Minnesota has fallen rapidly. The Sioux City Division of the Omaha was abandoned both in and out of St. Paul last evening, ...

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 25.--Arrangements have been made to have the Home Market Club banket take place on Thursday evening, Feb. 9. Senator Sherman, Congressmen McKinley and Goff, and the other guests will all attend, as had been previously arranged.

GENESEO, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The report of the Superintendent of the salt reservation at Syracuse is of very great interest because it bears also upon the salt fields in Michigan and in the western part of the State of New-York.

Karl Klindworth's second piano recital at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon was devoted to Chopin. Mr. Klindworth has been so intimately associated with the study of this composer that a goodly number of persons assembled to hear him.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25.--A number of college men, most of them graduates, met this afternoon at one of the hotels and organized a University Baseball Association, with A.L. Packard as President, F.H. Parker as Vice-President, and F.M. Tilden as Treasurer.

The Sugar Trust seems to be getting along very comfortably. It has decided to close up Moller, Sierck Co.'s refinery at Greenpoint, which is in the combination.

The North German Lloyd steamship Elder and the Erie ferryboat Pavonia had a collision yesterday morning in the North River, by which the ferryboat was much damaged, her 80 or so passengers were somewhat frightened, and the steamship scratched.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The annual report of the State Assessors submitted to the Legislature to-day shows an increase in real and personal property since 1886 of $136,445,834.
The annual meeting of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association was held yesterday afternoon at its offices in the Potter Building, and was well attended.
Despite the horrible weather the annual reception of the Eastern Boulevard Club, which was held last evening at the Lexington-Avenue Opera House, was great success.

The Board of Directors of the Traders and Travelers' Accident Company held a special meeting yesterday at the company's offices, 287 Broadway, at which the resignation of General Manager Russell P. Hoyt was tendered.
The trial jury in the case of Antonio D'Andrea was completed at recess yesterday, and Assistant District Attorney Davis opened the case for the people at the afternoon session.

The final music-drama of Wagner's Niebelungen tetealogy, "Die Gotterdammerung," was performed for the first time in America last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before an audience of uncommon size and brilliancy.

The Ohio Society of New-York held a special meeting last night at its rooms, 236 Fifth-avenue, and took appropriate action respecting the death of Charles W. Moulton, who was one of the Vice-Presidents of the society. Addresses were delivered by Gen. Wager Swayne, Col. W.L. Strong, C.C. Shayne, and Col. W.P. Fogg, and eulogistic resolutions were adopted.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 25.--The annual meeting of the Norfolk and New-Brunswick Hosiery Company, the largest manufactory in the town, employing 1,200 workmen, was held here to-day.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The assignment of Gregg Co. of Trumansburg, N.Y., to Samuel D. Halliday of Ithaca was recorded to-day.
Dr. Albert Strang, 45 years old, who lived at Yorktown, Westchester County, was brought to Bellevue Hospital, Monday, suffering from dementia.
Murat Halstead of Cincinnati is at the Brevoort House. Francisco A. Manzanares of New-Mexico is at the Buckingham Hotel.

BROWNWOOD, Texas, Jan. 25.--City Marshal Butler and wife were kept up nearly all to Tuesday night by a sick child. About 3 A.M., both fell asleep with the baby lying between them. When they awoke the baby was gone.
