Policeman Francis O'Dea, who is on trial in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, for manslaughter for having struck and killed Edgar Smith on the night of Nov. 6, was the principal witness at yesterday's hearing.

The fifth game in the bookmakers' cushion carom billiard tournament, which is now being held in the Columbia Rooms, was played last evening, and it proved to be the most closely contested and exciting of the series so far played.

Five hundred and fifty brokers have signed the petition asking the Governors of the Stock Exchange to authorize dealings in petroleum certificates. This represents much over half of the membership of the Exchange, for many of the signatures are of firm names, including in some instances two or three brokers each.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--High license has received some attention from everybody around the Capitol to-day, including the Governor. The latter listened closely to what ex-Assemblyman Walter Howe of New-York had to say when that gentleman visited him in the morning.

Abraham Citron, a Russian who has recently made this country his home, has secured an energetic as well as good-looking wife, thought it took a night in Ludlow-Street Jail and a prospect of a considerable period of incarceration to lead him up to the point of accepting the desirable lady's hand. Judge Ehrlich of the City Court tied the knot.

Superintendent of School Buildings Jasper officially investigated yesterday the accident which occurred at Grammar School No. 4 on Wednesday. It was found that a piece of molding over the door in the primary department room, presided over by Miss Ross, had fallen just as the children were leaving for their noon recess.
ALBANY, Jan. 25.--The Senate took up the Fassett bill reducing the fees of Quarantine to-day and progressed it to a third reading. To this none of the Democrats offered any opposition.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 25.--At 3 o'clock this morning the great trotting sire Happy Medium, 25 years old, the property of Gen. W. T. Withers, of Fairlawn Stock Farm, this city, died of spinal meningitis.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25.--Isaac Stanley was sentenced to-day to five years in the penitentiary, the lightest penalty for his crime.

PARIS, Jan. 25.--The Perfect of Nancy has made a report of the Barbaret-Hahuemann frontier affair, in which he says that the French frontier was not violated by Hahnemann when he took Barbaret's gun away. Barbaret has not made a formal complaint to the Government against Hahnemann, and therefore the incident cannot be made the subject of diplomatic representations.

The Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday disposed of a great deal of routine business. The leasing of the rink building at Broadway and Sixty-seventh-street to the Second Battery for an armory at $5,000 a year for five years was approved. Controller Myers was authorized to sell the Jay-Street Ferry franchise at auction Feb. 1 at not less than $2,000 a year.
Among some of the members of the Produce Exchange there has been a desire to quicken the communicating of news between the Exchange and points in the South and West.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 25.--Louis Drucker, a New-Canaan constable, was murdered this afternoon by Jacob Keeler. Drucker had a warrant for the arrest of Keeler on a charge of selling liquor without a license, and went to Keeler's house to arrest him. Keeler heard that he had been complained of, and, armed with a ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25.--H.B. West, proprietor of the new Johnson House, was arrested in November for violating the law which requires keepers of public houses who serve substitute butter to conspicuously display the sign "Oleomargarine used here."

If a great majority of the Metropolitan Opera House Company (Limited) stockholders act at the meeting to-morrow evening pursuant to their sentiments expressed in reply to the Directors' circular of Saturday last there will ...
LONDON, Jan. 25.--The steamship Olympia, (Br.,) Capt. Swain, sid, from Naples for New-York Jan. 23.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25.--The special correspondent of the Baltimore Sun at Rome writes: "A number of important changes in connection with the government of the Catholic Church in the United States are contemplated. Though nothing has been formulated yet, it is agreed upon in ecclesiastical circles that Archbishop Williams of Boston will be made a Cardinal at ...

MONTREAL, Jan. 25.--The annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Quebec opened at the Masonic Chambers to-day. There was an unusually large attendance of delegates, which was due to the interest taken in the motions to exclude tavern keepers from the organization ...

The owner of the fee of an opera box in New-York does not necessarily repose on roses, as he appears to do when viewed from the family circle. In the case of the Metropolitan Opera House he paid, to begin ...
The curling pond at Central Park presented a most animated appearance yesterday afternoon, with seven rinks on the ice and 56 players at the hacks to do battle for the new ...
The Police Captains and Sergeants are greatly dissatisfied with the new helmets the Police Commissioners have adopted as their head gear when on duty.

About two score of fine-looking men, most of them elderly, sat on either side of a long table in the main saloon of the big steamship City of Berlin as she lay at her pier in Jersey City yesterday afternoon. They were the eastern passenger agents of the Inman and International Company, and they had been invited to partake of a lunch on board in celebration ...

There was a pretty church wedding in St. Barnabas's Episcopal Church at Irvington-onthe-Hudson last evening, Miss Harriet A. Rutter, youngest daughter of James H. Rutter, who at the time of his death was President of the ...
John Lance Haring and John B. Collins were tried yesterday before Judge Dixon, at Patterson, on indictments for keeping a disorderly house, which meant that they sold pools on horse races,

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 25.--Both houses of the Legislature met at noon to-day, and after comparing journals on the vote for United States Senator President Hull declared James F. Wilson elected Senator from Iowa for six years, beginning March 4, 1889.

The location of the Democratic National Convention and the choosing of a successor to Hubert O. Thompson on the National Committee are matters said to have been discussed at a meeting of Tammany's Sub-Executive Committee yesterday at Tammany Hall.

WINNIPEG, Jan. 25.--The explosion in the Wellington Mines at the town to Nanaimo, British Columbia, which occurred on Tuesday, has resulted in more serious disaster than was at first anticipatad. Two hundred men were in the mine at the time of the explosion, and it is now certain that the majority of them have perished.

Yesterday afternoon James H. Holmes, living at 1,577 Seventh-avenue, and A.C. Dupont, of 805 Third-avenue, were brought before Justice Gorman, in the Harlem Police Court, for fighting on the Ninth-avenue elevated station at Ninety-thirdstreet. Dupont is a collector for a book firm in Nassau-street and was sent to collect a bill from Holmes.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Jan. 25.--Monday night the Post Office at Annapolis was entered by burglars, the through mail bags from Yarmouth for Halifax, from Halifax for Yarmouth, ...

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 25.--The report of the Treasurer of Harvard College for the year ending Aug 31, 1887, shows the receipts to have been $2,792,114, and the balance remaining over the disbursements, $103,933.
Dr. George S. Meigs, who committed suicide Monday morning by taking prussic acid in his office, 133 West Thirty-fourth-street, had his life insured in various mutual associations for $11,000.

Valentine Kuhn, a barber at 347 Firststreet, Jersey City, had Lorenzo Katz, a butcher of the same street, arrested yesterday morning and taken before Justice Stilsing on a charge of assault, and was in turn accused of abducting Katz's niece, Johanna Katz.

A fire at 93, 95, and 97 William-street, near Maiden-lane, last night, resulted in the destruction of property of the value of $100,000. At about 11:20 o'clock smoke was discovered issuing from the third-floor windows, and the alarm then given was quickly followed by a a second and third signal.
The stockholders of the Navassa Phosphate Company of New-York held an annual meeting yesterday which has seldom been equaled for excitement and contention.

ALBANY, Jan. 25.--At a recent meeting of the State Civil Service Commission a resolution was passed asking the Attorney-General to advise the commission "whether the statutes giving a preference to honorably-discharged soldiers for appointments to office under the civil service acts are confined to honorably-discharged soldiers of the late war, (1861 to 1865,) or whether in his opinion such statutes embrace any honorably-discharged soldier."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The hearing in the carload lot cases was resumed by the Inter-State Commerce Commission this morning. John C. O'Donnell, President of the Pittsburgh Retail Grocers' Protective Association, was called as a witness, and in answer to inquiries, stated that in his opinion the discrimination between carload and less than carload ...

PORT AU PRINCE, Hayti, Jan. 10.--The increase in the number of guards at this point and the dispatch of messengers to the northern provinces would indicate that the Government is not free from apprehension. In order to understand the present situation a glance at the near past will be necessary.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25.--The evidence in the tally sheet forgery cases closed to-day, and the argument was begun this afternoon with a speech by District Attorney Sellers. There will probably be four or five speeches, and it is hoped to get the case to the jury by Friday night at furthest. The defense has done all that it can to give the case a political aspect.

SHENECTADY, Jan. 25.--Last night when the news reached this city that the Union College Trustees had failed to elect a President at their meeting in Albany the students became very indignant. Immediately after the chapel services this morning the Fellows held a college ...

Mrs. Julia Hanna, who kept a boarding house at 68 West Nineteenth-street, yesterday, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, accused Mrs. Annie J. Strong of having swindled her out of $286, and wanted her committed for obtaining money and board under false pretenses and for violating the boarding-house act.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25.--"I am not a candidate and neither would I accept the nomination for President," said George W. Childs of the Public Ledger to-day when questioned in reference to the published statement that Mr. James McManes would go to the Republican National Convention and there work and vote for Mr. Child's nomination.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 25.--The customs officials in Toronto have made a seizure, on the ground of false and fraudulent valuation, of a span of horses, two or three carriages, harness, trappings, , belonging to I. Cohnfeld, who lately left New-York under peculiar circumstances.
The subject of nominating or not nominating a candidate for President is beginning to agitate the United Labor Party.

In due and proper order the Governing Committee of the Union Club had arranged to try Gen. William Cutting at its regular monthly meeting last night. But the committee did nothing of the kind. It met, its members traveling painfully through the snow to the clubhouse, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25.--It came to light to-day that a secret meeting of the leading committeemen of the striking Reading miners was held at Mahanoy City last Mondny night, and at it such action was taken as will probably lead to an ending of the miners' troubles.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 25.--While the funeral of Benjamin Munday was in progress today the spirited team of hearse horses ran away, and, colliding with a lamp post, broke it short off and overturned the hearse. The remains were tossed about within the hearse, but the coffin way not damaged.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 25, via Galveston. --The Presidential campaign may be considered well under way, Gen. Diaz being the leading candidate. More than 50 interior newspapers have come out in favor of his re-election, and a number of Diaz clubs have been organized in different parts of the republic.
The backbone of the strike at the Clark Thread Works in Newark is undoubtedly broken; but much dissatisfaction prevails.

Despite the bad weather last night a very fair audience attended the concert of Marie Biro De Marion at Steinway Hall. It was a very generous audience, or else one that wanted its money's worth. Every number was encored with great impartiality.

Owing to the storm the 10-mile amateur race for the National Amateur Skating Association's medal, which was to have been skated at Fleetwood Park last night, was postponed until to-night, but as the conditions are not likely to be favorable for some time the race will probably be declared "off."

A respectably-appearing young man, who said that his name was Robinson, called at Police Headquarters last night and made inquiries for his sister Lily who, he said, had been arrested by Central Office detectives and was locked up at Police Headquarters.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 25.--There are no further developments of interest concerning the muddled affairs of the First National Bank, whose doors are still closed. Bank Examiner Clark and several assistants are hard at work upon the books, which are in such a tangled condition that no definite information can be given to the public for several days.

The Rev. Justin D. Fulton lectured last evening at Cooper Union on his book, the title of which is "Why Priests Should Wed." Tickets for the lecture cost $1 each, and those who bought tickets were presented with copies of the book. Mr. Fulton was very hoarse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--There is but one opinion about the character of the Republican convention held here yesterday to elect delegates to the National Convention. It is by everybody referred to as altogether disgraceful and disreputable. To persons who recall the period when right of suffrage was exercised the ...
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25.--The Republican State Convention completed its work to-night by nominating a full State ticket and appointing a delegation to the Chicago National Convention.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Conductors and engineers in the employ of the Erie Railroad Company are much exercised just now over an order issued by the officials of the road requiring them to carry "reliable watches" ...

Little Fannie Berger, who fell between the cars of a Third-avenue elevated train at Ninth-street and so narrowly escaped being killed, at midnight Tuesday, was feeling more comfortable last night at her home, 221 East One Hundred and Ninth-street.
A son of Peter Trelde, who died in a coach on Monday while being removed from St. Peter's Hospital to his home, 136 Third-avenue, Brooklyn, appealed to Coroner Rooney yesterday to hold an inquest.

PARIS, Jan. 25.--Eugene Labiche, the celebrated dramatic author, who died on Monday, had suffered from heart disease for years, but of late his existence had been a prolonged torture. His cage became complicated by lung fever and liver trouble.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 25.--Rochester has for many years felt keenly the need of a first-rate concert auditorium and opera house, and from time to time many schemes have been set on foot to provide the city with such a place for amusements of a high order.
The will of David Carruthers, a resident of Tomales, Marion County, Ca., was filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Fourscore members of the New-York Association of the Theta Delta Chi College Society sat down last evening in the Hotel Brunswick to partake of the third annual dinner of the organization in this city. The dampness without did not affect the ardor within.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and Associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 646--James Black, respondent, vs. The Brooklyn City Railroad Company, appellant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--Leave of absence for one year on Surgeon's certificate of disability has been granted Capt. Henry G. Burton, Assistant Surgeon, to take effect when he is able to travel. The leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate ...

MR. BUTTERWORTH has brought the subject of commercial union with Canada before the House of Representatives by a resolution with a long preamble, the substance of the resolution being that the United States should "use all proper ...

There is spirit in the performance of "Carmen" by Mr. Foster's company at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, and Bizet's lovely music is always enjoyable. Mr. A.D. Saxon displaced Mr. Clark as Escamillo last evening, and the change was for the better.

Harper's Magazine is doing excellent service to the public in the series of papers it is publishing concerning questions of importance before Congress, and in none has it been more fortunate than in the one on ...
MADRID, Jan. 25.--Ex-Queen Isabella Will be permitted to live in Seville.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25.--The President has sent the following nominations to the Senate: Interior Department.--To be Receivers of Public Moneys: Absalom H. Weir at Springfield, Mo.; Robert Kennedy at Shasta, Cal.; J.F. Linthicam at Sacramento, Cal.; Lewis C. Granger at Marysville, Cal.; John J. Orr of Kentucky at Buffalo, Wyoming ...
A meeting of the pedestrians who are to enter the six days' go-as-you-please race which begins in Madison-Square Garden Feb. 5 was held in the office of the Sporting Times yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--Optimism is the rule of tha hour. To-day is the thirtieth anniversary of the marriage of the Crown Prince of Germany, and to read the leaders of the papers here and in Germany and the addresses sent to him one would think he had only got a troublesome cold.

The pretty fence which lends an air of seclusion to Mrs. Langtry's house in Twentythird-street, and which extends far out on the sidewalk beyond the limits allowed by law, was not ruthlessly torn from its foundations by the city authorities yesterday and carted away to the resting-place of apple vendors' stands and obnoxious signs.

In the Paine-Dunn suits now on trial before Judge Lawrence in the Supreme Court the third day of the proceedings opened drearily enough, and when Lawyer Kellogg announced that he and Almon Goodwin would alternate in ...

Wall-street continued yesterday to enjoy the heroic chronicle of how well Broker Arthur Hunter of the Stock Exchange met big Broker S. Morris Pryor of the Consolidated Exchange-- met him and tried to destroy him in a pugilistic ...

Spain has no longer any intention of playing second fiddle to the rest of the world, at least so far as gigantic expositions are concerned. It promises to be the theatre of a world's fair in the coming Spring.

A long string of new securities was added yesterday to the list dealt in on the Stock Exchange, including $616,000 additional first mortgage consolidated 5 per cent. gold bonds of the Cincinnati, Jackson and Mackinaw Railroad, making $2,016,000 listed to date; $1,494,000 ...
NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 25.--Grave apprehensions are felt for the safety of the steamboat Alabama which left Mobile for this port on the morning of Jan. 14.

With the thermometer standing at 8 above zero several thousand people were kept stamping the ground around the Sands-street station of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday morning while a wayward car, which endeavored to make the trip to this city without getting a proper grip upon the cable, was hauled back and made to submit.

The bids of the electric light and gas companies for the privilege of lighting Brooklyn's streets during 1888 are all in the hands of the Aldermanic Committee on Lamps and Gas, and will be considered at a meeting to be held to-morrow night.

The Board of Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art met yesterday to consider the case of ex-Superintendent John Ward Stimson, which was brought up before them on an appeal from the pupils of the Art Schools that the board would reconsider the action of the sub-committee already published with regard to Mr. Stimson.
One hundred and four lots of stocks, bonds, claims, , were sold at auction yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange by Adrian H. Muller Son.

"L'Abbe Constantin" has proved such a success in Paris that a company has already been organized to present the play in the French "provinces," and it is being equally well received on its tour. The traveling company embraces Messrs. Paul Deshayes, Angelo, Dorsay, Goudehalde, and Laferte, and Mmes. Harris, Charlotte Renard, Henriette Renard, ...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25.--The wife of T.B. Squire, Secretary of the Standard Oil Company, was in the police court to-day as prosecuting witness against her discharged cook, Jennie Hellis.

ALABNY, Jan. 25.--The members of the Democratic State Committee are slowly coming in. The meeting at which they will select a member of the National Committee in the place of the late Hubert O. Thompson will be held at the Delavan House at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.
William H. Brodie, one of the oldest and best known cotton brokers in New-York, was stricken down suddenly by illness at his office, 97 Pearl-street, yesterday morning.

LONDON, Jan. 25.--The Marquis of Ripon, in a speech at Ely this evening, denied that the proposed banquet at Dublin had been abandoned owing to difficulty in regard to the customary toast to the Queen.

A petition to the officers, Directors, and stockholders of the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company has been signed by many citizens, protesting against the proposed innovation of running the coaches on Sunday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25.--Richard Fitzgerald, who was serving a sentence of two years in the penitentiary and was confined in the south wing, escaped from his cell last night, leaving a dummy lying on his cot. He dodged the officers and guards until 9:30 o'clock, then climbed to the top of the wall, donned a guard's clothes, and, jumping to the ground outside, a distance of 35 feet, escaped.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 25.--The sub scribers to the Bell Telephone Company's service whose contracts extended beyond Nov. 17, 1886, the date of Rochester's great telephone strike, are all interested in the test suit that came off before Justice Rumsey, in the Circuit Court, this week.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25.--Breezy, sunshiny weather and a crowd 35,000 people assisted at the entrance of Borealis Rex this afternoon.

OTSEGO LAKE, Mich., Jan. 25.--A broken rail on the Smith and Foyer Lumber Railroad caused a train to jump the track near this place yesterday, and John Reardon and James Morrissey were killed. Five others were severely injured. The engineer and fireman escaped with slight bruises.

Mrs. Edna Perrin, who has been under several indictments for advertising the sale of "green goods," was brought to trial yesterday before Judge Cowing in Part II. General Sessions on one of the indictments.

ATHENS, Jan. 26.--M. Gennadius, the Greek Minister at London, has been ordered to proceed to Washington immediately, and to spare no efforts to induce the American Government to abolish the duty on currants.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--General Manager Stone of the Burlington has notified Chairman Faithern of the Northwestern Railway Freight Bureau that the guarantee given by the Chicago,

Bernhard Stern, the senior member of the dry goods firm of Stern Brothers, West Twentythird-street, died at his residence, 16 East Fifty-sixth-street, yesterday morning, after a short illness.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Jan. 26.--About 1 o'clock this morning three masked men entered the humble hut of Henry Merritts, an old woodsman, in Henderson Township, and demanded to be shown where his supposed wealth was concealed.

An enrollment of all the Republican voters of the city who have not been enrolled since Jan. 1, 1885, will take place in all the Assembly districts except the Eighth to-day, between 8 A.M. and 10 P.M., at the respective district headquarters.

If the men who navigate the harbor of New-York can bring any influence to bear upon the Assembly, it is likely that there will be a strong opposition to the passage of the bill introduced on Wednesday providing for the bridging of the Hudson River between Spuyten Duyvil and the Jersey shore.

BOSTON, Jan. 26.--T. Jefferson Coolidge has been elected President of the Boston and Lowell Road, in place of F.L. Higginson, who was found to be ineligible.
The change in the cast of "L'Abb Constantin" that was made at Wallack's Theatre last evening put an element in the performance of that charming play that was lacking previously.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 26.--The Albany Bonsilate Company, one of the largest concerns of the kind in the country, to-day concluded to wind up its affairs and close the business.
Many complaints have been made recently by people whose houses have been entered by firemen and the fire patrol for the purpose of putting out fires that thefts have been committed.

The New-York board of Uunderwriters met yesterday for the purpose, if possible, of evolving a plan that would clear the fire insurance atmosphere, obviate the necessity of throatcutting, and put business on a paying basis. About 75 members of the board were present. With about a dozen exceptions all the companies which do business in New-York were represented. It was stated that the absentees were "out of town."
The fact that Maurice Marques, a young Frenchman a who has had a room in the Hotel Dam for eight years past, was an inmate of Ludlow-Street Jail, and had been for a week.

Fan-tan and boc-hop-bu, two games of chance in which the Chinese in New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and other American cities are greatly interested, were described last night in a paper read by Stewart Culin of Philadelphia before the Numismatic and Archaeological Society of this city.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 26.--Bishop Edward G. Andrews delivered an eloquent sermon to the students of the Wesleyan University this morning, in observance of the day of prayer for colleges. This evening a prayer and praise service was held. College exercises were suspended throughout the day, and considerable religious interest was manifested.

The trial of Charles A. Curtis, who created considerable excitement in the District Attorney's office recently by saying that money had been used in securing in suspension of sentence in the case of John Nuttall, charged with petit larceny, was begun yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part III.
At the Metropolitan Opera House this evening Weber's "Euryanthe" will be sung.
ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The State's general fund is $150 richer than the State Treasurer estimated that it would be. Yesterday Deputy State Treasurer Danforth opened the mail.

Friends of Charles F. Tonjes, the ex-Produce Exchange broker whose financial misfortunes recently caused much wonder among his old associates, are congratulating themselves that he has had the good luck to have his affairs settled by the exertions of a friend, who devoted about three weeks to the task.

ROCKLAND, Me., Jan. 26.--The Hon. D.N. Moreland, Chairman of the Maine Board of Railroad Commissioners, has been observing the effect of the inter-State commerce law in Maine. Speaking on the subject, Mr. Moreland said:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 26.--Molly Wilkes, bay mare, 6 years, has been sold by E.S. Muir of Donerail, Ky., to William Redding of New-York for $10,000. She is by Young Jim, dam Augusta, by Alice West, and has a record of 2:24 .

LONDON, Jan. 26.--Whether one likes to call it "cheek" or courage, it is undeniable that the Comte de Lesseps is making a wonderful fight in the face of the Ministry's knock-down blow. His circular, although containing statements which those with even the slightest

Al Hayman, manager of Baldwin's and the California Theatre, San Francisco, is on his way to this city, where he will remain for the rest of the Winter after his arrival next Wednesday. He has joined with "Lucky" Baldwin, the owner of Baldwin's, in plans for making extensive alterations in that house, and $25,000 is to be expended in the changes.

CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 26.--Lastnight the American residents of Mexico held a large and enthusiastic meeting for the purpose of making suitable arrangements for the reception of Gen. Bragg, the newly-appointed United States Minister to Mexico.

ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The report of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad for the quarter ended Dec. 31 shows gross earnings of $164,625 and a deficiency from operating expenses of $28,557. The same quarter in 1886 gave gross earnings, $151,413 and deficiency, $45,331.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--The Right Hon. William Henry Smith, First Lord of the Treasury, and Government leader in the House of Commons, in a letter urges all the Conservative members in Parliament to be present on Feb. 9, when questions of the utmost importance will be submitted.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 26.--Mr. William T. Walters of this city will open his galleries of paintings on all Wednesdays from February to May, inclusive, on Saturdays during April, Easter Monday, and the 22d of February for the benefit of the poor of the city.
ALBANY, Jan. 26.--Ten years ago, in this very town, David B. Hill committed a blunder which lost him prestige in his party and all but cost him the confidence of his associates.

Judge Depue, at Newark, has granted a writ of certiorari removing to the Supreme Court the action of Judge Kirkpatrick in refusing to allow an agnostic to testify in his court. James Powers sued James Percy in Bloomfield, and Percy appealed to the Common Pleas.
CORNING, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Charles C.B. Walker died here this morning. He had been constantly ill since last Summer, when abdominal dropsy appeared as a result of chronic liver

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 26.--The Republican Convention adjourned after midnight this morning. It was nearly 1 o'clock when the fourth delegate at large was chosen to the National Convention, the delegates for the Second and Sixth Congressional Districts being selected today.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Dominick Grady, an aged peddler of Utica, and his wife were found dead in their bed at 62 Steuben-street, this city, this morning. Their death was caused by escaping illuminating gas from the street main through the sewer. Other families were affected, but none of them seriously.

The Freshmen of the School of Arts, Columbia College, held their regular monthly meeting yesterday. Some discussion arose over the action of the Sophomores in inscribing on the menus used at the Freshman dinner last Friday evening the muchmeaning word "fresh" in a shade greatly resembling that favored color of Erin's Isle.
ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 26.--Chancellor P.H. Mell of the University of Georgia died at his residence on the campus this morning at 6 o'clock.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 26.--The New-York Central station at Niagara Falls, containing the American Express, baggage, and carriage offices, besides the train house, caught fire at 12:30 P.M. to-day and burned to the ground, involving a loss of $50,000.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Jan. 26.--The Legislature met again to-day and after a brief session adjourned till March 1, to admit of the Ministerial elections taking place.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 26.--The Pennsylvania Company's reduction in passenger rates by selling 2,000-mile tickets for $40, good on all the company's lines west of Pittsburg, has been met by the Cincinnati, Washington and Baltimore with the same reduction for 2,000-mile tickets, and by the Erie, on its Western divisions, by a re

Princetonians assembled in force at the Hotel Brunswick last night and listened to a very entertaining lecture delivered by Prof. Young before the Princeton Club on the Princeton astronomical expedition to Russia last Summer.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 26.--A terrific explosion of dynamite occurred this morning at the Carbon Limestone Company's quarries, on the line of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Road, about 10 miles from Youngstown, Ohio.

BOSTON, Jan. 26.--A very good imitation of a Western blizzard, if indeed it is not the genuine article, settled down on New-England to-day. In the northern and western sections it was accompanied by an unusually heavy snowfall.
TORONTO, Jan. 26.--The Central Bank scandal seems to get worse each day. The court and liquidators inquire further into the dealings of its officials.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Provisions continued today in the upward movement developed Wednesday after the bear raid on Pork. Finding the market showed a disposition to recover quickly from forced depressions, traders of all classes became free buy
Much that is interesting can be found in a perusal of the fifty-second annual report of the Managers of the New-York Institution for the Blind.

The real estate brokers held a meeting yesterday afternoon and discussed the advisability of paying the deposits on contracts into a bank, in order to protect the buyer in the case of a doubtful seller. The brokers' committee will report on the subject. That interesting array of names--an alphabetical list of undesirable tenants--will be put to use immediately after the next board meeting. This step was decided upon yesterday.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan. 26.--After having been in session for three days sub-District No. 12 of Miners' National District No. 135, Knights of Labor, adjourned this evening. This is the body which represents that half of the Schuylkill region miners who are non-members

The Emigration Commissioners yesterday received a letter from Mayor Hewitt, who is an exoffice member of the board, interceding for the Rev. Emil Panelius, Pastor of a Lutheran church, who was recently denied admission to the Garden as missionary.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 26.--Last Fall, before the opening of the distilling season, meetings were held of nearly all the distillers of the State to devise means of relieving the overcrowded market.

The Archdeaconry of New-York held a meeting yesterday afternoon at Grace Chapel, in East Fourteenth-street, at which the Right Rev. Bishop Potter presided. The objects of the meeting were to hear the reports of the Committee on By-laws and for districting the city for charitable work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The President to-day issued an order directing the relief of Major William Ludlow, Corps of Engineers, as Engineer Commissioner of the District of Columbia, and detailing Major Charles W. Raymond, Corps of Engineers, now on duty in this city, to succeed him.
"Papa, do not drink to-night!" The words came in soft, pleading, tear-soaked tones from the sweet, golden-haired innocent that grasped his hand beseechingly.

The Directors of the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company operating the line of stages on Fifthavenue held a meeting yesterday afternoon and by unanimous vote decided to run their stages hereafter on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The White House lacked none of its appointments to-night. The reception to the Justices of the Supreme Court and Judges of the District was attended by a company of about 1,200 people.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 26.--Some hundreds of opinions touching revenue reform have been collected by the Plain Dealer from all sections of Ohio, the persons interviewed being representative men of both the Democratic and Republican Parties. Every Democrat and nearly every Republican favors a revision of the tariff.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 26.--An extensive and systematic coal steal has been discovered at Bainbridge, Ross County, Ohio, a small town on the Ohio Southern Railroad.

Some activity and much strength was shown in yesterday's stock market. Few stocks declined; many advanced; holders of securities were generally given courage by the day's record. Even the Gould stocks were kept steady and made to show a rising tendency.

The death is announced of Marie Rose Dumas, sister of the elder Dumas, and 5 years his senior. More than 40 years ago she joined the Order of St. Vincent de Paul. In her old age she was sent to Italy, a warm climate being almost a necessity to her. Her decease took place at Florence.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 26.--The people in the upper part of Rockland County are greatly agitated this week over the strange disappearance of William Gallagher of Grassy Point, a young man well known and much respected there.
The semi-annual concert of the students of the New-York College of Music, which was given at Chickering Hall last evening, was an exceedingly creditable entertainment to all concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--In the hearing in the carload lot cases this morning Markham Staples, one of the New-York agents of the Erie Road, and John Walsh, freight agent at Pier 19 North River, were examined as to the details of freight handling and transfers at New-York, and particularly as to the river and harbor service and the cost of the same.

The will of William Main Smillie, Vice-President of the American Bank Note Company, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court yesterday. It gives all his estate to his Executors--Leonard D. White and J. Truro Robertson--in trust for his widow, Josephine B. Smillie, and after her death it is to go to his daughter, Mrs. Minnie S. Pierce, to be held by her from the control of her husband.

People who are in the habit of assailing the Winter climate of New-York as the very worst in the world will be apt to modify their views if they have a read the tale of the inhabitants of Beardsley, Minn., that appeared in yesterday's papers.

The steamship Croma, Capt. W.R. Lord, from Leith Jan. 1 and Dundee Jan. 7, reached port yesterday after a voyage of continual struggle with adverse winds and heavy seas. She encountered strong southwest gales to Jan. 18 and then a gale from the northeast with frost and snow.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 26.--The Superintendents of the various divisious on the Pennsylvania Company's lines west of Pittsburg are holding a conference on the wage question.

There was an accident on the stage of the Academy of Music last night in full view of the spectators. It was in the third act of "Mazulin" during the harlequinade, and Tommy Tet, the new clown, was attracting general attention.

At the meeting of the Shakespeare Society in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, last evening, W.H. Fleming read a pager on "The First Folio Shakespeares in New-York City." He said the literary value of the first folio of Shakespeare's plays could not be overestimated.

Thomas Patrick Conneff, late of England, champion runner of the world at distances of from two to four miles, was given a rousing welcome to this country last night by the Manhattan Athletic Club at its house, 524 Fifthavenue, Between 300 and 400 members of

The fifth game of the bookmakers' cushion carrom tournament was placed between Dave Johnson and Tom Childs at the Columbia Rooms last night. Childs, who had to make 120 points to Johnson's 150, backed himselft at odds of $100 to $97 before he picked up his cue.

John Ward Stimson, formerly Superintendent of the Metropolitan Museum Art Schools, at Third-avenue and Forty-ninth-street, received official notice yesterday from Acting Chairman W.C. Prime of the Executive Committee that
James H. Lamb, whose father, Thomas Lamb, died at his home, 317 Lafayette-avenue, Brooklyn, on Dec. 31, leaving an estate valued at $200,000, began yesterday a contest of his father's will.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Michael Fleming was arrested yesterday on the charge of stealing about $1,000 in diamonds, jewelry, and money from Mrs. George W. Flower, a wealthy widow by whom he was employed as coachman.

President John Newell of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad and Chauncey Andrews left last night for their homes. When Mr. Newell arrived here on Sunday he came from New-York. When he got on the Pennsylvania Railroad train he pulled out his annual pass, but was surprised to find that it was dated 1887.
News reached Rutland, Vt., Sunday from the Consul at Yokohama, Japan, of the death by drowning of Charles H. Ripley, son of the late Gen. W.Y. Ripley of Center Rutland.
Surrogate Ransom has under consideration the appointment of Richard J. Morrisson, the Public Administrator, to take charge of the estate of Emiliano Bergamini, the Italian banker at 15 Centrestreet.

PARIS, Jan. 26.--The boulevard wits are having great fun to-day concerning a comic sheet hailing presumably from America, giving correct indications as to how an art gallery should look according to Anthony Comstock.
The Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Fund Association yesterday took final action in regard to the amount which shall be raised and expended for the proposed memorial.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--To-day a committee of the Knights of Labor consisting of Edward Moore, Henry Bennett, and Joseph Cahill appeared before the Attorney-General and asked that a quo warranto be issued against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company with a view to a forfeiture of its charter.

The Western Coal Dealers' Association yesterday at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel agreed that the supply of coal is ample in its territory and that no symptoms of trouble in its mines are apparent. No increase of prices was made.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 26.--It is announced that Janeway Co. have made a reduction in wages for the next six months. It was found necessary either to make a general reduction or discharge some of the employes, as the orders received were less than two-thirds those of last year. The employes and the firm are on the best of terms.

Palestine Commandery's Knights made a gallant display at Metropolitan Opera House last evaning, and they danced long and merrily. It was a gala night for the Masonic fraternity and many of the high officers of the order took part in the festivities.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 26.--The Government will attach an officer of the general staff to each local brigade of troops except three, who will be charged with organizing arrangements, preparing for mobilization, and supervising the tactical drill of the reserve battalions. A flotilla, consisting of two steamers and two transports, has been formed on the Amu-Daria River.
DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 26.--The Republican Congressional Convention of the Eleventh District began its session at Ishpeming in the upper peninsula yesterday afternoon with a full delegation.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 26.--Mrs. Anna Parmlee, who was born in Vermont, April 29, 1784, died today near Clinton, in this county, on the second anniversary of the death of a maiden sister, Thankful Stanton, aged 99 years, who lived with her. Other members of the family were long lived. Mrs. Parmlee lived in the town of Paris until 1809, when she removed to the place where she died.

The twenty-fourth annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association of New-York will be given this evening at 6 o'clock in the large banquet bail at Delmonico's.

ALBANY, Jan. 26.--The Harlem Republican Club was incorporated to-day with these officers: President--Andrew B. Humphrey; Vice-Presidents --Charles A. Patrick and John A. Colvin; Corresponding Secretary--Charles D. Baker; Recording Secretary--John E. Vandecarr; Treasurer--Andrew M. Underhill.

In order to further improve the facilities of travel between New-York and Atlantic City the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will on Jan. 27 add a second parlor car to the one now in service between the two points, leaving NewYork at 1 P.M.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 26.--There was another surprise for society gossips in the Tyson-Johns wedding to-day.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 26.--Eddie Gould, with First Vice-President Clark of the Missouri Pacific and their party, arrived here yesterday on their special train en route north from a visit to the Mexican border.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 26.--President McMillan of the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railroad has appointed George T. Jarvis Superintendent of that new enterprise, which is now just on the point of completion.
The Church of the Holy Spirit, Sixtysixth-street and Madison-avenue, was crowded last evening at the marriage of Miss Lillie Cohu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A.B. Cohu, to William Howard Barnard.
M. Gr vy was troubled by only 14 visitors on New Year's Day. On the same anniversary last year he had to receive nearly 8,000.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--Ignatius M. Pribyl, a dealer in guns, confessed judgement to the amount of $48,384 this afternoon in favor of Allanson H. Paxton.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 26.--A notable change in the methods of Connecticut dairy farming is going on in the establishments throughout the State of a large number of creameries for the manufacture of butter.

Judge Moore charged the jury in the trial of Officer Francis O'Dea, indicted for manslaugter in the second degree for the killing of Edgar Smith, yesterday in the Sessions Court, Brooklyn, and at 11 o'clock the jury retired.

The Atlas Line stemship Atlas, from Kingston, yesterday brought A. Petersen, the mate, and eight of the crew of the bark Nordenskjold, which went ashore at Jacmel on Jan. 1. The bark was a total loss. She was bound from Havre for Jacmel with a general cargo.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 26.--The Schedule Committee of the National Baseball League concluded its work last night and the members left for their homes.

Chickering Hall has been engaged by the Citizens' Committee on High License for a non-partisan mass meeting on Monday evening, Feb. 6, in the interests of high license legislation now pending in the Legislature.

George Gunton delivered Wednesday evening the second of his series of lectures on social questions in the Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton's church in West Forty-eighth-street, speaking on the general law of progress. He defined progress as the movement from the simple to the complex.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26.--A very important decision was rendered yesterday by Judge Gresham in the Central Iowa Railroad foreclosure case. A year or two ago a firm of extensive grain shippers made a contract in Iowa with the Central Iowa Railroad for certain rebates on their shipments.

NYACK, Jan. 27.--Burglars have made it very unpleasant for some residents of Haverstraw this week, and no progress has yet been made in apprehending the thieves. They made a good haul in a couple of places, and succeeded in getting away with their booty without being detected.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27.--The management of the Reading Railroad Company has ordered that 10 cents per ton on all coal mined from lands owned by the Reading Coal and Iron Company since Dec. 1 shall be set aside as a sinking fund, to be used either in the acquisition of additional lands or in liquidating coal land bonds and mortgages.

Janeway Co. of New-Brunswick, N.J., write to THE TIMES that the story that they have reduced the wages of their employes is absolutely false. Their orders are heavier than they were at this time last year, they declare, and they have not the slightest intention of making any reductions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27.--The actions of what is known as the "Philadelphia Syndicate," headed by Charles T. Yerkes, continue to attract considerable attention from the press and public. The latest sensation in connection with the syndicate is the publication of a private circular offering stock in the West Chicago Railway Company.

The young graduates of Dartmouth and the older ones who make it a point to become young again at least once every year on the evening when their Alumni Association has its annual dinner sat down last night at Delmonico's to talk over the past, enjoy the present, and prophecy as to the future.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 27.--The grandest and most attractive event of the carnival so far was the storming this evening of the ice palace by the Fire King and his force. His fiery majesty arrived in the city this morning and gathered his forces for the grand assault.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27.--A bold robbery that netted the thieves several thousand dollars was committed this morning in the jewelry store of Henry Yost, on Forty-seventh-street.

Twenty-six cattle on the farm of Benjamin Davis at Hicksville, Long Island, were found to be suffering from pleuro-pneumonia yesterday by Dr. Ryder, veterinary of the United States Bureau of Animal Industry, and were ordered to be killed. The cattle were appraised at $500, which will be paid to the owner out of the United States Treasury.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has affirmed the judgment of the court below giving William Ainley damages against the Manhattan Railway Company for the loss of his wife's society and services in consequence of the injuries she received by slipping on the icy steps of one of the company's stations.

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--Gloom pervaded the Executive Chamber to-day. Hill was mad over his failure to carry the Democratic State Committee yesterday.

When the moon rises at 5:10 this evening she will be in partial eclipse, with about threefifths of her lower side darkened. Forty-one minutes before the hour of her rising the earth will have begun to cast its shadow upon her.

Osgoodby of Buffalo was indicted with others for conspiracy to defraud, and for using the mails for the purpose of swindling country newspaper publishers and other people who could be beguiled with threadbare devices. Several hundred papers were victimized by the plausible schemes.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Jan.27.--The blizzard has been raging throughout the Schuylkill coal regions to-day. Trains were delayed from two to nine hours by the snowdrifts, and all the coal laterals are blocked so that even if mining had been going on actively it would have had to be suspended to-day.

PARIS, Jan. 27.--La France says that England and France have signed rules for the guidance of a mixed naval commission, which is to be appointed by the two Governments to settle the New-Hebrides question, and that, consequently, the French troops in the New-Hebrides will soon be withdrawn.

The subscription taken among members of the theatrical profession for the benefit of Mrs. Nellie Wetherell, amounting to $2,800, was sent to her lately in the shape of bank books showing deposits for that amount.

The publicity given by THE TIMES to the robbery committed at Goodyear's rubber store, 59 Maiden-lane, on Wednesday night during or after the fire in William-street, has started investigations which, probably, will place the responsibility for the repeated thefts of this kind which have been reported where it belongs.
The Hon. Robert C. Winthrop of Boston has just presented to the State Library the commission of his ancestor. John Winthrop, to be magistrate at Namecocke, New-London.
The six Judges of the City Court yesterday removed John Reid, who for four years has been Chief Clerk. He is a Tammany Democrat, and for 12 years has been connected with the court.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 27.--A frightful accident occurred this afternoon on the new cable line, which was opened for travel this week. A grip car and one passenger car attached were thrown from the track at the foot of a very steep hill on Selby-avenue and 15 persons were more or less injured.

Yesterday was most uncomfortable to the average New-Yorker. The sidewalks were covered with ice, which the high winds polished off to a slippery and dangerous promenading ground. As night advanced the cold increased.

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--It would seem as if the office holders in New-York City all want their salaries raised. A batch of measures for the benefit of these tax eaters was introduced in the Assembly to-day. Mr. Wissig had a bill to give the Park Commissioners salaries of $5,000 apiece.
William R. Pryor, a 14-year-old English lad, was landed at Castle Garden yesterday from the Red Star steamship Pennland under the name of J. Lloyd.
The Russian sculptor Opekueshin has just commenced a statue to form part of a monument to be erected in the Kremlin by the Czar to his father's memory. The complete cost is to be at least 120,000.

ATOKA, Indian Territory, Jan. 27.--The Choctaws are greatly exercised over their net proceed claim against the United States Government for property which had to be abandoned in Mississippi and Alabama when they were removed West.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27.--The steamer City of New-York from China and Japan entered the harbor this afternoon flying a yellow flag. Three cases of smallpox were found on board. The purser contracted the disease before the steamer started and was left at Hong-Kong. A lady cabin passenger died on the passage. The steamer has been placed in quarantine.

A double tenement house situated on the northeast corner of Tenth-avenue and Fiftyseventh-street was gutted by fire yesterday afternoon and 14 families were rendered homeless. Fortunately, the fire was not attended by loss of life, although there were many narrow escapes and a gallant rescue was made by a member of the Fire Department.

Rosalia Klein arrived here on Tuesday on the steamship Rugia, from Hamburg, and is now anxiously awaiting the arrival of her lover, Heinrich Neumann.

BOSTON, Jan. 27.--Harry Ross, the young son of A.F. Ross of Newburyport, met with a peculiar and probably fatal accident this morning. He was a passenger on the 8:10 train from Newburyport bound for Boston.

ALBANY, Jan. 27.--Miss Charline Weidman, the actress, died suddenly at her parents' residence here last night aged 35 years. She severed her connection with Arthur Rehan's company two weeks since because of financial differences.

JANESVILLE, Wis., Jan. 28.--The St. Paul through express collided with a detached engine of the Chicago accommodation of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway at that place yesterday morning, badly wrecking both engines and telescoping the St. Paul baggage car. MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 28.--A difficulty occurred at Duck Hill, Miss., a little town 40 miles south of here yesterday over a load of wood, during which W.H. Moody, who is the County Surveyor, shot and killed Benjamin Wesson, a Justice of the Peace. Moody surrendered to the authorities and is in jail.
