Two musical and dramatic entertainments will be given in the Lyceum Theatre on the afternoons of Thursday and Friday, Feb. 23 and 24, at 2:30 o'clock, the proceeds to be devoted to a worthy charity.

MADRID, Feb. 5.--A dispatch from Huelva states that yesterday a mob of Rio Tinto miners, now on strike, being ordered to disporse refused to do so and were fixed upon by troops. Several persons are reported to have been killed and five wounded.
Wolves have reappeared in Hungary. A Judge was returning in his sledge from Grosswardein to Cseb when a number of these animals attacked him.

An interesting spectacle was witnessed yesterday afternoon at the Church of San Salvatore, an Italian mission of the Protestant Episcopal Church, situated in Mulberry-street, near Bleecker, which was the gift of the late Miss Catherine Lorillard Wolfe to the Italians of this city. About 200 picturesque little boys and girls took an active part in the evening service, which was spoken and sung in Italian.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--Miss Maggie Ryan, a daughter of a clerk in the Quartermaster-General's office, walked down Pennsylvania-avenue Saturday with Martin Brennan, a young man who had been waiting on her for two years, and who supposed, though nothing had been definitely said on the subject, that he was her accepted suitor.
--The title of Mr. Lowell's collection of poems, now in the press of Houghton, Mifflin Co., is "Heartsease and Rue."

After long delay the people of Chicago are about to move against the gas monopoly which has been formed in their city, and their action will attract attention throughout the country because it is an attempt to break down a Trust by the enforcement of such laws as are to be found in the statute books of every State.
The running of the Fifth-avenue stages on Sunday, which promised to be an enterprise surrounded with many difficulties, has become an accomplished fact.

One of the features of the seven hundredth performance at the Casino will be the appearance of Frank Wilson in a brand-new costume. He will blossom out on this occasion in a most gorgeous baronial dress, which is calculated to astonish the audience as much as it will the old Princess.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 5.--Rain fell in torrents all along the Hudson Valley last night and early this morning, and to-day there was a general thaw which continues to-night. Great masses of snow have melted and still are melting, and serious freshets are looked for to-morrow unless a sudden and pronounced change of temperature intervenes.
Capt. John Douglas, commander of the Guion Line steamship Nevada, one of the most popular of the Atlantic liner Captains, died yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital.
CASSEL, Feb. 5.--Four persons were killed by an explosion in a gunpowder factory at Hanau to-day.
Bishop Potter yesterday paid his annual visit to the Seamen's Free Chapel, which floats in the East River at the foot of Pike-street, and confirmed 11 sailors and seven daughters of seamen.

The announcement comes from abroad that Miss Corbin, a niece of Austin Corbin, is engaged to be married to Robin Horace Walpole, a nephew of Drummond Wolf, and about 34 years old. Miss Corbin will by her marriage ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--Commissioner Colman has received an official request from the office of the Chief Secretary of Queensland to recommend to the Government of that colony a suitable person for employment as instructor in agriculture. The letis as follows:

President Thirkield is not altogether correct in his conception of the position of the colored people in the South. They have abundant opportunities in every walk of life. They can command the recognition they merit.

The Jewish Chronicle records the death at The Hague of one of the last of the Waterloo veterans. This was Chapman Enthoven, who wore the silver cross of the Netherlands for his services in the campaign of 1815.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5.--A new departure in the line of relic worship has been taken in this city. The preliminary steps for the formation of a corporation whose object is the purchase ...

The mystery surrounding the death of Michael Mallon, the bartender who died Friday evening at his home, 2,166 Eighth-avenue, from a fracture of the skull, seems to be growing deeper. Except with the police the impression is gaining favor that he was murdered.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 5.--It is reported on good authority that the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railway Company has decided to build a line from Jesup, Ga., to Jacksonville, Fla., giving it an independent line for through Florida business. The new line will be 110 miles long and will probably be completed by next Fall.

A locomotive has been sent by the King of the Belgians to Tangiers as a present to the Sultan of Morocco, a singularly inappropriate gift, considering that there is not a yard of railway or train line within his dominions.

A remarkable Alsatian has just passed away in the person of the Baron Albert von Dietrich, Strasburg, in his eighty-sixth year. He was descended from Dominic von Dietrich, who signed the treaty by which Strasburg was given to France in the time of Louis XIV.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 5.--In ordering a nolle entered yesterday in the case of Henry Pogue, a Director of the broken Fidelity Bank, under indictment in the United States court for certifying as correct a false bank statement, Judge Sage defined the law as to the criminal liability of Directors of a bank in which there has been a misapplication of funds.
BUFFALO, Feb. 5.--The bill that is now before the Legislature relative to the claim of those Cayuga Indians who reside in Canada is of the greatest interest.
Prince Napoleon has made another addition to the numerous relics of the First Emperor in purchasing a locket given by him to a Venetian beauty of high rank in 1809.

A very strong argument has been prepared by William J. Gibson to show that the internal revenue tax on tobacco should not be abolished by the Government, and has been printed in a convenient form for circulation.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 5.--Over a week ago F.C. Nickels of this city addressed a letter to Judge John McGill, Mayor of Jackson, Miss., asking what were the real facts about the recent troubles at the municipal election, which a Senate committee is to investigate.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5.--The professional labor men who are trying to keep the Democratic National Convention away from the new Auditorium Building, if it is held in Chicago at all, yesterday wrote two letters from which they expect great results.

ALBANY, Feb. 5.--Below are given abstracts from the official semi-annual reports of the NewYork City savings banks, except that of the Dry Dock returned for correction, showing their condition on Jan. 1, as reported to Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine, as required by law.

Peter Brannick, a policeman of the Nineteenth Precinct, who died on Saturday, was about to resign from the force, of which he had been a member since 1882, to enjoy a large fortune derived from an uncle --a "Forty-niner"--who recently died intestate in San Francisco.

One bitter afternoon during the recent cold snap a reporter of THE TIMES climbed to the sky parlor of the weather observer in the Equitable Building. Any one doubting the significance of the expression "climbed" had better try ascension by elevator of a Sunday afternoon.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 5.--The arrest yesterday of Constables Potts and Hamilton for receiving bribes in this city is the sensation to-day. Recently, under the decision of Judge Given, they and Constable Pierce seized the stocks of three wholesale liquor dealers.

LONDON, Feb. 5.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 1 to ; there was no demand. On the Stock Exchange business was inactive in every department throughout the week and prices dropped. Operators are in a state of suspense over the political outlook and are doing nothing. There is a general tendency to realize.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 6.--This morning Judge J.R. Morton of the Circuit Court of this county issued the following order:
The Leather Bag Manufacturers' Association of the Eastern and Middle States had its first annual dinner last evening at Delmonico's. Forty-two members and nearly a dozen invited guests sat down.

BERLIN, Feb. 6.--Prince Bismarck's speech in the Reichstag to-day was an event of unusual importance. Every seat in the House was occupied long before the Chancellor appeared. The entire diplomatic corps was present, and Prince William was in the box reserved for the imperial family.

The striking tenement-house cigarmakers belonging to Jacoby Bookman of East Thirtyeighth-street were excited yesterday at the positive orders they received from the firm that they must quit their dwellings by Thursday or they would be evicted.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6.--Interest continues in the tally-sheet trial now going on in the criminal court. Granville, the witness for the State, was put through a searching crossexamination by Mr. Converse, counsel for the defense, lasting from 11 o'clock this morning until after 4 this afternoon, the object of the defense being to bring before the jury the full life of Granville, which, it is generally conceded, ...
Rarely, if ever, has Chickering Hall contained at a public meeting a more respectable and intelligent assemblage of men and women than was gathered together last evening in favor of high license.
The auction sale of the second part of the Trivulzio Library was begun yesterday at the Leavitt Art Rooms, in Broadway, and will continue throughout the week.

ALBANY, Feb. 6.--The Assembly was in session exactly 12 minutes to-night. Then young Assemblyman Sheehan, simulating great trepidation, moved to adjourn, and 54 membars voted yea and 31 members, who had received no appointments and no promises of any, voted in the negative.
James B. Silkman died at the House of the Good Samaritan, Seventh-avenue and Thirtyseventh-street, on Saturday.
Shakespeare's comedy of "Measure for Measure," one of the works of the period in the poet's life that brought forth "Hamlet," was put on the New-York stage last night after many years of neglect.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 6.--The steamer Resolute, from New-York for New-Haven, with a large low, was disabled last night off Penfield Reef by blowing a hole in her boiler. She managed to make this port in safety, where the damage will be repaired.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 6.--The Folding Hat Rack Company assigned to-day to George W. Boyco. Liabilities, $15,000; assets, about the same. A preference of $9,105 was given to G.W. Hamilton.
What promises to be a case celebrated among insurance litigations was begun yesterday at noon before Justice Cullen and a jury in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.
The Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic last evening, at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory, elected John C. Limbeck Chairman by a vote of 87 to 75 for Coroner Levy.
At the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commission at the Mayor's office yesterday the award of the contract for building the Eighth Regiment Armory to Isaac A. Hopper for $248,290 was approved.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 6.--The contest over the will of Tamma Sutherland commenced in the Surrogate Court to-day, the contestants opening.
SAN REMO, Feb. 6.--The swelling in the lower part of the German Crown Prince's larynx has slightly increased, and interferes somewhat with his respiration when he exerts himself.

The Union League Club made its twentyfifth anniversary, which occurred last night, the occasion of a festival worthy in its magnificence of the proud position the clup occupies among the social organizations of the Union. Preparations for the event had been long under way.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Feb. 6.--A quarrel between two brothers, Calvin and Nathaniel Turner, aged 15 and 17 years, respectively, living at Port Murray, a hamlet a few miles from here, resulted in the death of Nathaniel yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 6.--Mrs. Harriet S. Durfee of Rockville has been elected President of the Connecticut Department of the Woman's Relief Corps, G.A.R.; Mrs. Mary E. Mathews of Bristol, ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--Mathias Busch, a saloon keeper, cut his wife's throat with a butcher's knife this afternoon, killing her instantly. The wife had been willed a small sum of money by a relative, and this Busch wanted her to turn over to him. She refused, and the couple had frequently quarreled about the matter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6.--News of a terrible shipwreck on the Washington Territory coast was received in San Francisco this morning. The wrecked vessel was the British iron bark Abercorn, which was on her way from Maryport, England, to Portland, Oregon.

The veteran volunteen firemen of Brooklyn overran the Academy of Music on Montague-street last night, on the occasion of their third annual ball. They had had the place decorated with flags of all nations and steamers of ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--Capt. Charles Porter, Eighth Infantry, now on leave of absence at Brooklyn, has been ordered to report by letter to the Superintendent of the Recruiting Service at NewYork to conduct recruits to the Department of the Platte. Orderly Sergt. James Whelan has been placed on the retired list.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 6.--To-morrow the interState convention of coal operators and miners will convene in Old City Hall, and probably remain in session for several days. The Scale Committee has not yet come to an agreement. A meeting was held this forenoon, but no conclusion was reached.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6.--The Metropolitan National Bank had another run upon it to-day and will not open its doors to-morrow. Its late Vice-President, John R. Decamp, was arrested late this afternoon, and one or two other arrests are expected.

The Directors of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company will meet to-morrow at the company's office on Sands-street and take the preliminary story toward the consolidation of their road with the new Union Elevated Road, whose structure ...

Few new features of consequence are to be discovered in the stock market. The demand for railway bonds by investors continues unabated, and every baning house that is related to any of the new issues of bonds has the same story to tell of a desire upon the public's part to put money into securities promising safety along with fair interest returns.

E. Whitney Hall, the Referee in the Emily Ruter case, has filed his report in which he finds that her brother, Diedrich Ruter, is not a fit person to have charge of her. Emily is about 18 years old, though she does not seem to be ...

Manager Abbey on Saturday last signed a contract with the father of young Hofmann, the wonderful boy pianist, by the terms of which the lad will give a series of 100 concerts under the management of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau next season.
There was an Executors' sale at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday of a piece of property with a remarkable history.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Feb. 6.--The Rev. Fathers Lenarkawicz and Wolamski, the Polish and Greek priests of Shenandoah, accomplished a victory to-night when legal proclamations and armed forces were powerless.

At a meeting of the creditors of George Keyes, Son Co., dealers in dry goods at 351 Eigthavenue, held yesterday at the Sturtevant House, the statement presented showed assets--Stock as inventoried at cost, $60,146 54; open accounts, ...

The third and last cotillion ball of the season took place last evening at Delmonico's. The special features of the evening were the introduction of both the Hungarian band and Lander's orchestra, and the use of lovely flowers for the favors. Only slight floral decoration besides the favers was furnished, Lee, formerly with Klunder, being the decorator.

BOSTON, Feb. 6.--Mrs. Sarah Jane Robinson of Somerville was to-day placed on trial for her life for the second time. She is charged with the murder of Prince Albert Freeman, her brotherin-law, who died in Cambridge June 29, 1885, as alleged, by poison.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 6.--C.F. Meert, a resident of Shrewsbury, was found dead to-day under circumstances which lead to the theory of suicide, Mr. Meert was for many years extensively engaged in the wine business in New-York City.

The encouragement of taste in the fine arts is a comparatively recent development in clubs, but when once begun at the Union League it has been carried forward with the energy its members put in other concerns, commercial or political.

A fire broke out at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the cellar of the two-story frame building 308 East Fifty-sixth-street, which was used as a stable by a number of milkmen and grocers in the neighborhood.

VIENNA, Feb. 6.--At the sitting of the Budget Committee to-day, the Minister of War declared than an increase of the staff of landwehr officers was an absolute necessity, and he would therefore ask an extra credit of $250,000 for that purpose.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 6.--In the trial of Tramp Deacons for the murder of Mrs. Stone in August last, the prosecution has already occupied four days in introducing testimony.

"Laura Dennis," the 18-year-old young woman who became ambitious for histrionic honors and came to this city in search of an engagement, left for her home in Chicago yesterday with Harry Ballard of the Chicago InterOcean, who is a friend of her family.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6.--W.H. Watkins of Detroit, H.B. Phillips of Pittsburg, and Harry Wright of Philadelphia, the National League Schedule Committee, dropped into Buffalo quietly Sunday night to avoid reporters. About the time they struck the town the reporters-struck them.

Old Patrick Trenor, the wealthy Veseystreet cordial manufacturer, who during the past few months received frequent mention in the newspapers by reason of legal proceedings to have him declared a lunatic died at noon Saturday in a flat at 162 East One Hundred and Fourth-street, where he went to live with old frends, E.P. Stover and family, when he began to decline physically last year.
The committee appointed by the House of Representatives to "investigate" the strikes in Pennsylvania will no doubt render such a report as they suppose will be pleasing to "Labor."

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 6.--On Saturday afternoon and night at the Boston Theatre Henry Irving played to larger audiences and bad larger receipts than were ever recorded for two dramatic performances in Boston.

At the Manhattan Life Insurance Company's office it was learned yesterday that the bungling forger, whose two bogus checks, bearing a clumsy imitation of President McLean's signature, were refused payment at the First National Bank of this city, is believed to be one of the company's agents at a small point in Massachusetts.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 6.--Joseph Medill, editor of the Chicago Tribune, has been in Jachsonville for some days past, and is occupying rooms at the Windsor Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6.--This afternoon a meeting of citizens was held in the Mayor's office at the City Hall to make final arrangements for the appointment of a delegation to appear before the National Democratic Committee, which meets in Washington on the 22d ...
The Trustees of Columbia College yesterday established a new department in the collegiate course for women, whereby they may obtain, after post-graduate study, the degrees ...

The Clearing House Association has joined the movement for the repeal of the half-holiday law, and has appointed as a committee, with power to represent their interests as may be required, E.H. Perkins, Jr., President of the Importers ...

The formation of the great proposed rubber trust is now a question of only a few days. The committee appointed to settle the differences between Christopher Meyer and the others, regarding New-Jersey manufactories, has effected a compromise and will propose ...
It is unquestionably true that a great deal of Wagner's music is unsingable; but that is not a sufficient reason why the singable parts should not be sung.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--A big reduction was made to-day in lumber rates by the Chicago and Alton to Kansas City and Southwestern Missouri River points from 13 cents to 10 cents a hundred.

David W. Judd, Quarantine Commissioner, died yesterday at the Rutland Flats of pneumonia, after an Illness of four days. He had been troubled a good deal with a cold during the Winter, but it did not keep him from business, to which he devoted himself almost through last week.

The Italo-Americano Carbonari Society is working secretly but actively to stop the Italian pauper immigration system. There are in this city, it is said, some 60,000 Italians, a very large number, If not most of whom, have been induced to come to this country by false representations.

The recent order of the Adjutant-General of the State Militia for a court-martial to try Capt. H.A. Ely of Company C, Ninth Regiment, on charges preferred by Major Miller of the Twenty-second Regiment, has caused a great deal of ill feeling among some members of those commands.

The exceptionally severe experience of New-Hampshire for the year 1887 in the matter of fire losses again directs attention to the State's attitude toward insurance companies and the results thus far of the experiment which was begun two years ago.

Fire Marshal Shelden, who was instrumental in discovering the girl incendiary at the Hospital for the Relief of the Ruptured and Crippled, has received a letter from the Chairman of the Board of Hospital Managers, O.B. Potter, thanking him for his promptness and ability, and expressing the hope that the little culprit might not be too severely punished for her misdeeds.

EUFAULA, Ala., Feb. 6.--The modesty of Manager Moore of the Western Union office in this city, who recieved the message of Gov. Gordon of Georgia respiting the condemned murderer Lewis Moore for 20 days from last Thursday, has kept a thrilling incident and the very narrow escape of the condemned out of print.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6.--The ChestnutStreet Opera House never held a larger audience than that gathered this evening to witness the McCaull Opera Company in a revival of "Falka," which had not been previously heard in this City for four years, at which time it ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--A decision was rendered by the United States Supreme Court to-day in the case of the United States against Douglas Smith, brought here upon a certificate of division of opinion between the Judges of the Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6.--One of Gov. David B. Hill's foolish friends, the Hon. Roswell P. Flower, has contributed largely to the Governor's great act of giving himself away.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6.--The fight between sugar retiners for the control of the coast trade was resumed this morning with increased vigor. Early in the day the directors of the California refinery held a council of warand it was resolved that another cut should be made on the yellow sugars in order to get the entire business.

The Rev. Dr. W.J. Simmons, a colored man, District Secretary for the Baptist Home Missionary Society, with the whole South for his territory, addressed yesterday morning the regular Monday meeting of the Baptist ministers of this city.
The popular fancy seems to have been ensnared by the six days' race in progress at Madison-Square Garden. Yet the race to by no means an ideal affair of its kind.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 668--Rowland Brill, respondent, vs. John Brill, appellant.--Argued by Homer A. Nelson for appellant. O.D.M. Baker for respondent. ...
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 6.--The snow on the ice in the Hudson is still quite deep. It will take a heavy rainstorm or a prolonged thaw and then freezing weather before any ice boating can occur.

LONDON, Feb. 6.--It is, of course, too early to guess what the effect of Prince Bismarck's speech will be abroad, either upon the Bourses or on those mightier circles, where it is settled whether peace or war shall reign.
ALBANY, Feb. 6.--Below are given the resources, deposits, and surplus reported to Bank Superintendent Paine by the Trust Companies of New-York City on Jan. 1.

At the Chickering Hall meeting last night expression was given to what seems to be a very general demand in this city for the enactment of a high license law for the restriction of the traffic in intoxicating liquors.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 6.--Mr. Judson Smith, Secretary of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, received this morning the following from the Famine Relief Committee at Constantinople:
Nineteen months ago Rollin M. Squire and Maurice B. Flynn were jointly indicted for conspiracy to defraud the city.
FISHKILL, N.Y., Feb. 6.--In Southern Dutchess many cases of diphtheria are reported. Three of the children of Theodore Hoyt have died in this village, and several others are not expected to live.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6.--Alvan Clark, maker of the lenses for the Lick Observatory, has completed his work on Mount Hamilton and will in a few days leave for his home. The lenses of the observatory are in working order, and the only remaining work is to adjust the apparatus.

William Rogers, the "green-goods" man who was arrested recently charged with having swindled County Commissioner Perkins of Lancaster County, S.C., out of $400 by selling him what purported to be $4,000 in "green goods," ...

There came very near being a riot in Meserolestreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday afternoon, when a Deputy Sheriff attempted to levy upon the property of Jacob Manz, who lives on the second floor of the tenement house at 57.
The Newark Amateur Opera Company produced last night at Library Hall, Newark, the "Pirates of Penzance" before all audience of over 700 people.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6.--A new rate schedule of the Pacific Mall Company, advancing freight rates to Panama. Central America, and Mexico 20 per cent, all around, will be issued to-morrow. Del Campo agents have not seen fit to take advantage of the advance, and the three steamers of the line, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Guatemala, now in port are laid up.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 6.--Intelligence of the arrest of Miles and John Terry was received today from Berryville. They are border outlaws, having killed a number of men, the last being John Meeks.

An informal reception was tendered yesterday afternoon by the members of the NewYork Press Club to M. Paul Blouet at the rooms of the club in Nassau-street. M. Blouet is better known as "Max O'Rell," the author of "John Bull and His Island."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--Mr. Riddleberger made another attempt to-day to discuss in open session the extradition treaty between the United States and Great Britain now pending in the star chamber sittings of the Senate.

HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 6.--The trial of Battice Jackson, colored, for the murder of Miss Gertrude M. Hover of Kinderhook, Columbia County, was begun here to-day in the Circuit Court, Justice Edwards presiding, and the work of securing a jury was tedious.
The German Chancellor put his foot down yesterday. Diplomacy left the Cabinet and entered the Forum. There it spoke with no ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 6.--In the United States District Court this morning the case of Mme. Janauschek against Henry Bull, proprietor of a Newport hotel, came up on a motion for a new trial. The case was tried here in December last, and the complainant was then awarded $12,000 damages for injuries received by a fall down stairs in defendant's hotel. The motion was made on the ground that the verdict was against the evidence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.--Little Josef Hofmann, the wonderful pianist, appeared this afternoon at Albaugh's Opera House. An immense audience was there to greet him, and their hearty and spontaneous appreciation seemed to spur the boy on to doing his best work.

Mr. Richard Mansfield tried popular prices on the west side for the first time last night, and with the most gratifying success. The Grand Opera House was crowded as it had never been before except on extraordinary occasions, and "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" was received with a favor bordering upon enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--A meeting of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois stockholders has been called for Thursday of this week to act upon an issue of stock to be used in the consolidation with the Chicago and Indiana Coal Railroad, the exchange to be made share for share.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7.--Drafts-Sight, 12 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents.

ALBANY, Feb. 7.--The Larchmont Horse Railroad Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $25,000 to operate a railroad of one and onequarter miles, from the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company's tracks to Larchmont Manor, in Westchester County. The Trustees are Charles H. Murray, Jersey City; Thomas H. French, Helen Flint, New-York; Edward E. Flint, Chicago; William H. Campbell, William Murray, Larchmont, and Julia W. Southback, Larchmont Manor.

MADRID, Feb. 7.--Senor Castelar created a sensation in Congress to-day by declaring that when the monarchy implants democratic reforms all republicans must serve it. Senor Castelar made a long speech.
The propriety of the taxation of personal property was discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange.

A fire started in the third story of 46 Vesey-street yesterday afternoon, in the factory of the Inventors' Manufacturing Company. This company manufactures articles needing varnish in their preparation for the market, and it was some of the varnish or the turpentine or benzine used by the company which caused yesterday's fire.
The second Brooklyn Cotillion was given last evening at the Remsen Rooms. After supper and the german the cotillion was led off at 1 o'clock by A. Melvine Snedeker and J.S. Meserole.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7.--The Senate in executive session to-day confirmed all the nominations in hand, as follows: John Clement of Camden, Lay Judge of the Court of Errors; Charles H. Winfield, ...

NYACK, Feb. 7.--Mrs. Charity Smith, wife of Tunis Smith, of this place, died at noon to-day of pleuro-pneumonia after a brief illness. No woman in Rockland County was better known or more highly esteemed than Mrs. Smith.

LONDON, Feb. 7.--Mr. Gladstone greatly enjoyed his visit to Cannes. The weather there has been almost Summerlike. On Sunday he gave a dinner party, at which were present the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess of Baden, Prince Leopold of Hohenzollern, Prince Radziwill, and Prince

George H. Forster, President of the Board of Aldermen, received from the board yesterday, through Alderman Storm, a handsomelycarved ivory gavel, the head of which was encircled with a broad gold band bearing the ....

Annie Basanke, who arrived at Castle Garden a week ago and went at once to an employment agency at 29 Washington-street, from which she was taken on Friday last by a man who said he wanted a servant, appeared in Justice Massey's court, Brooklyn, yesterday to prosecute this man for attempting to abduct her.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.--Henry E. Reese, chief bookkeeper and cashier of the Continental Hotel, was arraigned before Magistrate Durnam this afternoon charged with embezzlement. The warrant on which Reese was arrested was sworn out by Herbert S. Brown, a member of the firm of J.E. Kingsley Co., proprietors of the hotel.
Sidney J. Cowen, who qualified on Saturday as temporary Administrator of the Bergamini estate, has made some interesting discoveries in relation to the affairs of the dead Italian banker.
ALBANY, Feb. 7.--From reports of railroads for the quarter ended Dec. 31 the following figures are abstracted:

LONDON, Feb. 7.--The steamship Hans Kurt, (Ger.,) Capt. Glavecke, from Bremen for NewYork, has arrived at Rotterdam with her port bow stove, having received this damage in a collision with an unknown vessel.

Thomas Donnelly of 99 Nassau-street is a member of the Liederkranz Society. Each of the members of that society is entitled to a ticket, worth $10, to the annual ball, which takes place Thursday night. In the Court of Special Sessions yesterday ...

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 7.--News was received at Newberne to-day to the effect that the Clyde Line steamer Margie, plying between Newberne and points in Hyde County, has been burned to the water's edge at Bay borough, N.C. Loss, $5,500; insurance, $4,000.

COLUMBUS, S.C., Feb. 7.--Farmer Asbury Hamilton Perkins, County Commissioner of Lancaster County, who recently lost $400 in a "greengoods" transaction in New-York City, has returned to his home in Lancaster a sadder but a wiser man. Public sentiment in his neighborhood is so strong against Perkins that he has been compelled to resign his office, and his resignation was accepted by Gov. Richardson to-day.

F. Grote Co. manufacturers of ivory goods at 114 East Fourteenth-street, have confessed judgment for $46,942 in favor of William Steinway for money lent, and given him a chattel mortgage as security for notes.
BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 7.--The annual meeting of the West End Street Railroad Company, which controls the entire horse-car system in and around Boston, was held to-day.

LEWISBURG, Penn., Feb. 7.--A north-bound freight train on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad while moving slowly near here this morning was overtaken by another freight, the engine of which plowed through the caboose and two cars of the first train.
ALBANY, Feb. 7.--The following reports for the quarter ending Dec. 31 have been filed:

The Episcopal Mission, which is situated on Stanton street, a little east of Ludlow, is one of those institutions which is doing much valuable work among the east side poor under the energetic superintendence of Elias J. Herrick.

At his benefit performance in the Thalia Theatre last evening. Herr Possart appeared as the wicked Duke of Gloster, in Shakespeare's "Kind Richard III." The house was crowded, and even the space usually reserved for the orchestra was filled in with seats for auditors.

KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 7.--A special from Havana, Cuba, says that the editor of El Pueblo Soberano, a daily paper published in that city, has been arrested and lodged in jail for circulating some copies of his paper throughout the city after it had been suppressed by order of the Judge of Monserrate, a district of Havana.
WELLS, Minn., Feb. 7.--Last Wednesday there was born to Mrs. Fred Miller at Rice Lake a speck of humanity that barely tipped the beam at 1 pounds.
The General Term of the Superior Court has reversed the judgment entered on the report of a Referee in favor of Elmore A. Kent and others in their suit against Jesse C. Woodhull.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 7.--For two long days Granville has stood a searching cross-examination by counsel for the defense without so much as a break from the testimony given in chief during last week.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 7.--The taxpayers and all of those interested in the financial affairs of this debt-ridden city are in a great state of excitement over an amendment to the Martin act, which has just been introduced in the Senate by Senator Edwards of Hudson.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 7.--The troubles which have beset the South Pennsylvania Road have been settled, and the lack of harmony which enabled the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to interfere in the building of the road and to almost strangle it has come to an end.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association, in its rooms, in Temple Court, yesterday afternoon, resolutions were adopted to the memory of David W. Judd, the publisher, who died suddenly on Monday.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 7.--A bill, the passage of which by the Legislature was secured by a committee of citizens to-day, abolishes the Sewerage Commission, a body of high-paid officials, and gives all their powers to the Common Council.

The Legislative Committee of the Board of Education, consisting of Commissioners Sprague, Guggenheimer, Gallaway, Devoe, Webb, and the President of the board, J. Edward Simmons, will take the 9 o'clock limited express to-day for Albany.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 7.--Chief of State Police E.F. Curtis, in his first annual report to the Legislature, makes a poorer showing for the working of prohibition than during the first year of the trial of the law.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 7.--In Fair Haven to-day a hall just finished by order of Henry H. Rogers of New-York in the schoolhouse which he presented to his native town three years ago was dedicated.
ALBANY, Feb. 7.--The panicky feeling professed by some members of the Assembly, and genuinely entertained by some others, has not yet abated.

VIENNA, Feb. 7.--The Boerse was favorably affected by Prince Bismarck's speech. Austrian securities were strong at a rise of per cent., Lembergs advanced 5 florins, Anglo-Austrian Bank 2 florins, Credit Anstalt 3 florins, and Lombards 1 florin.

Patrick Powers, aged 22 years, of 398 Van Brunt-street, Brooklyn, was discovered stealing some rope on the vessel Black Hawk, lying at the foot of Richards-street yesterday afternoon, whereupon he jumped overboard and was drowned. His body was not recovered.

Mayor Hewitt's last message has received another indorsement. A meeting for that purpose was held at the New-York Cotton Exchange yesterday afternoon, which was attended by about 150 members and down-town business men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--The President has sustained the action of the Secretary of War in issuing the order limiting details of aides-de-camp to four years. There was considerable opposition to the order on the part of general officers of the army, and each of them applied to have exceptions made in particular cases.

Wagner at the lodging house at 256 East Fifty-first-street, and said that the proprietor, William Archibald, wanted a permit to ...

BOSTON, Feb. 7.--A cablegram received to-day from the European Union of Astronomers announces the discovery of an asteroid (No. 272) by Prof. Charles at Nice. The last observed position was: February, 4 days 6 hours 24 minutes, Washington mean time; right ascension, 10 degrees 1 minute 10 seconds; declination, north, 19 20' 22''. Its daily motion is 13 minutes in right ascension and south 5 minutes in declination.
The Baptist Home Society celebrated its nineteenth annual meeting last night by throwing open the new chapel in the Old Ladies' Home, in Sixty-eighth-street, near Lexingtonavenue.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 7.--The crowd seeking admittance to the court room where the Deacons murder trial is in progress was greater than ever this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.--At the annual meeting of the Huntingdon and Broad Top Mountain Railroad Company to-day it was stated that after a lapse of three years the company resumed the payment of dividends last July.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--The efforts of the Hon. Roswell Pettibone Flower to plant a tender Hill boom in the unfavorable soil of Chicago have been the subject of considerable comment here to-day, and the little handful of malcontents who love the ways of the wily David have been guyed unmercifully.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--Mrs. Cora White, a colored woman, has sued the proprietor of the Hotel Grace, on Clark-street, for $10,000 damages. She called at the hotel a few weeks ago to see a friend.

ALBANY, Feb. 7.--As the commerce of the State increases the lands under water adjacent to the shores of navigable streams and about islands in commercial centres are more sought after. Grants to these can be acquired by individuals only by an act of the Legislature or by a resolution of the Commissioners of the Land Office.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 7.--John Benson, whose gambling house was raided in December last, pleaded guilty to-day and was fined $1,000 and costs in each of two cases for writing lottery policies or one year in jail, $100 for running a poker table, and $50 for selling liquor without a license.

The second day of the celebratad Tyler insurance suit, on trial before Judge Cullen and a jury in the Brooklyn Supreme Court, was a busy one for the legal talent engaged and interesting for the spectators.

The proceeds of the first day's sale of the Trivulzio collection were $6,600. Yesterday's sale footed up $1,100, giving a total of $7,700 for the two days. Denon's etchings in two volumes broke the monotony of low prices by bringing $25 per volume.

The committee of Supervising Inspectors who are to investigate the doings of Messrs. Fairchild and Marsland, Local Inspectors of Steamboats at this port, began its work yesterday. George W. Deese, who represented the Brotherhood of Steamboat Pilots, conducted the examination for the complainants.

John William Kitson, who died on Monday of spinal trouble, was a member of the firm of Ellin, Kitson Co., architectural sculptors. He was born in Huntersfield, England, in 1846, and when a boy went to the London house of Farmer Brinley, stone carvers and modelers.

The New-Jersey State Board of Education does not get along very well with the Passaic County Board of Chosen Freehelders. The former board has the appointment of County School Superintendents and the county boards have the power to confirm or reject the appointments.

BOSTON, Feb. 7.--The evidence presented to-day at the trial of Mrs. Sarah J. Robinson, who is charged with poisoning her whole family, was entirely of a circumstantial character, but before the day closed Mrs. Robinson was evidently worried.

ALBANY, Feb. 7.--Gov. Hill gave his first ladies' reception in the Executive Mansion this evening from 9 until 11 o'clock. A heavy snowstorm prevailed. His military staff acted as ushers, and dancing was kept up until midnight. A lunch was served during the evening. The affair was strictly social, as the bachelor Governor put it, and it was given in honor of ladies who had entertained him and personal friends.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 7.--An old commission has been presented to Surrogate O.P. Carpenter here by Elmer Wilklow of Kopplebush, Ulster County.

Mr. Sidney Woollett recited a large part of "The Merchant of Venice" before a numerous and attentive audience at the MadisonSquare Theatre Monday afternoon.
PLATTSBURG, Mo., Feb. 7.--An awful tragedy occurred two miles northwest of this city to-day. Neva Everett, a pretty girl of 16, was one of the belles of the neighborhood.

Wall-street busied itself yesterday with discussions of sensational tales suggesting a marked change in base by the Commercial Cable Company, practically amounting to a surrender to the Gould cable companies.

Ernst Possart, the German actor, whose benefit at the Thalia Theatre last night attracted a great house, received a cablegram Monday announcing that Geissler who was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder at Breslau in February, 1361, had been pardoned and freed that afternoon.

The Carsey-Keogh Executive Committee of the Anti-Monopoly League, that sometimes consists of six and at other times of three members, according to the exigencies of the times, met last evening at 116 West Twenty-thirdstreet.
BRIDGEPORT Feb. 7.--A very pretty parlor wedding occurred at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Davenport this evening at 297 Washington-avenue.

The body of Romaine Dillon, the eccentric recluse, who died alone in his apartments at the Union-Square Hotel last Saturday, has been removed to the home of his niece, Mrs. B.B. Baldwin, 1 East Thirtieth-street. It is eight years ago since Dillon was released from the Utica Asylum for the Criminal Insane.

Judge Dugro of the Superior Court has refused an application made by a corporation calling itself the New-York Underground Railway Company for a mandamus to permit them to break ground in Lafayette-place.

Richard K. Fox, the proprietor of the Police Gazette, was arrested yesterday by Inspector Willliams, charged with aiding a prize fight in allowing one to be arranged at his office recently between Patrick Farley of Brooklyn and Tom Dores of Yonkers.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7.--Josef Hofmann had one of the largest houses of the season at the Academy of Music this afternoon. The enthusiasm was unbounded, and the little fellow was given a most unusual greeting. To a newspaper man who talked with him this morning he did not express any great love for Mayor Howitt. "I like New-York," he said, "but I don't like the City Hall."

Patrick Trenor's will was filed for probate yesterday by Fullerton Rushmore. It was executed on Nov. 24, 1887, and is witnessed by Henry C. and Hanna Meyer of 1,641 Lexingtonavenue.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 7.--The Erie Railroad officials have issued supplementary instructions modifying the order that was to have gone into effect on the 12th inst., and which required each conductor and locomotive engineer on the line to provide himself with a "reliable" watch, which should not vary from standard time more than 30 seconds in a month.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7.--A meeting of the local east-bound committee was held to-day, at which it was agreed to advance the dressed meats rate to Boston via all Central Traffic Association lines 3 cents a hundred.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 7.--A serious stabbing affray is reported from Tuxedo Park. Charles McPeek, the proprietor of a saloon outside the limits, had an altercation with one Eagan on Sunday, leading to blows. Finally McPeek shot and stabbed Eagan. The injured man was taken to a Jersey City hospital, where, it is said, he cannot live. McPeek fled.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 7.--Six young children, ranging in age from 5 to 16 years, are left motherless, and perhaps fatherless, by a tragedy which occurred at 347 Smallman-street this morning at 6:30 o'clock.
Policeman Richard McCarty, attached to the Eighteenth Precinct, Brooklyn, has got in a peek of trouble for having clubbed a prisoner.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7.--The Captain and crew of the ship Standard, bound for San Francisco, and now lying at the old navy yard, have been quenching their thirst with foul water and are now all seriously ill.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 7.--For the past week or more grave fears have been entertained for D.R. Locke ("Nasby") of the Blade of this city, who has been ill for two months, but within the past 24 hours his symptoms have taken a more favorable turn, and he is out of danger for the present. The alarming reports sent out that he is dying are utterly without foundation.

R.D. Warburg Co., of Nottingham, England, have obtained an attachment against Margaret S.C. Jones in a suit to recover $10,004 20 for goods sold. Mrs. Jones was a special partner in the firm of Francis J.C. Ferris Co., importers of notions, laces, and fancy goods, at 273 Church-street, this city.

The steamship City of Truro, from Mediterranean ports, came in through Long Island Sound on Monday night. At 9 P.M., when off Little Gull, she ran down the schooner William M. McKay, which sailed from New-York for St. John last Saturday.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Feb. 7.--For the past two weeks John L. Lee hae been relegated to that obscurity which so many people think he should never have emerged from. John L. Lee is the Chairman of the committee sent here recently to receive aid for the Lehigh strikers.

A dispatch from Plainfield, N.J., published in one of the evening papers yesterday, stated on the authority of an unnamed prominent gentleman of this city that the heirs of John Roach were about to bring suit against the United States Government for $2,500,000 damages for its refusal to accept the ships which he built for it.

CINCINNANI, Ohio, Feb. 7.--The closing of the doors of the Metropolitan Bank to-day had but little effect on business in this city. It was noticed that the stronger banks gained by it, and the weak banks lost some depositors.

Services were held yesterday morning on board the Guion steamship Nevada over the body of Capt. John Douglas, who pluckily brought the ship through a hard voyage on her last trip from Liverpool when he was in the last stages of abdominal cancer, not leaving his post of active duty until she came into port last Wednesday. Then he took to his bed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--Quite a breeze has been stirred by the discussion provoked in the House yesterday by Mr. White over the alleged use by him of a private telegraph wire to Wallstreet.
"Siegfried" will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening.

A pigeon-shooting match took place yesterday afternoon on the Carteret Gun Club's range down at Bergen Point--a shooting match that attracted halt of Wall-street as spectators, tempted reckless brokers into big bets, and generally stirred up the Stock Exchange sporting blood to rare liveliness.
The Orange Athletic Club will give a ball Friday evening, Feb. 10, at their clubhouse in Orange. The spacious tennis building will be used for dancing, and supper will be served in the billiard room.

As the Third-avenue elevated railway train which left Harlem at 10:25 o'clock was approaching the Forty-second-street station yesterday morning a well-dressed, elderly man was seen to pass down the steps at the northern end of the platform and walk toward the switch house, about 20 feet distant.

The protests from the South against the enactment of a Federal law to regulate the sale of adulterated lard are in themselves sufficient proof that enormous quantities of cottonseed oil are used by certain manufacturers in making lard.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 7.--The railroads were partially blocked with snow again yesterday, and wheat receipts for a few days will be lessened both here and at country points.

A walking match without music is about as inspiriting as a funeral without a hearse. So thought the people who walked into MadisonSquare Garden yesterday morning, and yesterday afternoon, too, for that matter. The Garden was enveloped in a sort of quiet that is seldom to be found outside of cemeteries.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 7.--The Hon. Witter J. Baxter, one of the most prominent citizens in Southern Michigan, died very suddenly last night at his home in Jonesville. He was attending to his business as usual during the day, retired at 8 o'clock and was found dead in bed an hour later.

The second grand exhibition of orchids ever held in this country will begin at the Eden Mus e Feb. 16, and will continue for one week. Extensive preparations have been made to make the show a most complete and representative affair.

The Old Fifth-Street School Association held its fifth annual dinner at Clark's in Twentythird-street, last night, to commemorate the fiftieth year since the opening of the school.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 9.--Clement Arthur Day was hanged at the jail in this city this forenoon. He was 41 years old. His crime was the murder of Johanna Rosa Cross, aged 22, on the Black River Canal, near Boonville, on June 9, 1887. Day and the murdered woman had lived together, and having quarreled he stabbed her to death. He was convicted on the evidence of his own father, who had witnessed the crime.

IGNACE, Mich., Feb. 9.--A serious snow blockade occurred on the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic Railway yesterday, and the express, accommodation, and some freight trains are still stuck fast west of Seney. The thermometer registered 20 below at Alpena this morning, the coldest of the Winter. At Ishpeming it was 35 below, Marquette 26 , and Mackinaw City 22 below.

BOSTON, Feb. 9.--The surprise at the Robinson murder trial to-day was the introduction of Dr. Biers as a witness by the Government. His evidence, however, was confined to his relations with Mrs. Robinson. Nothing was elecited of special importance. Mrs. Robinson continued her testimony, and after a few witnesses were examined in rebuttal Lawyer Goodrich began his argument for the defense, which was not concluded at adjournment.
Bugene Beoudoin, the little stowaway who was found on Jan. 5 on the Red Star steamship Noordland, will be sent back to his home.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 9.--It was after 3 o'clock this afternoon when the Inter-State Convention of Coal Miners and Operators got down to business.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 9.--Twice within 10 days negroes have been lynched in the parish of Tangipahoa for an attempted assault on white women.

For some days Elijah John Morrison, the Monmouth County (N.J.) hermit, has not been seen. He is supposed to have wandered away from his hut in the forest of pines and poplars here and perished. He is without relatives, but his will is said to be in favor of two widow ladies of his neighborhood. He is said to be worth nearly $100,000, without including some unimproved property in Harlem, New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9.--The long-standing strike among the upholstery weavers of Kensington was ended to-day, when the strikers in meeting assembled decided to yield and accept the terms of the manufacturers. OTTAWA, Ill., Feb. 9.--The jury this morning in the Circuit Court returned a verdict of guilty and imprisonment for life against George Bolzer, who murdered his cousin Nicholas Haul, at Streator, on July 15 last. On a former trial the jury recommended that the defendant be hanged.

ALBANY, Feb. 9.--The gorgeous Executive Mansion in which Gov. Hill lives a bachelor life is the cause of a scandal, beside which the patch upon Gov. Marcy's trousers that the State had to pay for sinks into utter insignificance.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 9.--The Pennsylvania lines west of Pittsburg have effected an arrangement by which the regular allowance of baggage will be checked through from any of their stations to points on the Pacific coast. This will be appreciated as a convenience by passengers to California, Oregon, c., as heretofore it has been necessary for them to recheck baggage from the Missouri River.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10.--Many underwriters in this city have given up the British bark Glenavon as lost. She sailed from Astoria, Oregon, Aug. 27 for Liverpool, and was spoken Oct. 28 off the Falkland Islands by the ship Scottish Wizard. Three days later the Wizard barely escaped being wrecked in a terrible storm, and the bark is supposed to have gone down.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 10.--Two men were digging up some dynamite which had been buried to protect it until wanted to use a gas well near Bellvue, Ohio, to-day, when one of them struck the explosive material with his pick. The explosion instantly killed the two men, and caused such a shock as to suggest an earthquake at Tiffin, Sandusky, Put-inBay, and other points in that locality.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 10.--Charles Barker of Barnwell County attempted to shoot a mad dog to day, but the cap failed to explode. He then clubbed the gun and struck the rabid animal with the breech. The concussion discharged the gun and the load entered Barker's side, killing him instantly.

CLONTARF, Minn., Feb. 10.--The regular Manitoba passenger train going north was wrecked here yesterday through a broken flange on an engine wheel. As the cold was intense, the mercury being 40 below, the wrecked passengers suffered severely.

ALBANY, Feb. 10.--A committee of city and town school Superintendents met with State Superintendent of Public Instruction Draper to-day to advise with him as to more perfect legislation for compelling the attendance of children at school. It was finally decided late in the afternoon that each gentleman present should draft a bill proposing the needful remedy to the present compulsory education law and present it at a subsequent meeting to be held next Saturday.

ASHLAND, Wis., Feb. 11.--Under a treaty of 1842 and another of 1865 with the Government the various bands of Chippewa Indians, now represented by a few semi-civilized fullbloods and a large number of half-breeds, were to receive a large sum of money for certain lands over which they roamed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11.--The public building appropriations promise to be enormous before the Fiftieth Congress closes its first session. There are bills now before the House and the Senate that call for the expenditure of about $30,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11.--A movement is on foot here to establish a home for disabled Confederate soldiers. A bill has been introduced in the Legislature to grant for this purpose the arsenal at Pikesville. This arsenal was established by the United States in 1819. A few years ago it was given to Maryland by the National Government.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 11.--The Jersey Central Railroad Company has lost large quantities of coal this Winter through thieves, who have plied their vocation at night while the long coal trains have been switched off on a siding extending along the meadows near the Elizabeth River. So bold and serious have these robberies become that several detectives were put on the case.

The Twenty-second Regiment and the Spartan Harriers united last evening in athletic games, which were held at the regiment's armory in Fourteenth-street. The attendance was good and the games the same, although, on account of the hurry to reach the dancing, they were trade rather short. The floor was clear and all ready for the dance by 10 o'clock.

James Albert at 10 o'clock last evening was proclaimed the champion of the world's goas-you-please pedestrians. He broke Fitzgerald'a unprecedented record with comparative ease, and terminated a 140-hour run, resting during the week only 19 hours, 21 minutes, and 50 seconds, with the great score of 621 miles and 1,320 yards.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11.--At a meeting of the Local Finance Committee to-day the Chairman said that $23,000 had been subscribed by Chicago citizens to defray the expenses of the Democratic National Convention, provided it comes to Chicago, and the sum will be incrceased to $50,000 if necessary. The working committees decided to go to Washington next Saturday.

LEWES, Del., Feb. 11.--The barkentine Mascotte, from Pernambuco for Delaware Breakwater for orders with 800 tons of sugar, is ashore near North Rehoboth Life-Saving Station. The crew is safe. The vessel is full of water and listed off shore. Sea is breaking over her decks. Lewee wreckers have contracted to float her.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 11.--Seven negroes and six whites, convicted of petty larcenies, were whipped with from five to ten lashes each at NewCastle this morning. About 200 spectators were present. Some of the victims took their punishment without flinching, but two of them squirmed constantly. One of the negroes, on receiving his tenth lash, asked the Sheriff for a chew of tobacco. Samuel Long, (white,) convicted of check forgery, stood one hour in the pillory.

A telegram received by J.A. Van Brunt of 75 South-street yesterday from Richmond, Va., stated that, for the first time in the history of that State, the Legislative Committee had reported favorably the abolishing of compulsory pilotage on coastwise vessels. Friends of the bill anticipated a hard fight, but were hopeful of carrying it.

The death is announced of that most amusing of French dramatic authors, M. Eugene Labiche of the French Academy, but better known as Labiche of the Palais Royal Theatre. He expired at l2:30 this morning, after a long and painful illness.

The promised activity in the real estate market has met all expectations within the past week. Inquiry among those in the business has found every one busy in making actual sales or preparing for a brisk season which has already almost arrived.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 12.--Mr. Hubert F.H. Jerningham, Colonial Secretary of British Honduras, who is stopping at the Hotel Royal, arrived at New-Orleans on Saturday on board the steamship City of Dallas, and comes partly to enjoy the festivities of the Mardi-Gras season and partly on official business relating to his colony.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 12.--The Thirteenth Separate Company, Fenton Guards, N.G.S.N.Y., is sharing in the general advancement of the State militia. Not only are its ranks full but new applications await action.

A very clever musical comedy entitled "Der Tolle Wenzel," otherwise "The Mad Wenzel," was performed for the first time in this country at the Thalia Theatre Saturday evening. The literary portion of the play is the work of Herr W. Manstaedt and the musical selections show the mechanical skill of Herr G. Steffens.

The joint resolution passed by the Senate for the celebration of what it somewhat indefinitely calls "the Centennial of the Constitution" practically provides that this celebration shall be held in Washington, but does not commit the country to the method of commemoration at first suggested, that of laying the foundations of a World's Fair to be established in that city.

LONDON, Feb. 12.--Thousands of persons gathered in Trafalgar-square this afternoon to attend a meeting announced to be held there. The meeting was adjourned, however, to the Thames Embankment, where several speeches were made. There was no disorder and the police did not interfere.

The Rev. Dr. Talmage preached upon "Wifely Ambition" in his series of sermons to women yesterday in the Brooklyn Tabernacle. "I am most anxious that woman," he said, "not waiting for the rights denied her, promptly and decisively employ the rights she already has in her possession.
The Funeral of the Rev. A.E. Goodnough, who was Pastor of the Church of Our Saviour in Pierrepont-street, Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the church.
PHILIPPOPOLIS, Feb. 12.--It is rumored that an order to mobilize the Bulgarian Army is about to be issued.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 12.--G.B. Abbott of Chicago, National Commander of the Sons of Veterans, is making an official tour of the camps in this State. On Wednesday evening he will institute a new camp at Norwalk, with a charter membership of 40, each member being son of a veteran connected with Buckingham Post in that city. Commander Abbott has received marked attention during his official visit.

LONGVIEW, Texas, Feb. 12.--The most brutal crime ever committed in Texas was reported here to-day by Sheriff Forsyth of Panola County. On Friday afternoon the office of Treasurer Hill of Panola County was entered by a gang of burglars, who killed the Treasurer and cut off his head.

It was reported yesterday that eight shoemakers' local assemblies in Cincinnati had voted to withdraw from District Assembly No. 48 and to join National Assembly District No. 216 of shoemakers that has been recently organized.

Mr. Crowley of Central Park is himself again. His appetite has returned, and with it strength will come in due time. He still wears the languid air of an invalid, but it becomes him well, and now that all danger is past all his loyal and admiring little subjects are smiling and happy.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 12.--The congregation of the Centre Church of this city, the oldest parish in this part of the State, after listening to an eloquent appeal from the Pastor, Dr. Newman Smythe, to-day subscribed $25,000 to wipe out the debt of the church. Members of the firm of E.H. Trowbridge's Sons subscribed over one-half the amount.

LONDON, Feb. 12.--Discount was easy during the past week at 1 to . Business on the Stock Exchange was extremely inactive. Foreign securities soon lost the advance resulting from Prince Bismarck's speech. Speculation in English railway securities has ceased; operators for a rise closing their accounts assisted in causing a decline.
James Bradly fell down the elevator shaft at the Titus Bakery, Newark, yesterday, and died almost immediately. He was 38 years old. He leaves a widow and one child. He was formerly a cowboy.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 12.--It appears from a search of the county records that about 1,800 divorces have been granted in Hennepin County since 1853. In 1886 there were 107 divorces, the largest number granted in any one year.

Lent begins this week with Ash Wednesday. Each of the Catholic churches will hold two extra night services each week during lent. At one a sermon will be preached and the other will consist of the devotion known as the "way of the cross."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 12.--The "Soo" line is branching out in a new direction. Arrangments have been perfected between it and the Lehigh Valley Road whereby the latter's coal shipments to the West are to be sent directly to the " Soo" docks at Gladstone, and flour taken thence to the coast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The Rev. Dr. Van Dyke of the Brick Church, New-York, preached to a large audience to-night in the New-York-Avenue Presbyterian Church, upon "The National Sin of Literary Piracy," his sermon being a review of the international copyright question in its moral aspects. Although the weather was stormy Mrs. Cleveland was present, and there was in the audience a fair representation of Congress.

Since its performance by the late John T. Raymond and his company, in Harlem, Mr. David D. Lloyd's amusing play, "The Woman Hater," has been rewritten. The second and third acts have been compressed into one and the movement made brisker.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 12.--At Vincennes last night Larry McCaffrey was shot and killed by George Hartmann. The men quarreled over dice. McCaffrey insulted Hartmann and drew a knife when the latter fired three shots, instantly killing McCaffrey. Hartmann fled, and has not yet been arrested.

BUFFALO, Feb. 12.--Buffalo is bothered with two toll roads within its corporate limits, and residents of the southern part of the city have been trying for two years to secure their abolishment. They assert that the toll gates greatly hinder the growth of the city in that direction, for manufacturers refuse to settle in a section where tolls are required.

Belinda, the noble Newfoundland dog familiar in the past to the frequenters of Central Park, died last Friday, after a short illness, of gastric fever. She was owned by Miss Hubbell and was either a friend or bowing acquaintance to every little child whom she saw in the park.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12.--C.E. Hamilton, Ex-Attorney-General of Manitoba, according to a resident of Winnipeg, denies that he is a resident of the United States. Strenuous efforts are being made in Manitoba to keep the fact that he has changed his allegiance a secret.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 12.--The Opera House was crowded this evening at a meeting held in support of home rule in Ireland. Mayor Bulkley presided. Speeches were made by Mr. John Stuart, ...

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Feb. 12.--The steamer Island Home struck a cake of ice this morning while making the package from Nantucket to Woods Holl, causing her to leak badly. She returned to Nantucket and was beached. The steamer Monohansett left Edgartown this afternoon to assist her.

Since the sudden death of Romaine Dillon at the Union-Square Hotel on Feb. 4, a diligent but vain search has been made for his will. So far as known them are but two heirs, a niece, Mrs. Baldwin of this city, and a nephew, Frank Nesmith of Philadelphia.
MARISSA, Ill., Feb. 12.--G.W. Guthrie, a wealthy farmer living two miles north of this place, was shot to death at 11 o'clock this morning while attempting to resist a desperate burglar.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12.--The principal feature of the freight war yesterday was another out by the Soo line in order to maintain the differential of 10 cents first class from the Eastern seaboard.

The Congressional committee which is investigating the Philadelphia and Reading Company's strike will not examine Austin Corbin as a witness to-day. It stated, just before adjournment on Saturday that it so intended to do. Mr. Corbin is confined to his house in this city with a severe cold, and sent word to a TIMES reporter last evening that he could not say when he would be able to go to Washington.

BUFFALO, Feb. 12.--The Grand Army of the Republic is dissatisfied with the present Board of Pension Examiners for Western New York. Complaints have been frequent of ill treatment accorded to veterans who appeared before the board for examination, and the matter culminated some time since in the publication of charges against the physicians composing the board.

Frederick K. Reed, the stock broker of 53 Broadway, who lived at 106 East Sixteenthstreet, is a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Prison on a charge of having swindled Mrs. Louisa Saussy of 148 West Forty-first-street out of $2,300 which he had prevailed upon her to intrust to him to invest in stocks.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12.--Gov. McGill, being questioned to-day in regard to the Hon. C.K. Davis's successor on the National Republican Committee, said: "I have heard that my name has been mentioned in connection with the vacant office, but I do not want it.
MINDEN, Ontario, Feb. 12.--The residence of William Hull was burned last night. His aged mother, who was alone in the house at the time, was burned to death.

As to Southey the world has been well informed. The poet's son long ago gave to the public, in six volumes, his father's correspondence, with an account of his life, and a son-in-law of Southey's has published four other volumes of letters.

Rudolph Aronson, the manager of the Casino, was looking unusually well yesterday morning, as he stood upon the Cunard Company's steamship landing, waiting for the Custom House officials "to go through" his effects.

Frank Hall of Philadelphia, who has "managed" the six-day go-as-you-please contest which ended on Saturday night at the MadisonSquare Garden, did not look like an ideal manager as he sat in the office of the Ashland House, in Fourth-avenue, near Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--The Fiftieth Congress may be "stupid," in the estimation of the Hon. Thomas B. Reed, but, when it comes to devoting itself to a scheme to get rid of money in a way not calculated to reduce taxation it must be admitted that it does it generously if not ingeniously.

Symonds; "Telegraph and Telephone," by Thomas Gray, assistant to Sir William Thomson; "Temple," by Dr. Robertson Smith, and "United States," by Profs. Johnston and Whitney and Gen. F.A. Walker.
SAN REMO, Feb. 12.--The German Crown Prince arose this afternoon and sat up several hours. He is exceedingly well and lively.

CORK, Feb. 12.--The magistrate to-day remanded Mr. Gilhooly, member of Parliament, for trial at the Scuull Sessions on March 2. Bail was refused.
There were 97 arrests yesterday for violations of the excise law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--Mrs. Weltha A. Emmons, the wife of Prof. Emmons of the Geological Survey, who had rendered herself famous through her eccentric conduct, died here to-day in rooms on F-street, where she had been living for the last two months. It is stated at the house that she died of general debility.

CHICAGO, Feb, 12.--There is a curious state of affairs existing in the relations of dressed beef shippers and the trunk lines. There has been trouble ever since the Grand Trunk fought the other lines and was allowed a differential by them.

LONDON, Feb. 12.--A pack of caged wolves escaped from Sanger's Circus to-day. The elephants, camels, horses, and other animals became mad with terror and were liberated with difficulty. The wolves were trapped in a stable, where they furiously devoured a horse already slain. They still fiercely defy capture.

On Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday evenings there will be sales at auction of 237 paintings by European artists belonging to C.F. Hazeltine of Philadelphia. Apparently this dealer has been waiting for the repeal of the law against sales after nightfall; he is about to sell 500 from his present stock, and this is the first batch.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12.--Dr. Patton, President-elect of Princeton College, preached this morning in Marquand Chapel. The sermon was a strong defense of faith against materialism. No allusion was made to his election except in a prayer asking guidance in the decision of the momentous questions of the present hour. The chapel was crowded and a number of persons were turned away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--It is expected that the Committee on Territories of the House of Representatives will take final action to-morrow on the numerous bills looking to the admission into the Union of States of the Territories of Dakota, Montana, Washington, and New-Mexico.

The Central Labor Union yesterday passed a resolution condemning the formation of sugar and other trusts, whose sole object is to put up prices of necessaries of life for the purpose of making the rich richer, and calling upon the Grand Jury to indict the firms who have entered the sugar trust, under the conspiracy law.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 12.--Mr. and Mrs. M. B. Merrill of Hayfield Township, Penn., west of this city, have just celebrated their seventy-fifth or diamond wedding anniversary by a family reunion, at which all of their 15 living children were present. Mr. Merrill is 97 and his wife is 89 years of age.

The Republicans are beginning to prepare for the district conventions which elect two delegates each to the National Convention. The State Convention, at which four delegates at large will be added to the 68 thus elected by the district plan, may be held to the city of Syracuse in the early part of May.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12.--The law and its officers have placed a leading part in Chicago theatrical affairs during the last week. NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 13.--Ice has nearly gone from Buzzard's Bay. Many buoys have been broken or dragged away. The schooner Annie E. Ketohum of Baltimore ran on a rock while beating in. She leaks 500 strokes an hour.

Henry Knickerbacker, Jr., the youngest son of Henry Knickerbacker, a wealthy broker, whose office is at 15 New-street, shot himself in the head with a revolver at the Worden Hotel, Saratoga, yesterday morning about 10 o'clock, and died a few moments afterward.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 13.--Intense interest is everywhere manifested in the surprising change that has come over the spirit of the dreams of the great Maine statesman.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Feb. 13.--The most disastrous fire that this place has seen for some time occurred last night just before midnight. The St. Albans Hospital was completely gutted and two out of eight patients suffocated.

Nothing could be more thoroughly Parisian than the later plays of Alexandre Dumas fils. The wit in them is Parisian wit, the people are Parisians, the philosophy with which they are abundantly supplied could not have originated anywhere else.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 13.--Mrs. Susan H. Beckel to-day entered proceedings in court here asking for the appointment of a Receiver for the Beckel House, the leading hotel of this city. The proprietor, Horace Fox, became involved by his Mayville (N.Y.) house, and it has taken him to the wall. Mrs. Beckel's claim is for rent, and amounts to $4,500. The total liabilities amount to about $35,000.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was hold at the clubrooms in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The old Board of Directors was re-elected and to the list was added the names of Ben Ali Haggin and James Schofflein. The club's finances were reported to be in an excellent condition, and a promising outlook for next season was reported.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 13.--An active political campaign carried on in midwinter, and when the thermometer ranges from 10 to 35 below zero, is a novelty.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13.--There was but little of general interest developed in the tallysheet trial to-day, except the testimony of Prop. C.C. Howard, who explained the action of nitric acid upon paper when figures made in ink had been eliminated by its use.
A fire broke out at 12:35 this morning in the print-coloring establishment of B. Kurz, at 86 and 88 Park-place, and spread rapidly, gutting the two buildings in a very short time.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 13.--Judge Walter Q. Gresham was in this city this afternoon, but he refused absolutely to express an opinion on the Blaine letter.
The final statements of Gov. HOADLY and of Mayor HEWITT touching the part taken by Mr. TILDEN in the Electoral controversy of 1877 are given in our news ...
There is no other French financial journal whose opinions and statements have so much weight as those of L' Economiste Francais.
