At an auction sale of bronzes, silver, ceramics, and curios yesterday afternoon at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries, 366 and 368 Fifth-avenue, the three lots of Baugrand silverware, which gave the chief interest to the sale, went to dealers at very low prices.

To the great relief of letter carriers St. Valentine seems to be going out of fashion. The business at the Post Office was not perceptibly increased by his feast day yesterday, and were it not for the calendar the officials would not have noticed the event at all.
SAN REMO, Feb. 14.--The German Crown Prince passed a restless night, but slept this morning. He is without fever and there are no bad symptoms in the throat.

District Attorney Fellows said yesterday that the case of Gould and Sage would be sent to the Grand Jury some time this week, but that he would make no recommendation as to the action it should take in the matter unless it should request his advice.

At the invitation of the National Board of Fire and Marine Underwriters a committee from the Cotton Exchange met in the office of the board, at 25 William-street, yesterday to hear what it had to say in regard to proposed improvements in the baling of cotton.

PARIS, Feb. 14.--The Jours Gras have brought no public festivity or street fun. The people seem to have lost all interest in the carnival fetes; and yet the sun came to gild the scene for the first time in many days. The balls at the Opera, the Continental Hotel, and the Hotel de Ville were overcrowded, and every ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 14.--There was a quiet, unheralded conference at the Palmer House on Sunday, which was attended by some of the leading admirers of Gov. Hill in Chicago. They were there to meet ex-Judge George W. Cothran of Buffalo, who used to be a Cleveland man, but now waves the Hill banner. Judge Cothran was questioned to-day about the political situation, and declared Gov. Hill an ideal candidate for the Presidency.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 14.--H.B. West, proprietor of the new Johnson House, was fined $50 and costs to-day for setting unlabeled oleomargarine before his guests. This case has been in the police court since last Fall, stubbornly fought inch by inch. The main reliance of the defense was upon the hope that the statute would be declared unconstitutional.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 14.--In a collision today near Gatineau Bridge between the Winnipeg express and a west-bound freight train an engine and two cars were wrecked, but nobody was seriously hurt, Damage, $20,000.

Mayor Hewitt's proposed municipal building promises to have a hard time of it all around. The law passed by the last Legislature was not just such a law as the Mayor wanted, so he prepared for something else, and the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund fell in with his plans.

For a second time within a year the house of Mrs. B.H. Van Auken, 421 Fifth-avenue, was the scene of a wedding yesterday afternoon. Miss Cornolia Van Auken was the bride on this occasion and the bridegroom was Lindley Hoffman Chapin.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Feb. 14.--Recent developments and the condition of the miners, strike--to say nothing of the strike on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad--prove once more the truth of the old adage that too many cooks spoil the broth.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14.--The first general reception in the new Executive Mansion took place to-night, when Gov. Hill, surrounded by his staff, welcomed those he had invited to meet the heads of the departments and members of the Legislature. Guests were received by the Governor in the great North Room. The attendance was very large and the company of more than usual brilliancy.

Informally, but still with a growing interest, members of the Produce Exchange discussed further yesterday the way in which the Standard Oil tail had wagged the anti-monopoly dog in the Produce Exchange special committee on the reason why that body's memberships are of such diminished and diminishing value.

NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 14.--With the thermometer at 68 , and the sky unflecked by a single cloud, the weather was all that could be desired to-day. For the seventeenth time Rex resumed his dominion over the Crescent City, and on the fete day of Mardi Gras treated his subjects to a glimpse of his pageant.

Louis F. Post, William T. Croasdale, the Rev. Hugh F. Pentecost, and others of the Henry George faction of the United Labor Party, have applied to Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court for incorporation as the Anti-Poverty Society.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14.--Major Frank T. Lee of the Second Regiment, one of the prominent military men of the State, was married this evening to Miss Susie B. Scranton, a well-known society young lady and daughter of George H. Scranton.

ALBANY, Feb. 14.--How true it is that men move in a circle when dazed ! The Assembly to-day voted to move back into its chamber with the cracked stone ceiling. It has now got back to exactly the same point where it started from a fortnight ago, when this senseless scare was created by a few designing gentlemen for selfish purposes of their own, and perhaps Mr. Ainsworth ...
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 14.--John W. Bruder, a reporter on the Memphis Appeal, was run over and killed by a hook and ladder truck to-day, the wheels passing over his head and crushing it.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 14.--The Virginia Senate to-day passed a bill establishing a State Normal School at the historic old William and Mary College at Williamsburg in this State. This institution,...

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen a resolution by Mr. Conkling, recommending the enactment by the Legislature of Connelly's bill adding a member each from New-York City and Brooklyn to the State Board of Assessors, was adopted.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14.--A lynching took place this morning within 30 miles of St. Louis. The scene was Pinckneyville, Ill., and the time 2 o'clock this morning.

For some months past a few journals and a good many more or less public men in the Republican Party have been urging with much zeal and equal sincerity that the party should and could be rallied to victory by its better element.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Feb. 14.--Upon arriving here last evening the members of the Sterling Dramatic Company, booked to appear at Liscomb's Opera House all this week, found that quarters had been engaged at the leading hotel for several of them, and at another hostelry for the rest.
The annual meeting of the Archdeaconry of Westchester County was held yesterday in the Grace Episcopal Church, White Plains. The service commenced at 11 o'clock and Bishop Potter presided.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14.--The letter from Mr. Blaine retiring as a candidate for the Presidential nomination of the Republican Party still continues to be a very interesting topic of conversation among politicians and business men here.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14.--This has been Sherman day in Columbus, and everything calculated to strengthen his hold on the State and the delegation has been done by his friends. Mr. Sherman has been the recipient of unusual attention, many persons coming from distant sections of the State to pay their respects.

There is a lamentation among the junk dealers. Their "combine" has been broken up by the Department of Charities and Correction. Saddest of all, the work of destruction was accomplished by means of the insignificant item "bones."

About 200 business men, representing a majority of the 175 woolen mill companies east of Ohio, and various commission houses who sell woolen and worsted goods for manufacturers, met yesterday at 54 White-street to take steps toward organizing the Woolen Goods Association.

Messrs, Hitchcock, Darling Co., the proprietors of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, have got from Judge Patterson an injunction restraining Joseph Q. Laws, the fashionable tailor in the hotel building who recently failed, and his Assignee, George Vestner, from leasing the store which Mr. Laws occupied to Lewis Cohen or any one else for any other purpose than maintaining therein a first-class merchant tailer's business.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 14.--At the meeting of the commission on the Putnam equestrian statue with Gov. Lounsbury this afternoon the Hon. Henry C. Robinson stated that E.C. Stedman of New-York City has declined to deliver the poem at the dedication.

The Kings County Republican General Committee met last night in the Everett Assembly Rooms, on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and, as usual, got into a row over the old trouble in the Second Ward, where the enemies of John Ward, the present "boss," rose against him, and in their might ordered a new primary.

The number 13 loses its malignant powers on Staten Island, at least in connection with the charity ball for the benefit of the S.R. Smith Infirmary. The thirteenth annual ball was held Monday evening at the German Club rooms.
A meeting of the creditors of M. E. Salomon, Wholesale dealers in tobacco at 85 Maiden-lane, was held yesterday at the rooms of the Tobacco Board of Trade.

An appalling accident occurred on the unfinished Broadway branch of the Union Elevated Railroad Company of Brooklyn yesterday. The time was 9:45 A.M. and the scene was between Ellery and Fayette streets, a point reached by the construction gang of the iron contractors, J. B. J.M. Cornell.

The Secretary of the Winchester Repeating Arms Company explained to a correspondent of THE TIMES a few weeks ago that the company could hardly expect to export the ammunition which it makes because of the high duty on lead.

TRENTON, Feb. 14.--One of the most memorable and exciting contests ever witnessed in the New-Jersey Legislature will likely be provoked by the combined Local Option and High License bill reported to-day by the House Judiciary Committee as a substitute for the Local Option bill, whose progress was ordered by the joint caucus last week.

During the run of "Adonis" at the Bijou Opera House a book agent invaded the green room and succeeded in inveigling even the wily actor and actress into purchasing sets of Appleton's Encyclopedia. Edward Rice took a set which he presented to Dixey, and afterward secured one for himself. Then Miss Ida Bell subscribed for a set.
BUFFALO, Feb. 14.--Sufficient time has not elapsed since the appearance of Blaine's letter to allow the Republican sentiment in this section to crystallize.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 14.--John Stevenson is 90 years old. He has annoyed the community for many years buying up small claims and then proceeding in court against the debtors.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14.--The Junior Assembly to-night was a very brilliant and successful affair. Anniversary Hall was handsomoly decorated and the costumes worn by the ladies were rich and tasteful.

More than a year ago Ramon Paez, the well-known author of works of travel, left a number of stereotype plates in the care of Richard Handy, Printer, 45 Rose-street, Mr. Handy afterward failed in business, since which time the most diligent search and inquiry have failed to discover the plates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14.--There are some echoes to-day of the talk of yesterday over Blaine's Florence letter, but the purport of the opinions is about the same. The friends of Mr. Blaine who believe that he will be the candidate notwithstanding his declaration that his name will not be presented to the National Convention, still insist that it will greatly strengthen ...

WARSAW, N.Y., Feb. 14.--The papers were served yesterday in two suits against the Hon. Augustus Frank of the Bank of Warsaw and the Hon. Donald McNaughton of Rochester to recover on certain claims against the Rochester and State Line Railway Company, which, it is claimed, are entitled ...
SARATOGA, Feb. 14.--The suicide of Henry Knickerbacker of New York in the Worden Hotel here yesterday is the topic of much discussion.

Steamboat Inspectors Worden, O'Brien, and Robinson will to-day peruse the Moran family Bible. Their perusal will not be for the purpose of attaining proficiency in Biblical lore, but their reading will be, so to speak, between the leaves.

CARLISLE, Penn., Feb. 14.--W.L. Boswell, Sr., and W.L. Boswell, Jr., insurance agents, having offices on Walnut-street, Philadelphia, appeared before the Carlisle courts to-day to defend a charge for which they were admitted to bail last Summer.

"We who are about to die, salute you," or as it is more euphoniously expressed in the Roman tongue, "Morituri te salutamus," was the mournful motto which decorated the coffin lids used by the Thirteen Club as menus at its seventy-fourth dinner Monday evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14.--Capt. William H. Arthurs, Assistant Surgeon, has been granted two months' extension of leave of absence.
The Building Materials Exchange held a meeting yesterday to listen to the report of the Committee on Docks.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 14.--Miss Sophia Hungerford is the assistant teacher in the Woodberry High School. Woodberry is on the outskirts of Baltimore, about a mile from Miss Hungerford's home.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14.--The NewYork Milk Exchange has fixed the price of milk at 3 cents a quart, delivered in the city, from Feb. 10 until further notice.

At Dockstader's Monday evening, after Jose, Frillman, Rieger, and Dockstader himself had done their preliminary warbling and had vied with one another in telling artistic whoppers, James Albert, the winner in the recent six-day race, was introduced to audience.

Mr. Nat C. Goodwin appeared with his company at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre Monday evening in the double bill he has lately made popular, comprising "Lend Me Five Shillings," and Mark Melford's three-act farce "Turned Up."
The West India Cable Company's steamer Grappler has just successfully finished repairing the telegraph cable broken between Jamaica and Colon, a work upon which she has been engaged since November.

William I. Negus and William C.B. Carpenter, composing the firm of William I. Negus Co., dealers in hardware at 17 Warren-street, made an assignment yesterday to Frederick G. Smedley, giving preferences for $21,770 as follows: For rent, $812; North River Bank, $8,492; Importers and Traders' National Bank, $8,456; National Seaboard Bank, $4,010. The preferences to the banks are for notes indorsed by the firm.

"Pete" has passed its one hundredth night at Mr. Harrigan's Park Theatre with a record of uninterrupted success, the melody, the humor, and the pictures of the piece having caught the public favor and held it. "Pete" will last through the remainder of the season, and may be seen again hereafter.

A committee of the Chamber of Commerce, of which James H. Seymour, F.K. Thurber, and Henry Wilson were the members, called on Mayor Hewitt yesterday to advocate the substitution of a new rail--less objectionable to owners and drivers of vehicles--for the present lowflanged, centre-bearing street car rail.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 14.--The parishioners of Christ's Episcopal Church on Union-avenue, Allegheny, were treated to a genuine sensation at the morning service Sunday in the shape of a letter of resignation from the Rector, the Rev. Mr. Meech.
Admiral Ammen has consented to the publication of the following personal letter from Gen. Grant:

The Veteran Corps of the Twenty-second Regiment, at its meeting last night at 4 Unionsquare, examined the new uniform that the corps has adopted. It is similar to the old, with the exception of the blouse, which is single-breasted, of dark blue cloth, with collar, sleeve, seams, and edge trimmed with a double row of black mohair.

Seventy-five oil paintings belonging to the estates of H.P. Kidder of Boston, James H. Van Alen of Newport, and Edward Matthews of NewYork were sold at auction at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries last evening.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 14.--Four men arrived here to-day from Norfolk, considerably worse for an exciting experience on the bay.
For some time Collector Magone has had special Treasury agents watching for refined opium smugglers, who bring the drug into the United States by the St. Lawrence River route.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14.--Every indication points to the most desperate means being resorted to for the purpose of bringing the strike in the Schuylkill region to an end.

The Legislative Committee of the Real Estate Exchange held a somewhat animated meeting yesterday and discussed the propriety of the taxation of personal property.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 14.--The Mayor of Richmond is in daily receipt of letters from all parts of the country in regard to the proposal to remove Libby Prison from here to Chicago. Among the letters received to-day was one from James Stewart of Pittsburg, late Captain of Company K, One Hundred and Forty-sixth New-York Volunteers, and Brevet LieutenantColonel.

Julia Reynolds, a boarder at 4 Bond-street, Brooklyn, upset a Kerosene lamp in her room last evening, and in an instant her dress was in flames. Mrd. Millie J. Donnell tried to extinguish the flames, but failed, and was herself badly burned about the arms.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 14.--The National Shooting Tournament, open to the world, began to-day on the Pennsylvania Clubhouse grounds, at West End, and 20 rounds were shot. Owing to the recent snowstorm the grounds were in a terrible condition.

For a few days past political circles in Castleton, Staten Island, have been in a ferment over the candidacy of Richard L'H. Finch, Democrat, and Robert Moore, the present incumbent and an independent nominee, for the office of Supervisor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14.--The Republican State Central Committee to-night decided to hold the State Convention for the nomination of the candidates for State officers and to select delegates at large to the National Convention at Dayton on April 18 and 19.

BOSTON, Feb. 14.--A bill in equity was filed to-day in the Supreme Judicial Court for Essex County by the Trustees of Phillips Academy against the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, the Visitors of the Theological Instition in Phillips Academy, Messrs. Seelye, Eustis, and Marshall, and the five Professors whose cases have recently come under investigation by the Board of Visitors upon accusations preferred by Messrs. Wellman, Dexter, and others.
"Mr. Gould will arrive in Florida next Monday or Tuesday on board the Atalanta." Such is the assurance whispered around. "He will not come direct to New-York," it is added.

The removal of the tenement-house cigarmakers who have been in the employment of Jacoby Bookman, for non-payment of February rent and for taking an active interest in the strike, began shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

Miss Fanny Davenport, with her company, is rehearsing "La Tosca" twice a day, and Manager Edwin Price, her husband, says there is no doubt that the play will be ready for production, as announced, at French and Sanger's now Broadway Theatre on Monday week, the 27th inst.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14.--Charles C. Ford, Captain of the New-Haven Grays and proprietor of Ford's Advertising Agency, was arrested to-day by United States Marshal Lovejoy on a charge of aiding and abetting a lottery in violation of the United States statutes.

Herrmann, the wizard, assisted by his wife and by "the great fantasieste, D'Alvini," entertained a very large audience at the FifthAvenue Theatre on Monday evening. There were five parts to the programme, and all were exceedingly clever.
The etched work of Felix Buhot is hardly known in the United States to collectors of black and white. Mr. S.P. Avery is almost alone in the discovery of his peculiar talents.

Two young ruffians forced an entrance to the apartments of Mrs. Charles G. Murch, at 298 Manhattan-avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday night, and, knocking down Mrs. Murch, 70 years old, robbed her of $10 and assaulted her in a cruel and brutal manner.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14.--There was a long discussion between counsel in the tallysheet trial to-day, the defense taking the ground that the testimony of Justice Matthias Martin relative to the offer of Ike Hill to give $3,000 if he would throw out the two precincts in dispute was not competent, and requesting that it be stricken from the record.

One of the interesting features of the debate in the Senate on the Blair Educational bill is the strong opposition made to the measure by prominent Republicans on the ground that it is in violation of the principle of State rights.
There are family jars in the Seventy-first Regiment, the principal one on account of Company I, that has for many years been commanded by Capt L. Frank Barry.

ELBERON, N.J., Feb. 14.--Margaret Purcell, the aged housekeeper who was so brutally assaulted by Richard Kearney, a colored coachman, at Mrs. Lyddy's Elberon cottage, No. 2, is lying in a very precarious condition, her recovery being considered doubtful.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14.--Martin A. Ryerson, carrying out the intentions of his father, Martin Ryerson, has given a piece of property valued at $225,000 to eight charitable institutions of the city.

LONDON, Feb. 14.--At a Cabinet council held to-day it was decided to instruct the Irish Executive to cease prosecuting newspapers for publishing reports of meetings of suppressed branches of the League.

PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss., Feb. 14.--On the wide gallery of his handsome residence in this cheery suburb of New-Orleans, in the warm sunshine in his padded chair, the thermometer at 77, and the roses blooming and the birds singing in the magnolia on the lawn, sat nearly all yesterday morning Gen. William S. Harney.

The arrival of Ernest Gye. formerly director of the Royal Italian Opera Company, Covent Carden, London, on the Etruria on Sunday has given rise to rumors that the object of his visit is to inquire into the prospects of giving a season of Italian opera, or a concert tour, next Winter in the United States and Canada.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14.--The 150 employes of N.W. Gokey Sons' boot and shoe factory are out on a strike.

Intelligent workmen would not strike work in order to obtain such an advance unless they had some assurance that they would succeed and that the advanced wages would be paid long enough to reimburse them for what they might lose while the strike was in progress.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--Chicago shippers are ridiculing the announced advance of export rates to full inland rates to the seaboard on Feb. 20.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.--Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde, member of Parliamont, spent to-day in this city looking about Yale University and other points of interest. He was particularly delighted with Yale and its Professors. He has arranged for a big National League rally in the New-Haven Opera House to-morrow night.

NORTH WILBRAHAM, Mass., Feb. 15.--The extensive works of the Collins Paper Manufacturing Company caught fire at 3 o'clock this morning and were almost wholly destroyed.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 15.--The entire building of the Elmira Advertiser was burned tonight. Nothing was saved but a few files. The employes in the bindery, composing, and editorial rooms has narrow escapes. The Sunday Tidings office, next door south of the Advertiser's was also totally destroyed.

All the eloquence of auctioneer Leonard could not infuse a spirit of enthusiasm among those who attended last night's sale of the first part of the Haseltine collection of paintings at Moore's Art Galleries, 290 Fifth-avenue.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 15.--A local sporting man named Charles Bibbins offers to bet $5,000 against $2,000 that James Albert did not walk 621 miles in the recent race in the Madison-Square Garden and that he cannot walk 550 miles in six days. It is understood that if the bet is accepted Bibbins will undertake to prove that the 621 miles was accomplished by Albert and a twin brother who looks precisely like him, walking alternately.

Surrogate Ransom listened to testimony yesterday in the contest over the will of Mrs. Catherine Silber, widow of Frederick Silber, a butcher.

YORK, Penn., Feb. 15.--Oliver P. Truett, a fireman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, deliberately shot his wife and then himself with a revolver this morning. Truett will die and his wife is disfigured for life.

PLAINFIELD, N.J. Feb. 15.--John Reginald Talbot, the bogus Lord Courtnay, whose escapades in Newark and Plainfield were so widely published two months ago, wrote a letter to a former companion, an employe in the office of the Electric Light Company here a few days ago. The letter was dated at Albany and said that Talbot had secured a good situation and was having a smooth time of it there. He is living under an alias.

Miss Terry was presented with a pair of oxidized silver candlesticks.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 15.--The westbound freight on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad was wrecked this morning at Paint Rock, Ala., 60 miles west of this city. The wreck blockaded the road 12 hours.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 16.--The "Soo" line announced to-day an advance in the rates of flour, grain, and millstuffs. This follows the advance made last week by the Eastern trunk lines.

Walter J. Roberts, doing business as W. J. Roberts Co., dealer in stone, at 43 Broadway, has been placed in the hands of a Receiver--Jacob F.D. Solie--by Judge Pitshke of the City Court, on the application of Bloomingdale Brothers, judgment creditors.

Sans-Leroy, member of the Chamber of Deputies, for the appointment of a parliamentary committee to examine into the privileges of the Bank of France, on the ground that such motion infringes the prerogatives of the Executive.

They will be given a big reception at Winnipeg to-morrow. The result is due to popular feeling on the railroad question.

The sale of the first section of the paintings of the Hazeltine collection was terminated last night, when the pictures sold realized nearly $33,000, making a total of the three nights' sale of about $52,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--The will of Mrs. Weltha A. Emmons, who died in this city on Sunday last, was filed to-day with a petition asking for probate. The will, it is expected, will be contested and the question of the sanity of Mrs. Emmons again disputed.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 17.--Green B. Morris, owner of Apollo, the Derby winner of 1882, who is wintering here, was seen to-day by a TIMES correspondent in reference to Capt. Sam Brown's statement concerning that event.

ALBANY, Feb. 17.--Ex-Mayor "Jim" Howell's great scheme for securing additional terminal facilities for the Brooklyn Bridge was presented to the Assembly to-day by Assemblyman Farrell of Brooklyn. It requires the Brooklyn terminus to be located "at or near the City Hallsquare."

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 17.--Henry D. Wiltbank was arraigned in the Police Court to-day as a common drunkard, and sent to the Concord Reformatory. Four years ago he was Cashier in a leading bank of New-York City. He began to drink and lost his position, and has since fallen rapidly. He has been an inmate of the Lynn Inebriates' Home.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 17.--The Free Press has received complete returns from every county in the Eleventh Congressional District, with the exception of Manitou. They show a plurality of 526 for Seymour, (Rep., ) and as the entire vote of Manitou does not usually exceed 1,150 Seymour's plurality cannot fall below 400. Both sides claim the election.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--At an early hour this morning burglars broke into the SubPost Office at Port Richmond, blew open the safe, and stole $23 in cash and about $100 worth of postage stamps. It was just 3 o'clock when Baker Heffly, whose residence adjoins the Post Office, was aroused by a violent explosion.

Without any preliminary flourish of trumpets or unusual splurge the American Association of Public Accountants has been organized in this city, with James Yalden of this city as President and John Heins of Philadelphia as Vice-President, and a council, consisting of a dozen public accountants known here and in Boston, Philadelphia, and Western cities as thoroughly able and competent men.
The funeral of George V. Hecker, who died Tuesday at his residence, 278 Madison-avenue, tookplace yesterday morning at the Church of the Paulist Fathers, Ninth-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 17.--At a meeting of the Union Building Loan stockholders, held last evening. W.P. Voorhees, C.H. Runyon, and Alan H. Strong, on behalf of part of the stockholders, demanded an accounting from the Directors. The loan owns the Masonic Hall, which is worth $75,000 and 16 valuable building lots near the Pennsylvania Railway station. No account has been made in three years. The Directors promise to report next month.

That cheerful convalescent, Chimpanzee Crowley of Central Park, had his likeness taken a day or two ago. He submitted gracefully, and conducted himself as a tractable and gentlemanly sitter. About a dozen views in different attitudes were obtained.

The Norwegian bark Maude, Capt. Kroger, from Savannah for Hamburg, came into this port yesterday flying signals of distress. Five of her crew had refused to do duty Feb. 4 because, in their opinion, the vessel was unseaworthy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--Fifty recruits have been assigned to the Fifth Cavalry, and the same number to the Seventh Cavalry. Capt. William E. Hoffman, Ninth Infantry, has been ordered to his home to await retirement.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The funeral of D.R. Locke took place this afternoon, the services being held at the residence.

A mass meeting was held last evening in the large hall of the Cooper Union to protest against the continuance of the internal revenue tax on cigars and tobacco. M. De Costa presided, and speeches were made in both German and English.

The mangled body of John Daily, aged 30, a slate roofer, was found on the tracks of the Consolidated Railroad in New-Haven, Conn., Thursday night. The arms and legs were scattered along the tracks, but the head could not be found. Two weeks also he left his brother's house, 845 Pacific-street, Brooklyn, carrying his lunch. The announcement of his death was the first tidings since received of him.

GAINSESVILLE, Texas, Feb. 17.--An attempt was made last night to rob the Santa Fe passenger train due here from Galveston at 10:30 P.M. J.T. Pirtle, a detective and a resident of this city was at Sanger, a station about 20 miles south of here, when six men rode up on horseback.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Feb. 17.--Between 8 and 9 o'clock this morning an explosion of natural gas wrecked the house of Joseph Franklin, situated at the outskirts of the city, seriously if not fatally injuring Mrs. Franklin.
In the Tombs Police Court yesterday Isaac Lasser, aged 22, of 114 East Broadway, and Simon Nachtigall, dealer in tailors' trimmings, 99 Essexstreet, were held for trial in General Sessions.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 17.--M.F. Holihan, the Special Agent of the Treasury Department sent here from New-York City to investigate the opium smuggling cases, has secured evidence that the smugglers have confederates in New-York.
The House Military Committee must feel somewhat puzzled in its investigation of the purchase of Fort Brown military reservation in Texas.

Henri Bulard, aged 26, yesterday pleaded guilty to an attempt at larceny in the General Sessions. On Dec. 23 he snatched a pocketbook from the hand of Miss Mary d'Aubigne in Sixthavenue, near Eleventh-street. She screamed, and he thrust the pocketbook back into her hand and fainted.

The earliest of Maine's known poets was Parson Smith of Falmouth, who in 1759 wrote a bit of doggerel on "The Sexton's Appointment", which has been preserved. Another early versemaker was Senator Frye's ancestor, Gen. Joseph Frye, the founder of Fryeburg, who wrote a poem called "Calm Content".

LONDON, Feb. 17.--In the House of Commons this evening Mr. Balfour, Cheif Secretary for Ireland, resumed the debate on the address in reply to the Queen's speech. He commented upon the vehement character of Mr. O'Brien's attack last evening, and said that still it was ...

The statue of the Queen which Mr. Boehm is executing for the University of London will be placed at the top of the first flight of the grand staircase, directly in front of the main entrance. Mr. Boehm has expressed himself highly pleased with this situation.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17.--The auction sale of autographs formerly belonging to the late Ben: Perley Poore, was continued to-day. An autograph letter of Edgar Allan Poe, upon the subject of "The Raven," , brought $90, and another upon literary matters brought $35.

No observant reader of the reports of the House of Commons since its reassembly can have failed to note a marked difference in tone between the speeches that are made now and the speeches that were made before the recess.

Henry D. Purroy, the President, called the County Democracy's Executive Committee to order last evening in the headquarters in Cooper Union. Police Justice White brought up the question of having the Democratic National Convention meet in this city and proposed that the Democratic members of Congress be requested to seek to have the convention held in this city. The motion was adopted.
The Young Men's Christian Association continued its twenty-second annual convention yesterday at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Madison-avenue and One Hundred and Twentyfirst-street.

Henry Piepgras of City Island has the contract for building a steel sloop 70 feet on the water line, on plans drawn by A.C. Smith, for Hugh and E.S. Auchincloss of the New-York Yacht Club. It is intended to be a racer, and has every promise of being a fast one.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 17.--The sale of trotting-bred horses, under the management of W.R. Brasfield Co. was ended here to-day, 67 animals being disposed of, chiefly at low prices, the average for the day being but $189.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 17.--In a recent issue of the Voice, the Prohibition organ of New-York, was published an article under the heading of "High License Failures--Startling and Conclusive Testimony from the West," ...
At the meeting of the Grand Army of the Republic in this city yesterday Capt. Horace M. Burbank of Saco was elected Department Commander by a vote of 219 to 89 for Col. Franklin M. Drew of Lewiston.

ROXBURY, N.Y., Feb. 17.--Sniffen Cartwright, a brother of Dr. Cartwright, who has a wide acquaintance in political circles in this State, of Batavia Kill, has had an experience that he will remember as long as he lives.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 17.--The Virginia House of Delegates this evening passed a bill intended to conform to the State laws the Federal inter-State commerce law. This measure provides for the appointment of a State Railroad Commission, consisting of three members.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 17.--The Bank of Central City, Dakota, closed its doors to-day. It is said and the suspension is caused by a lack of currency and will only be temporary, the bank having ample assets to meet all liabilities.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 17.--Two thousand people gathered on the ice on the Hudson opposite this city this afternoon to witness the trotting to sleighs along a straight-way mile track prepared by subscription.
The fourth public rehearsal of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society took place at the Academy of Music yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 17.--One of the greatest fires that ever visited Westerly, R.I., raged for three hours this morning, destroying several business buildings and causing a loss of about $150,000.

Martin McDonald, 70 years old, and apparently feeble and ingenuous, was convicted yesterday of grand larceny. William F. Roe, who had saved $500, saw an advertisement for a collector of rents, and wrote to the advertiser. He received an answer directing him to call on George C. Hill, at 61 Broadway, Room 7.

There was happiness on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The dealings doubled, rising above 264,000 shares, and prices through the whole list were buoyant. You couldn't see anything but smiling faces anywhere the whole Street over.

Since the Rev. U.D. Gulick was forced to resign the pastorate of the Twelfth-Street Reformed Church, Brooklyn, there has been a lack of unity among the members which threatens to break up the congregation.
DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 17.--Inquiries have been received from Buffalo, N.Y., asking information about the Murray Hill addition to Duluth, the nature of property, No such addition is known here.

Ganzell, L.G. Twitchell, and P.J. Conway; with Albany, D. Erick, J.H. Gladman, Anson Lord, S.F. Jones, and "Pete" Weckbacker; with Trov. J. Halpin; with Rochester, Richard Knox; with Binghamton, J.D. Curtis; with Milwaukee, J.Q. Sunck, Released by Troy, James Say.
SAN REMO, Feb. 17.--The Crown Prince of Germany had a good night. He is free from headache and fever.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--Louis Winans, a young man of this city, created a little sensation in broker circles here to-day. Mr. Winans insists that he was concerned in a neat scheme to bear the oil market, about three weeks ago, ...
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17.--Detectives James Tracy and John Hobbs of the city force were terribly beaten this morning in a saloon on Eighth and Pine streets.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 17.--It is claimed by a well-known lawyer of St. Paul that the appointment as Judges in Hennepin and Ramsey Counties, of Col. Hicks of Minneapolis and William Louis Kelly of St. Paul by Gov. McGill was unconstitutional, and therefore void.
A small but exceedingly choice gallery of pictures by French painters is shown at the Fifth-Avenue Galleries, above Thirty-fourth street, and will be sold at auction Feb. 28.

The funeral of Henry Knickerbacker, Sr., whose sad death occurred at Saratoga Feb. 13, took place at his residence, 830 Fifth-avenue, last evening. Only the relatives and immediate family friends were present.

An Insurance Exchange, in which about 25 companies are interested, is soon to be established, with meeting and board rooms on the top floor of the Niagara Insurance Company's building at 135 Broadway.

At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday Superintendent Murray was directed to issue the necessary orders for notice to be given to householders to clear the street gutters in front of their premises, and upon their failure so to do to have reports made out for the Corporation Attorney.

Whether or not the liquor question is to become an issue between political parties in the near future depends on the treatment accorded to moderate measures of restriction, like the High License bill, by those who represent the parties in legislation.
"Die Gotterdammerung" was preformed for the last time at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in the presence of an audience of great size.

Col. E.C. James, in the General Term of the Supreme Court, yesterday afternoon argued the appeal of Mrs. Laura V. Appleton from the decision of Judge Dykman of White Plains enjoining her from prosecuting her suit for a partition of the real estate which her brother, John Charles, Anderson, inherited by the will of their father, John Anderson, the tobacconist.

There is a hot fight on between the principal railroads and the ticket brokers, which seems to have come to stay, and in regard to which both sides are eager to carry it to a decisive issue. In its preliminary form it has so far taken definite shape in a bill introduced into the Virginia Legislature for the suppression of the business of ticket brokers in that State.

Cora Groves, a negress, was deserted by her husband at Flemington, N.J., and came here yesterday with her two children, one a boy of 4 years and the other not weaned, intending to go to-day to her mother at Gaylordsville, Conn.
Salmon disease has broken out in the Earn in its most virulent form, and the lower portion of the river has for several days been covered with dead and fungus-covered fish.

The Receivership for Walter J. Roberts, doing business as Walter J. Roberts Co., stone merchant of 43 Broadway, has been extended so as to include the claim of the Rhode Island National Bank for $5,516, which the latter was unable to collect by execution.

BASTROP, La., Feb. 17.--The explosion of a boiler on Mrs. J.N. Harp's plantation to-day killed two white men, named Reems and Johnson, and two colored men whose names are not given. Four other men were so badly scalded that they are not expected to recover. The boiler was blown to atoms and the ginhouse in which it stood was demolished.
DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 17.--A most remarkable accident occurred at Marquette last evening. A heavy freight train of 30 cars got beyond control of the crew.

Sugar importers yesterday were unanimous in expressing gratification at the appointment of the Trust Investigating Committee of the Senate and confidence that its work would result beneficially to the trade.

PARIS, Feb. 17.--The Chamber of Deputies has rejected, by a vote of 323 to 199, the proposal of M. Sans-Leroy for urgency for his motion for the appointment of a committee to inquire into questions connected with the charter of the Bank of France.

The new Broadway Theatre, which since the 1st of last September has been in process of erection at Broadway and Forty-first-street, is now rapidly approaching completion. It is now thought that it will be opened to the public on the evening of Feb. 27.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 17.--The body of a woman, welldressed in black silk, apparently about 30 years of ago, was fotnd in the marsh at the foot of South Fourth-street, near the Gloucester and Mount Ephraim Railroad, about 2 o'clock this afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17.--Representatives of all the prominent printing offices in this city met at the Elliott House here tonight and formed a Typothetae Union for mutual protection, similar to the one recently formed in New-York.

The Trustees of the Sands-Street Methodist Church, Brooklyn, are to meet in a few days to devise some plan to prevent the Union Elevated Road from erecting its structure along Sands-street from Fulton to the Bridge.

The weather of Canada has not altered in 200 years. The observations taken by the Jesuit Fathers at Quebec, and set down in the invaluable Relations day by day, show that the Winters were as long and the months of January and February as cold then as they are now, and that there has been no change whatever in the sense of mitigation.
The sudden death in Venice from an acute attack of typhoid fever of M. Hippolyte Noiret has robbed France of one of her most promising sons.

Mayor Hewitt was very angry yesterday when he called the members of the Street Opening Commission to order. "THE NEW-YORK TIMES has an article in to-day's issue," he said, "in which it is represented that I am opposed to the proposition to widen and extend Elm-street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17.--Dr. Patton has accepted the Presidency of Princeton College, but according to the statement of a member of the Faculty his letter of acceptance will not be published until the meeting of the Board of Trustees.

A few survivors of the Burnside expedition met yesterday at the office of Gen. E.S. Greeley, 7 Dey-street, to discuss the advisability of making an excursion to New-Berne, N.C. and to other battlefields in that State.
The Prospect Harriers had their regular moonlight run on Thursday night over the usual course through Prospect Park and return, a distance of about three miles and a half.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--The members of the Ways and Means Committee are day after day called upon to answer the same question-- "When will the Tariff bill be brought in?"

Julius Fitcheimer of England, who is a guest at they Murray Hill Hotel, reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that on Thursday he was robbed in a Broadway car of a pocketbook in which were $200 in Bank of England notes, private papers, and memoranda.

Gen. Roger A. Pryor, tall, gaunt, and raven-haired, stood up in Judge Freedman's part of the Superior Court yesterday and denounced the New-York Stock Exchange. "It is an infamous institution" he said. "It owns millions of property, and therefore thinks it has a right to trample upon any member ruthlessly."

Hiram Weissman, his wife, and 6-monthsold child of 45 Livingstone-street, Newark, were almost burned to death last night through carelessness in filling a lamp. The lamp exploded, setting fire to the contents of the room. In a few minutes the room was one mass of flames.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 17.--This morning the boring drill which has been hollowing out the centre of the cast-steel gun completed its work.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 17.--The organized painters of the two cities have about completed arrangements for opening co-operative shops, providing the master painters do not grant their demands for a slight advance in wages and nine hours' work. The scale was presented to the master painters' organization several weeks ago.

PARIS, Feb. 17.--Snow has again fallen, and the white sheet seems inclined to tarry indefinitely. The Paris Winter threatens to be exceptionally long and cold, and people are again starting for the South.

The Aldermanic Railroad Committee yesterday heard further arguments for and against the various schemes that have been proposed for providing rapid transit between this city and Long Island and within the city itself.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--Ex-President Charles E. Smith of the Reading Railroad Company was the first witness this morning before the Congressional investigating committee which is inquiring into the strike on the Reading Railroad system and in the coal regions.

In the second of his course of sermons on the duties and defects of husbands and wives Sunday evening, Father Coyle, in speaking of drunken husbands, said the present law had greatly increased drunkenness among both husbands and wives, that in attempting to ....

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Feb. 17.--Straight line farming is giving way to the dairy business in Sullivan County. The paper mill at Fallsburg has shut down on account of the difficulty experienced in procuring straw. The rapid growth of the milk business has greatly diminished the production of grain and straw, but will result eventually in pure milk being served to all classes of New-Yorkers at fair prices.
Prof. Joseph H. Gilmore of Rochester University, lectured yesterday morning at Columbia College on "The Rise of an American School of Poetry." The interest in Prof. Gilmore's lectures is increasing.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 17.--King William has had a violent attack of nephralgia. His condition, however, causes no alarm.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 17.--The Republican members of the Legislature met this afternoon and passed the following resolutions:
Gov. Hill had 10 minutes' talk with Mayor Hewitt yesterday. The Auction Room Committee of the Real Estate Exchange has refused to rent any part of the building for the sale of intoxicating liquors.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17.--The St. Louis delegation who propose to capture the Democratic Convention left for Washington this morning. Mayor Francis headed the party, which is composed of a score of prominent citizens. They are accompanied by a carload of champagne, beer, and cigars, and these arguments, it is anticipated, will prove effective.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb.17.--Mrs. Henry A. Paine, aged 22 years, died in Salem last evening from injuries received in falling from a sleigh on Monday evening last. She and her husband had driven from Woburn that morning to visit friends in Salem.
POTTSVILIE, Penn., Feb. 17.--The following was signed at 11:30 o'clock to-night and given to the representatives of the press:

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--The identity of one of the burglars who threw the town into a fever of excitement by murdering Amos J. Snell, the west side millionaire, about 2 o'clock Wednesday morning, Feb. 8, has been discovered.

Night Clerk Twigg of the Continental Hotel had a novel experience with a new kind of sneak thief early one morning recently. Mr. Twigg comes on duty at midnight, last after Chief Clerk Thompson leaves, and as he has been off duty during the busy hours of the day he naturally sees many strange faces in the early morning hours.

A horse driven by J.H. Morgan, while crossing Second-avenue at One Hundred and Twelfthstreet yesterday afternoon, became frightened and ran away, throwing out the occupant. Dashing on toward the East River the animal ran over Lizzie Zorn, aged 10 years, breaking one of her legs and inflicting internal injuries. She lives at One Hundred and Fifteenth-street and Third-avenue.

An automatic burglar alarm last night caused the arrest of three youthful burglars--Robert Humphrey, age 17, of 35 James-street; John Sullivan, 14, of 85 James-street, and James Campbell, 14, of 36 Oak-street.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 17.--The draft of the fishery treaty adopted at Washington has reached the Dominion Government. It was under consideration for four hours at a meeting of the Cabinet held this afternoon. The document, it is understood, will not be made public until after Parliament meets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 17.--Now that the Lick Observatory is virtually completed in accordance with the original plans, the monster telescope having been placed on its pedastal and its marvelous power demonstrated, the following facts regarding the great work will doubtless prove an unpleasant surprise to the public.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--Death was the punishment the jury this morning decided to inflict in the case of August Hetzke, who beat to death, his little stepson, Max Gilman.
RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 17.--Capt. Charles Irwin's Georgie won the challenge pennant of the North and South Shrewebury Rivers in the 20-mile race this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--Chairmen Abbott, Midgely, and Faithorn, as a committee to arrange minimum rates upon circuses, menageries, and traveling shows, have just arranged a new schedule, to apply this season, modifying and reducing the rates first established about 25 per cent.

After an illness extending over five months Alfred S. Barnes, the publisher, died at 11 o'clock last night at his residence, 815 St. Mark's-avenue, Brooklyn. All his family were gathered about his bedside, but the dying man could recognize none of them.

Every one will be sorry to hear that Mr. Wilkie Collins is again suffering from his old enemy the gout, which has pursued him with fiendish malignity for years. The famous novelist once related to me with his own lips the history of "The Moonstone" and said that some of the most entertaining scenes of that exciting novel were dictated when in the grasp of the gout-devil.
The entertainment in behalf of the Art School for Artisans, at Chickering Hall this afternoon, promises to be an exceptionally enjoyable one.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 17.--The dissatisfaction felt throughout the State when Gov. Lounsbury appointed S.M. Hotchkiss Labor Commissioner, instead of reappointing Prof. Arthur T. Hadley, is not likely to be diminished by the new Commissioner's maiden report, which will be issued within a week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17.--All the warring Northwestern roads were represented at the meeting in Chairman Faithorn's office to-day. It was developed that the "Soo" route was for peace and a differential and that the Burlington and Northern would recognize the right of no road to make a lower rate on Northwestern business.

Railroad earnings began to come in yesterday for the second week of February with the following increases: St. Paul, $11,474; Toledo and Ohio Central, $6,199; Long Isalnd, $4,772; Chicago and Eastern Illinois, $4,540. These decreases were shown: Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western, $9,498; Peoria, Decatur and Evansville, $2,300; Denver and Rio Grande, $8,320; St. Louis and San Francisco, $5,000.

About 50 of the parishioners of St. Stephen's Church met last evening at International Hall, in East Twenty-seventh-street. In accordance with the resolution that they adopted at a former meeting not to assemble again as parishioners, those who came did so as members of the Anti-Poverty Society and friends of Dr. McGlynn.

Canada may boast of having been the training school of four distinguished contemporaneous Englishmen. Lord Wolseley first made his mark in the Northwest expedition. Lord Dufferin had been in smaller offices before, but his administration in Canada made him known to the world, and he has been employed in the highest positions ever since.

Two or three days ago Chief of Police Burleigh of Waltham learned that six or seven strangers were in the city peddling what purported to be Pearline, and that in connection therewith they were perpetrating what was practically a fraud. It seems that they had two teams and were canvassing the town very thoroughly.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17.--The international curling match was played this afternoon on the ice of the Caledoman Curling Club and resulted in a victory for the Canadians by 40 points, although they were handicapped by playing with granite instead of iron.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 17.--The reception given to-night in honor of Ella Wheeler Wilcox by Mrs. Willis Howe of the Lindell Hotel proved to be one of the most interesting social events of the season. Several hundred invitations were issued, and the great hotel was thronged with guests. The costumes were magnificent, and the St. Louis ladies pronounced themselves charmed with the poetess of passion.

The Welshmen of this and surrounding cities are preparing for a great time on Wednesday, Washington's Birthday, when they intend holding the New-York City Eisteddfod in Association Hall, Twenty-third-street and Fourthavenue.

MONTREAL, Feb. 18.--There was a slim attendance at the championship snowshoe race meeting here this afternoon, but the races were capital.

The Trustees of the first mortgage bonds of the Houston and Texas Railroad Company met yesterday afternoon to set on foot preparations for dealing with the grievance of Mrs. Hettie Green and the bondholders associated with her for the purpose of resisting the Huntington plan of reorganization.
Herr Possart, the German actor, played the role of Franz Moor in Schiller's "Robbers" Friday night at the Thalia Theatre. It was his fiftieth performance, and the theatre was crowded to its utmost.

A short time since Deputy Postmaster W. S. Leake, when paying money into another Federal office in this city, was informed that a silver coin that had become smooth from usage could not be accepted, and was refused.

In the war which the Adams and American Express Companies, have been waging against the Erie Express they have just been joined by Thomas C. Platt and his United States Express Company. Notice has been served upon the Erie Express Company by the United States Company that packages will be accepted from the Erie for shipment to destination by it only upon prepayment of charges.
It is possible that others in their time may have called William Pitt unscrupulous; but surely no one has had a better right to apply that epithet to the great Minister than I have.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Feb. 18.--"Billy" Moloney, at one time Clerk to the Aldermanic Board, but of late a resident of Canada, sailed from this port to-day for Liverpool, England. He arrived here at 5 o'clock in the express from Quebec, and drove from the station straight to the steamer. He was accompanied by his son and daughter. The steamer left at 6 o'clock.

The generosity of the New-York Central Railroad Company to its employes is bearing fruit in many directions. In the fine new building on Madison-avenue there are daily informal discussions of matters of vital importance.

Lieut. E.K. Moore of the United States Navy gave a very interesting and instructive lecture before the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club last evening on "The Chronometer: Its History, Construction, Care, and Use." The lecture was one of the course which is giving the club all the available points on navigation. It is hoped by some that a course in the more practical parts of seamanship may at some future time be added.

DEADWOOD, Dakota, Feb. 18.--Information discloses the existence of a blackmailing organization, the ramifications of which extend into two continents, having for its object the blackmailing or defeat of negotiations of parties offering for sale or capitalization American mining properties in England.

BOSTON, Feb. 18.--The Andover controversy was again before Judge William Allen of the Supreme Court to-day on a question whether the records of the Board of Visitors of Phillips Academy in the case of Prof. Smythe could be controlled by parole evidence.
Harvard graduates will make merry at Delmonico's on Tuesday evening, when the annual dinner of the Harvard Club will be eaten. That the dinner will be a good one to a certainty.
The annual banquet of Le Cercle Francais de L'Harmonie was held last opening at the Hotel Brunswick. After the viands had been discussed President L. Lafon addressed the guests in French.

Considerable excitement has been created at Madrid by the case of a young girl possessing propety who died on Sunday in a convent at Vigo, where she became a nun against the will of her father, who moved every possible influence, legal and ecclesiastical, to prevent his daughter taking the veil.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 18.--A dozen firemen were severely injured, five of them seriously, and as many more were bruised in a fire here this afternoon. The fire originated in the furniture establishment of Henry Ten Broeck, on Burnet-street.

PARIS, Jan. 25.--It was high time that Signor Crispi struck his colors and consented to an amicable arrangement of that "Florentine incident," which was scarcely noticed when news first came that Signor Tosini had broken into the French consulate and sealed up its archives.

Policeman John Marks, attached to the Adams-street station, Brooklyn, was shot yesterday morning and he will probably die. He was in his bedroom at 164 Pearl-street at the time, and his wife, Eliza, was the only other person in the room.

WICHITA, Kan., Feb. 18.--A special from Beaver City, No Man's Land, reports a sensational killing at that place last night. On Feb. 10 Eugene Brusher was shot and killed by John Clark, who claimed that the shooting was accidental.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 18.--At Washingtonville on the Newburg branch of the Erie Railroad this afternoon a way freight train and a coal train collided. Several freight cars and a caboose were burned. Nobody was hurt.

All of the fixtures and furniture of the St. George Hotel, at 825 Broadway, were sold yesterday under the auctioneer's hammer to satisfy two chattel mortgages. This is the end of the third attempt which has been made during the last four years to run this hotel successfully.

READING, Mass., Feb. 18.--Thomas J. Wayfall died here this evening. He was a most prolific inventor, being second only to Edison in the number of his patents. His patents were mostly in connection with the rubber business, although he had recently perfected a new system of elevated railroad, which was to have been brought to the attention of the Legislature this month. Deceased leaves a large circle of friends.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 18.--Clayton Firth of Sugar Grove is dying from two bullet wounds in the head inflicted by himself. While in Texas last Fall he was taken ill and his brother brought him home. In explanation of his act he says the Texas physicians told him he could not recover and he was tired of being an invalid.

SAN REMO, Feb. 18.--Fresh and puzzling symptoms have manifested themselves in the case of the Crown Prince. The uneasiness concerning his condition has increased.

BERLIN, Feb. 18.--Prince Bismarck has obtained from Count Schouvaloff, the Russian Ambassador here, a definite declaration of the Czar's demands with reference to Bulgaria. No secret is made of the exact character of the proposals nor of the official opinion that they will be summarily rejected.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 16.--William C. Kelly, inventor of the Bessemer process of making steel, and who dies here on Saturday night, was years ago the proprietor of the Suanee Iron Works and Union Forge, in Lyon County, Ky. The metal produced at these works was taken from the furnace to the forge, where it was converted into charcoal blooms.
A large number of ornithologists assembled the other day in a London salesroom to bid for the possession of an egg of the great auk; and it was finally knocked down for the sum of 160 guineas.

Readers of the Century cannot fail to recall the papers on astronomy which have appeared during the last three years signed by an American astronomer whose name is particularly well known about the world in connection with observations of the sun.

ALBANY, Feb. 18.--The Assembly Chamber was soon converted into a workshop after Capitol Commissioner Perry's plan to shore up the vaulted stone ceiling was adopted, and it now looks like a lumber yard. Forces of men work day and night and are hurrying along with the task.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 18.--Postmaster Louis N. Fleury of Paso Del Norte was arrested last night by Mexican officers for a series of gigantic diamond robberies. PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 18.--The business firms burned out in the recent fire have since been occupied in removing their safes from the ruins. All the contents of Herring's Safes are preserved.
LONDON, Feb. 18.--Thomas Ryburn Buchanan, the Gladstonian candidate, was to-day re-elected to the House of Commons for the West Division of Edinburgh.

LONDON, Feb. 18.--It is well known that the wealth of the Rothschilds is back of the copper trust, but it has not been generally known that this financial family was engaged in any other operation of this sort. It now appears, however, from some investigations made by a London journalist that they have been going into the trust business pretty extensively of late.

The road will be built to Alton certainly, and eventually to St. Louis, thus giving two outlets to the East and an extrance into St. Louis.

CARLISLE, Penn., Feb. 18.--Two burglars entered Forster Mundorff's house at Mount Holly Springs last night. Mundorff awoke in time to be clubbed almost to death. In the scrimmage he fired his revolver and the robbers left without the $200 they were after.

The Anti-Saloon Republican National Committee has issued a call for a second national conference, which is to be held in this city April 18, and to last seven days. The call is addressed to all Republicans in the United States who sympathize with this movement and purpose, which is to crush out in its entirety the saloon element, and to all members of other parties and unattached voters who are willing to act with them.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Feb. 18.--A large crowd of sporting men witnessed a well-contested horserace on the ice on the Hudson River here this afternoon. The track was in excellent condition for trotting, and fast time was made.

JACKSON, Miss, Feb. 18.--The Senate to-day adopted the House bill to pay thirty-dollar yearly pensions to officers, soldiers, and sailors and their servants who served in the Confederate Army from Mississippi and who are now unable to labor because of injuries received in the service.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18.--A special meeting of the stockholders of the Old Colony Steamboat Company was held to-day, and it was voted to increase the capital stock to $1,200,000 by the issue to 3,000 new shares, to be offered pro rata to stockholders of this date.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18.--The Metropolitan Board of Police in executive session to-day increased the fees for liquor licenses to $1,000 from $800 for all retailers. The three grades of licenses of the first class are raised from $800, $500, and $350 to $1,000, $600, and $400, respectively. Licenses of the second class are raised from $175 to $200. Unless the number of licenses falls off, this action will put over $75,000 into the Treasury.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb.19.--Minnesota is for a radical tariff reduction and not for protection. It is for Gresham and not for Blaine. These are the two facts that seem to be most clearly established by nearly five columns of reviews of the political situation by Republican editors all over the State, which the Journal printed yesterday.

F.W. Pollock lectured before the Gaelic Society, at its rooms, 17 West Twenty-eighthstreet, last evening on "The Needs of the American Irish." He urged the necessity of studying the histories, traditions, music, poetry, and literature of Ireland in order that the natives of the Emerald Isle in this country might not be ashamed to acknowledge the land of their nativity.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y.,Feb. 19.--There were filed with the proper department at Harrisburg, Penn., Feb. 13, articles of association of the projected Binghamton and Williamsport Railroad. As contemplated the road will be about 90 miles in length and will be built by the Wyalusing route, crossing the Susquehanna River near the town so named.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--The plan of issuing interchangeable five-thousand-mile tickets, now being discussed by the Michigan roads, is stirring up railroad men greatly. It is proposed to issue these tickets at the rate of 2 cents a mile, and the commercial travelers are doing their best to get them.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19.--A terrific earthquake has occurred in the Province of Yun-Nan. Two thousand lives are reported to have been lost.

The Elsey Memorial Chapel, a handsome frame building in Jewett-avenue, Jersey City Heights, was dedicated yesterday. The chapel was built by John Elsey, a wealthy Washington Market (New-York) butcher. It will be devoted to the propagation of "faith-cure" doctrines.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 19.--The third large fire during the last five days occurred this afternoon on the scene of the disastrous conflagration of September, 1877.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 19.--Coulson Son of Allegheny City, Penn., have purchased from James Walker of this city Relic, a bay mare, 7 years old, by Mambrino Chief, Jr., dam Morality, by Walker Morrill, and Bellina, bay filly, 2 years old, by Jay Bird, dam Relic, for $1,000 each.
NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 19.--This village which has always been fortunate in escaping very costly fires had the most destructive conflagration in its history before noon to-day.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba., Feb. 19.--Further reports of the terrible distress existing among the Cadndian Indians in the far north are to hand. The Rev. W. Spendlove, a missionary from north of McKenzie River, is in the city, and tells of many hardships. He has been in the district for nine years, and his journey down occupied 80 or 85 days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Mr. W.W. Corcoran, the aged millionaire of this city, is again seriously ill and his relatives were telegraphed for and arrived here yesterday. His present illness is not connected with the partial stroke of paralysis which he suffered in July last, but is the result of a bronchial attack which has confined him to his bed for the last five weeks and has refused to yield to treatment.

BUFFALO, Feb. 19.--Henry Augermann, jeweler, 39 Genesee-street, is $2,500 and a safe poorer off than he was Saturday night. Professional thieves regard Buffalo as a "hoodoo" town, but one of them braved the "hoodoo" last night and made money by it. Henry Augermann put the most valuable part of his small stock in his safe Saturday night, when he closed.

ELMIRA, Feb. 19.--The remains of Charles Bentley, the fireman who was killed by falling walls during the fire in the Advertiser block, were followed to Second-Street Cemetery this afternoon by the largest funeral procession ever witnessed in Elmira. All of the old volunteer fire companies, which disbanded several years ago, reorganized and turned out in force.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton, at All Souls' Church, yesterday ended the series, begun last year, of sermons on "Woman in the State." He considered the dangers and benefits which might accompany the entrance of woman into citizenship. Instead of degrading her, he thought that occupation with large concerns and noble aims would educate her.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 19.--D. T. Edwards. age 18, son of a Newark (N.J.) confectioner, was accidentally killed in the elevator of the Windsor Hotel here shortly after noon today. Edwards came here two weeks ago with a bankrupt clothing sale company and was boarding at the hotel. He had started the elevator, and failing to get in the passenger compartment fell into the freight carriage.

BOSTON, Feb. 19.--John H. Autcliff of the firm of Stewart, Autcliff Co., iron and metal dealers, 250 Federal-street, has been missing from his home, 308 Sumner-street, East Boston, since Monday, Feb. 6. His relations have kept the matter very quiet. He left home ostensibly on a business errand, and since that time no trace of his whereabouts has been discovered.

The career of "The Wife" at the Lyceum Theatre has completely upset Manager Frohman's prearranged plans, which contemplated the production of at least three plays this season, and the continued success of the first venture of his new stock company has compelled him to make some changes in his business arrangements.

Jose Antonio Paez.

ROCHESTER, Feb., 19.--An engineer named Charles Curler, on a yard engine plying on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad between this city and Windsor Beach, four miles north, went crazy last night about dark and began a series of antics that came near costing many people their lives.

CARACAS, Feb. 10.--Yesterday an Electoral Convention met in El Concejo Municipul, (Municipal Council Chamber,) in this city, for the purpose of selecting a candidate whom the convention will recommend to Congress for confirmation as President of the United States of Venezuela to succeed Gen. Lopez, who now occupies that important office.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Feb, 19.--One day recently an old woman of Troy, N. Y., died at the age of 101 years, and it was announced that she was the oldest person in the State. Mrs. Bridget Eagan, who lives on the outskirts of Rondout. feels quite indignant over the statement, Mrs. Eagan is 105 years old, as her family Bible testifies and which the records brought over from Ireland years ago corroborate.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 19.--B.H. Demarest, proprietor of the Standard Museum, in Shakespeare Hall, left the city last night, leaving the members of his theatrical company behind in a state of destitution. He owes the Treasurer and other attaches several weeks' salary, and left his advertising and printing bills unpaid. He also left large bills at various hotels unpaid.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 19.--At 1 o'clock this morning the police sloop Folly of the oyster navy, in command of Capt. George W. Clarke, arrived in this port. She had as a prisoner the oyster schooner Albert Nickel of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--Special dispatches to the Times from Mount Vernon, Ill., say that a cyclone struck the town about 5 o'clock this afternoon. It swept away houses like cardboard and killed 15 or 20 people. Almost immediately fire broke out among the ruins and burned fiercely.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19.--Capt. James Watts of the lost ship John S. Berry, with 1 passenger and 13 of the crew of that ill-fated vessel, arrived here from Australia yesterday. His death was caused by blood poisoning following an operation by a corn doctor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--Capt. Edward F. Gardner, Assistant Surgeon, has been granted 21 days' leave of absence. First Lieut. Francis W. Mansfield, Eleventh Infantry, has been granted leave of absence until April 25.

DELAWARE BREAKWATER, Del., Feb. 20.--The bark Crown Jewel, (British,) from Oran, which arrived last night, rescued the Captain and crew of the water-logged schooner Edward C. Taulane, from Satilla River for New-York on Feb. 17, in latitude 35 18', longitude 73 10'.

MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Feb. 20.--Death and desolation won a terrible triumph last night. The cyclone slaughter has assumed appalling proportions, and it is doubtful whether the 31 dead bodies reported this evening is a complete list of the victims. Never before in the whole extent of the cyclone territory has such terrible devastation been visited on any community.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 22.--President Cleveland literaily did Savannah to-day "on the trot." He got here at 8:30 o'clock this morning, said he could not stay more than an hour, was put in a carriage, and, followed by carriages containing the rest of his party, drove through eight miles of streets, and got back to his train and was rolling out of the city in 64 minutes.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Feb. 22.--Theophilus Hackett, Jr., a young man, committed suicide at Columbia, a village a few miles from here, by an overdose of laudanum. He and a friend hired a conveyance in Easton on Saturday, drove to Columbia, and began a prolonged debauch. The dose was taken while mentally depressed. Hackett lived in Easton, where he was known as a fast young man. His parents are quite wealthy and move in good society.

HAVANA, Feb. 22.--The French Transatlantic Steamship Company has furnished its large fleet with complete apparatus for "dropping oil on the waves" during bad weather. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 26.--Wesley Willis, aged 21, quarreled with a neighbor to-day. Three officers attempted to arrest Willis. He ran and they fired, shooting him fatally through the back. His friends were enraged at the officers, and the feeling runs so high that they have been confined to avoid an outbreak.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26.--Charles Morris, a 16-year-old deaf mute, was struck by a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad between this city and Bordentown at 1 o'clock this afternoon. His head way taken off and he was literally cut to pieces. He was a pupil at the State school for deaf mutes, and had undertaken to walk to Bordentown for exercise. His parents live at Millville.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--The village of Valtarts, in the north of Italy, has been half buried by an avalanche. Many houses were wrecked and their occupants buried in the ruins. COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 27.--Col. E.B.C. Cash, the famous duelist and "fire eater," who killed Col. William M. Shannon, a prominent lawyer, in a duel in August, 1880, and who subsequently for 10 days defied the entire power of the State to arrest him, died at his home in Chesterfield County on Saturday of paralysis, aged 66 years.

The Board of Aldermen recently passed resolutions favoring the bill introduced in the Legislature providing for raising the salaries of Sergeants of Police. The Mayor vetoed this resolution yesterday, holding that the Board of Estimate and Apportionment had full power in the premises. Further the Mayor says: "So far as I know, there is no political party in this city that is not in favor of the doctrine of home rule in local affais."

SAN REMO, Feb. 28.--The sleep of the Crown Prince was disturbed in the early part of last night, but he slept well from 4 this morning until 8. LAS ANIMAS, Col., March 1.--Fred A. Hale, a prominent Denver architect, killed M.F. O'Reilly, a contractor, yesterday. O'Reilly had charge of the construction of the Court House. Hale was appointed to examine alleged faulty material used in the building and made an adverse report. Upon meeting, O'Reilly commenced an attack, when Hale pulled his revolver and O'Reilly fell, mortally wounded. At the Coroner's inquest Hale was exonerated.

The Stock Exchange began its dealings in oil yesterday under very favorable auspices. About 700,000 barrels were traded in.

PARIS, March 1.--M. Wilson, the son-inlaw of ex-President Grevy, who has been on trial for complicity in the Legion of Honor decoration scandals, has been convicted. He was sentenced to two years' imprisonment, to pay a fine of 3,000f., and to be deprived of his civil rights for five years.

Nothing could be learned from them as to what would be asked for, and very little information could be gained at the works.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 2.--Albert West, a young colored man, serving a sentence in the workhouse for an assault upon his father, this morning attacked Annias Stewart, the guard in the stone house, crushing his skull with a stone. Although Stewart was severely injured he fired upon the prisoner as he attempted to escape, and a bullet from his revolver took effect in West's heart, killing him instantly.

ALBANY, March 2.--Does Gov. Hill really wish his Quarantine nominations confirmed by the Senate? That was a question which was uppermost in many men's minds last night. BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 2.--The Jefferson County Jail probably holds more Christian negroes than any jail in the country, and instead of worldly songs and curses, the visitor now hears prayers and songs of praise. The reformation of the majority of the prisoners is due to the ghost of George Williams, who was hanged on Dec. 23. George was hanged for the murder of a fellow convict at Pratt Mines.

OTTAWA, March 2.--Postmaster-General McLelan says it is not true that American seedsmen will be discriminated against by the new parcel post convention. WASHINGTON, March 2.--Abram I. Jewell, a commission merchant of New-York and a member of the New-York Produce Exchange, appeared before the House Committee on Agriculture this morning. Up to 1878, he said, he had been in the lard business and had dealt largely in lard. His firm had been probably the first in the country to manufacture refined lard.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 2.--The bay colt Messenger Wilkes, 2 years, by Onward, dam Cuckoo, by Messenger Chief, has been sold by B. C. Alford of this city for $3,500 to E.H. Boardman of Grand Rapids, Mich.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 2.--The Farmers' Institute, under the auspices of the State Agricultural Society, closed a two days' session in this city to-night. Edwards were among the speakers. The farmers are well pleased with the institution.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 2.--A dispatch from Baracoa, 80 miles from Havana, states that a mother murdered her four children in cold blood. She chopped off the heads of two of them with a hatchet, and the other two she held in a tub of water until drowned, and then cut them up. She said when arrested and taken to jail that the devil tempted her to the crime.

John Reintz, while walking in College Point, Long Island, this evening was hooted at by a crowd of boys. Suddenly he turned, drew a revolver, and fired at them. CHICAGO, March 3.--Emma Lange, a 16year-old girl, committed suicide yesterday by taking poison. Thursday night the girl had staid out late with objectionable company and her father whipped her. This is the only reason known for her self-destruction, as she refused to talk after taking the poison further than to say that she wished to die.

The opening of the new Broadway Theatre last evening was one of the most brilliant theatrical events this city has ever seen. The house was thronged, the audience was an uncommonly interesting one to look at, and the beautiful auditorium was a resplendent sight. The new house received the approbation of every one present. Its decorations are novel, tasteful and showy.

"The King of Lumbermen" was a title enjoyed by Peter Herdic, who died Friday at the Glenham, in this city, when he was at the height of his power. PORT DEPOSIT, Md., March 3.--The Town Hall at Port Deposit, Md., owned by Jacob Tome, was destroyed by fire this morning, causing a loss of $12,000; insured for $10,000. JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 3.--Mrs. Gen. Grant arrived here this noon with Senator Stanford and party. After a very short stop in this city they left for St. Augustine where they will remain for two weeks. Mrs. Grant was in excellent health.

BRAINERD, Minn., March 3.--The burial party returned to-night from Little Falls, where the funeral services score held over the wife of Freight Agent W.S. Martin of the Northern Pacific. Three daughters and her husband survive her.
