GREAT FALLS, Montana, March 3.--It is stated on good authority that a company has been formed to establish extensive works for the reduction of copper ores here. It is understood that Boston parties who have mineral and railroad interests in Montana are interested. This enterprise is distinct from the Montana Smelting Company reduction works.

CHICAGO, March 3.--Quite a scare has been created at the city Bridewell, where 950 prisoners are confined, over the discovery of a case of smallpox yesterday. The victim is a man who came here from the East a few days ago and was sent out for vagrancy. He was promptly removed to the pest houes and yesterday 600 of the prisoners were vaccinated. The remainder Will be treated to day.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3.--Sebastian Jud, a Swede, had several of his fingers crushed in a stamping machine at the Meyer Rubber Works, last evening. He was taken to the office of Dr. C. M. SAN REMO, March 4.--At 10 o'clock tonight the German Crown Prince was unchanged. The patient passed a good night and a good day. Prince William has postponed his departure. He spends much time with his father.

LANESBOROUGH, Minn., March 4.--A singular series of deaths has occurred from natural causes in Amherst Township, this county, in the family of Jacob Vaught.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4.--Claus Spreckels and his son, A.B. Spreckels, the big California sugar refiners. were at the Continental Hotel to-day, where they were met by Francis R. Pemberton, President of the Pennsylvania Warehouse Company.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., March 4.--Miss Ettie Cleveland of Cassadoga, a school teacher, has been in poor health most of her life, which has lasted 35 years.

The Anti-Poverty Society, according to weekly custom, met last night at the Academy of Music and read from the Anti-Poverty journal of March 3, which was scattered about in the seats, that Dr. McGlynn would be the speaker of the evening and that Henry George was a Vice-President of the society.

LONDON, March 4.--There was an active demand for discount during the past week at 2@1 . The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 3@2 . Business on the Stock Exchange during the week was inactive, everything drooping. Foreign securities were heavily sold, especially Russians off German account. English railway securities were stagnant owing to the decline in traffic.

The March winds whistled across Macomb's Dam Bridge and sucked up the moisture on "the road" yesterday so vigorously that Seventh and Jerome avenues were turned into worse than corduroy roads. The air was so sharp that few persons, always excepting the old stagers whom nothing daunts, cared to make the drive to Gabe's and Judge Smith's.

TRENTON, March 4.--Next to the Local Option High License bill, which is now practically a law, the scheme of a system of new courts proposed by two bills introduced into the Assembly by Mr. Nixon of Cumberland is the most important matter that has been brought to the notice of the Legislature this year.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., March 4.--The breaker of the Glendower Colliery, situated about eight miles west of this city, and operated by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, was destroyed by fire this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--Having placed their own subordinates within the civil service rules, the Civil Service Commissioners propose to do the same with all clerical and messenger appointments under the General Government as rapidly as the interests of the service will permit.

How the members of the Knights of Labor will chuckle if the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers is beaten in its contest with the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company! Compromise or no compromise between the Knights and the brotherhood, they will chuckle. They are tickled beyond measure at the attitude now assumed by Arthur toward them.

An earthquake was distinctly felt at Massena, Norwood, and Potsdam about 4 P.M. Friday, the 2d inst. At Massena the rumbling was distinctly heard and the jarring felt. The regulating clock in the Jeweler's store stopped at the time of the shake.

BUFFALO, March 4.--The fight now being waged in the little city of Dunkirk, the metropolis of Chautauqua County, between the people on one hand and interested persons on the other is of greater importance than would appear on the surface.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Newman of 238 East Sixtieth-street celebrated their sliver wedding yesterday. They were remarried by the Rev. Dr. Heilbogen, and receive many valuable presents, one being a large silver pitcher, presented by the Lowell Literary Society.

General Passenger Agent Morton, who had done the talking for the company for a week, took a vacation over Sunday, his mantle falling temporarily upon George H. Ross, the Assistant General Freight Agent.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the acquittal of Squire and Flynn was roundly denounced. Resolutions were passed deploring the judicial farce, the prearranged end of which was the acquittal of politicians charged with high crimes against the people.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 4.--The brig John Welsh. Capt. Maloney, of Boston, from Norfolk for Boston with 300 tons of gas coal, ran ashore three miles west of the Point Judith LifeSaving Station last night and was discovered and reported by the surfmen at 1:30 this morning.

A west side pleasure party of 23 young men and women met with a serious mishap on the King's Bridge road at a late hour Saturday night. They were rolling homeward in a fourhorse conveyance, when they were suddenly precipitated down an embankment. None of the party escaped without bruises, and two persons were so badly hurt as to require hospital treatment.

Emil Roth, an Alsacian, living at 42 Hudson-street, committed suicide last evening by opening an artery in his left wrist and then cutting his throat with a razor.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 4.--Washington had a close call to-day and only succeeded in defeating the locals by a score of 3 to 2 by a batting streak in the last inning. The new butfielders, Wilmot and Hoy. did magnificent work. Ted Sullivan is satisfied with the team and has challenged the New-Yorks to play four games--one here, one in Mobile, and two in Atlanta; the game here to be next Thursday. Mutrie will probably accept.

The Republican State Committee will meet at the Fifth-avenue Hotel at noon March 15 to fix a time and place for holding a State Convention, at which delegates front this State may be elected to the republican National Convention.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5.--The appointment of ex-Lieut.-Gov. George G. Sill of this city as United States District Attorney for Connecticut, succeeding Lewis E. Stanton, who has held the office for the past three years, is highly creditable to the Administration.
MIDDLETON, N.Y., March 5.--About 25 years Kimball H. Dimmick, a native of NewYork, died at Los Angeles, Cal., while holding the post of United States Attorney for the Southern District of that State.
What looks like another attempt to get upon the eligible lists for appointment to the Brooklyn police force was discovered yesterday.

A bill was introduced in the Legislature a few days ago providing that all kinds of refuse, with the exception of garbage, may be dumped into Long Island Sound atany point exceeding a distance of 20 miles from the New-York City Hall.
Yesterday afternoon the sale of the Escosura collection was continued at the Bucken Art Galleries, 817 and 819 Broadway. The attendance was large and the bidding was spirited.

LONDON, March 5.--The steamship Suppicich (Br.) sld. from Palermo for New-York March 3.

ELLSWORTH, Me., March 5.--Frederick B. Aiken (Rep.) is elected Mayor over H.B. Mason (Dem.) by 181 majority, with one small outlying ward to hear from, which last year gave a small Republican majority. At least three of the five wards are Republican, showing heavy Republican gains from last year.
Judge Andrews has refused the application of Henry T. Krause for a mandamus to compel the Excise Commissioners to grant him a license to sell intoxicating liquors at 221 Washington-street.

Very quietly but none the less surely are steps being taken toward the consolidation of the elevated railroad interests in Brooklyn and the formation of a plan by which those interest when combined will work in harmony with the Long Island Railroad.
Charles Gaewitz, who lived at 619 East One Hundred and Forty-ninth-street, died suddenly Sunday night under circumstances which were remarkable enough to call for an investigation.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 5.--At a meeting of vessel owners here to-day it was unanimously agreed not to start any boat out of any port until May 1.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--The President has transmitted to Congress the remaining documents and protocols relating to the fisheries treaty, together with a letter from Secretary Bayard. In theory these were sent to both houses, but as is usual in such cases the inclosures (except the Secretary's letter) were sent only to the Senate.
The Rev. John Robinson, 82 years old, of NewBrighton, Staten Island, met with a serious accident in this city yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 5.--Railroad men here are by no means sanguine that the meeting of Western managers Thursday will lead to a speedy settlement of the rate war.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5.--Word has been received from Singapore that Robert Garrett of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, with his party and a retinue of servants, has arrived there. Garrett made a short stay in China, owing to the smallpox epidemic at the port at which he landed.
Mrs. Barbara Dalton of 418 West Fortyeighth-street recently bought a sewing machine from tha Domestic sewing Machine Company on the installment plan, but fell into arrears in the matter of payment.

The Irving "Faust" was viewed by a large audience at the Star Theatre last evening with respectful attention. The scenic features were admired, and the personal charm of Miss Terry manifested in her portrayal of Margaret had its usual effect.

Three boys, whose names are William Fox, John Murray, and John Fitzgerald, walked into the Oak-street police station on Sunday night and asked for lodging.

BOSTON, March 5.--"Bellman," Von Suppe's latest opera, was the announcement for the McCaull opera company's second week at the Park Theatre, where during the past week they gained many friends and drew large audiences by their admirable performances of "Boccaccio."
Maurice Barrymore watched the performance of "La Tosca" at the new Broadway Theatre on Saturday evening with a peculiar interest in the plot and situations.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5.--The ice yacht race for the prize for first-class yachts given by Judge Gildersleeve of New-York for yachts belonging to the Hudson River ice yacht clubs was sailed here to-day. Six boats participated. The prize was won by the Northern Light, owned by J.C. Barron. The course was about 13 miles, and the time was about one hour.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 5.--Mrs. Owen died at South Rondout to-day in her one hundredth year. She enjoyed vigorous health till about two years ago, when her physical and mental faculties began to fall. Mrs. Owen was a member of the Rondout Methodist Episcopal Church. Her reminiscences of the early-days of pioneer Methodism were interesting.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 5.--All the spinners in the Wamsutta Mills are out to-day.

A Coroner's jury yesterday rendered a verdict in direct contradiction to the evidence. The case was the inquest into the death of Maggie Curtin, a little girl who was run over and killed by a coal cart driven by Frederick Stockman.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 5.--Mutrie's NewYork Club struck a snag to-day in the NewOrleans team.

The conduct of some of the members of two committees of the Board of Aldermen has excited the suspicion that there exists in the present board a corrupt combination of which the notorious "boodle-combine" in the 1884 board is the prototype.

RICHMOND, Va., March 5.--In the early hours of the session of the Virginia Legislature, which is now about to expire, a proposition was made to appoint a committee to draft a memorial setting forth the reasons why the United States Government should carry out Mr. Blaine's suggestion and assume the debt of this State.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 5.--Baltimore has had many cool thieves in its history, but the well-dressed stranger who came to the city and stole Judge William A. Stewart's saw mill exceeded them all.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has just handed down a decision in the suit brought by Messrs. Cary and Wells to recover $5,000 from the Western Union Telegraph Company for soliciting and influencing certain members of the Legislature to secure the passage of a law by the Legislature relieving the company from certain taxation.

The New-Rochelle Yacht Club held its annual meeting last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. Charles Pryer, the Commodore of the club, called the meeting to order, and the club listened to detailed reports from the Secretary and Treasurer and from the Building and Regatta Committees.

A bill now pending in Congress, which has for its ostensible object the increase in weight of packages authorized to be transported through the mails from four pounds to eight, is the cause of much uneasiness among publishers, news agencies, mailing agencies, and Postmasters.

The March term of the Queens County Court and Court of Sessions began at Long Island City yesterday morning, Judge Garretson presiding. One of the most interesting cases on the civil calendar is that of John Cutter of Little Neck against Bloodgood H. Cutter, widely known as the Long Islands farmer-poet.

The contested will case of Harvey Sheldon was ended yesterday, principally on account of the discovery that there is nothing or little left of the estate. Harvey Sheldon, an old lawyer, who had been District Attorney of Onondaga County, married three wives.

James Tracey, 26 years old; who lives at 1,613 Second-avenue, walked into the outdoor department at Bellevue Hospital and complained of feeling ill. He was found to be suffering from smallpox, and was removed to the hospital on North Brother Island.

LONDON, March 5.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir Walter B. Barttelot (Conservative) moved the appointment of a royal commission to ascertain and report upon military measures necessary for the protection of the empire.
Railroad earnings reported yesterday for the closing weeks and the month of February made a fair showing.

The American Association held its annual Schedule Committee meeting in the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, yesterday. The corridors of the hotel were crowded with baseball players of all calibres, from the weather-beaten professional to the ambitious amateur.

CHICAGO, March 5.--While the Chairmen of the Grievance Committees of the enginemen of the Western roads were meeting in secret session at the Grand Pacific Hotel to-day everything was quiet at the headquarters of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Company.
The March Grand Jury was sworn in yesterday by Recorder Smyth. Henry A. Oakley of 10 West Tenth-street was made foreman.

Speyer Co., bankers of this city, have obtained an attachment against the firm of Seckendorf, Le Vino Co., hop merchants of Nuremberg, Germany, who have a branch at 31 Pearl-street, this city, for $13,683 balance of accounts. The attachment was based on the ground of non-residence, cable dispatches and newspaper reports of the firm's suspension.

Bertha Speck, a handsome young woman, lives at 7 Monroe-street, and has been in the habit of going to a saloon at Ridge and Houston streets. Here she fell in love with the bartender, Frederick William Hazelbeck. They agreed to get married.

WASHINGTON, March 5.--Some of the more intimate friends of Mr. S.J. Randall are infromed by that gentleman that he will to-morrow or Wednesday introduce his bill affecting, or proposing to affect, the revenues.

The great-grandchildren of Mrs. Agnes Allen Kissam called upon her yesterday at the residence of her son John, at 277 Sixth-avenue, Brooklyn, to congratulate her upon the attainment of her one hundredth birthday.

CHICAGO, March 5.--A Times special from Sioux Falls, Dakota, says that Bishop Hare, to whom Mrs. John Jacob Astor left $25,000 to be used for the Indiana under his care, has just returned from New-York, where he obtained from Mr. Actor $21,000 for a memorial church to be erected in Sioux Falls in memory of the late Mrs. Astor.
NYACK, N.Y., March 5--John Stagg attempted to cross the river on the ice here in the middle of January and was not afterward seen. His body was found under the ice at Piermont yesterday.

LONDON, March 5.--Count Herbert Bismarck will have an interview with Lord Salisbury to-morrow, and will urge him to give a more favorable consideration to Russia's proposals regarding Bulgaria. Count Herbert is expected to return to Berlin on Friday.

MOBILE, Ala., March 5.--The municipal election to-day was of moment as showing for the first time a contest between the old-time Democracy and the new labor movement. The negroes largely sided with the Democrats and worked steadily by the side of the whites, carrying the Democratic candidate by 1,500 majority.
DAYTON, Ohio, March 5.--The Dayton, Fort Wayne and Chicago is becoming more and more involved, and now appears to be wholly unable to extricate itself.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has affirmed the decision of Judge Barrett in the case of John E. Gill, whom Police Justice Solon B. Smith found guilty of conspiracy, and who, having been committed to the Tombs, obtained a writ of habeas corpus.

There is a strong probability that the Knights of Labor organization will find in a short time that there is power in organized capital as well as in organized labor, and that a labor organization may be boycotted successfully by organized industries.

The body of the young man who was on Sunday found lying dead in the woods near the Oakland Cemetery, Yonkera, was yesterday positively identified as that of young Dudley Arnoux of Brooklyn by his grandfather, Henry Dudley, an architect, whose place of business is at 49 Wall-street, this city.
MONTREAL, March 5.--The 4th of March is generally considered a critical day in financial circles, as a large amount of commercial paper matures upon that date.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 5.--Prof. William Thompson of the Hartford Theological Seminary is in a critical condition being unable to leave his rooms in Hosmer Hall.
John Cullen is building a factory at One Hundred and Seventh-street and First-avenue. James Madden is preparing the ground, and employed among his workmen John G. Callahan of 2,254 Second-aveune.
Col. Joseph Conrad, United States Army, is at the Grand Hotel.
The New-York Philharmonic Club will play at Chickering Hall this evening.

Two hundred and fifty Irish enthusiasts and patriots celebrated last night, in a banquet at Clarendon Hall, on Thirteenth-street, near Fourth-avenue, the twenty-first anniversary of the "Rising" of March 5, 1867.

The Woodside-section of Newark was the scene of a lively thief chase early yesterday morning. A number of burglaries have been committed in that locality, and Officer John Lambert, one of the pluckiest men on the force, was assigned to it in the hope that law would make an arrest.

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers is in great danger of forfeiting the sympathy and support of the public, which it has won by a ten years' record of prudence and good sense, by one gigantic mistake.

SAN REMO, March 5.--The Crown Prince passed a good night. His cough and expectoration have lessened. There is a more cheerful feeling regarding his immediate prospects. Prince William left San Remo to-day.

ALBANY, March 5.--It is reported here to-night that a meeting of the Republican State Committee will be called for the 15th inst., in New-York. The general opinion is that the committee will designate Syracuse as the place for holding the State Convention, and the middle of May as the time.

The second lecture of Course A of Mr. Stoddard's Lenten matinees at Daly's attracted an audience which filled the theatre from orchestra to gallery yesterday morning, and when the house was darkened to prepare for the exhibition of the pictures there was not a vacant seat in the house.

A fire broke out at 11 o'clock yesterday morning on the top floor of the seven-story building on the northeast corner of Vestry and Greenwich streets, and, although it was quickly subdued, a large loss was occasioned by fire and water.

Judge Barrett yesterday handed down a decision denying the application to vacate an order compelling Louis Sternberger, the Newstreet banker, to submit to an examination about his dealings with Casimir Hofmann, father of Josef Hofmann, the boy pianist.

KNOXVILLE, March 5.--The Louisville and Nashville Railroad has a large corps of engineers in the field surveying a line from Jellico to this city.

The Board of Excise yesterday addressed a letter, written by its-counsel, Charles H. Dayton, to the Mayors of cities, the Citizens' Committee on High License, the brewers, a number of wholesale liquor dealers, and the press, in order that it might obtain opinions upon which to base an excise bill that might be generally satisfactory. The suggestions offered by Mr. Dayton in this letter are approved by the Excise Board.

SOMERSET, Ky., March 5.--A frightful collision occurred on the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railroad at Pine Knot, Ky., about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, which resulted in the killing of one man, the fatal injuring of another, and the serious wounding of others, besides the damage to the railroad.
BELGRADE, March 5.--The election for members of the Skuptschina has resulted in the return of 130 Radicals and 19 Opposition candidates.

BALTIMORE, March 5.--Mayor Latrobe to-night vetoed the ordinance which the City Council passed to take the appointment of Baltimore and Ohio Directors from the Mayor and make them elective by the City Council.

Wong, accompanied by an American, went to 18 Mott-street on Monday, where a secret meeting of Chinese highbinders was going on. Bernard Roelker, who died at his residence, 17 East Twelfth-street, Monday afternoon, of pneumonia, was born April 24, 1816, at Osnabruck, Hanover. He received his education at the University of Bonn-on-theRhine, where he devoted himself largely to the studies of law and philology.

The Rockaway Hunting Club is very much disturbed by a letter from F. Gray Griswold, master of the hounds. It was written Feb. 28, and was addressed to the President, Dr. David L. Haight, but he was out of the city and did not get it until Monday.

SAN REMO, March 6.--The Crown Prince passed an excellent night. He coughed much less and there was a decided reduction in the throat discharge. He feels refreshed to-day. The weather is fine, and the Crown Prince spent the whole morning in the garden and had his lunch there. He walked considerable and feels much better.

VINCENNES, Ind., March 6.--The Rev. J. A. Asbury, one of the most prominent Methodist ministers of Indiana, was officiating at a funeral yesterday when he suddenly ceased preaching and fell forward with a gasp and died instantly. It was discovered that he had heart disease, and that in his ministerial labors he had overexerted, himself. Mr. Asbury was a much-esteemed minister, and his death caused a most profound shock.

Monday's stock market slumps were followed yesterday by rallies that brought about a much better and more confident feeling among the Wall-street contingent. Only three or four stocks showed declines, and those all fractional, while advances were general and some of them of consequence.

Dr. Charles Reed, who for 23 years has been a helpless invalid, died yesterday at his home, 792 Lafayette-avenue, Brooklyn. Since 1865 he has been affected with sciatica, and since 1872 spinal meningitis has increased his sufferings.

MORTIMER, Kan., March 6.--While John Geary, a farmer living near here, was at Kansas City last Saturday, his daughter eloped to Parsons and was married to a young man by the name of Parker, a son of a neighbor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6.--In the tallysheet forgery case to-day James D. Poston, President of the City Board of Elections, testified that H.J. Booth offered him $50 on the Sunday night after the election if he would induce Justice Martin of the Canvassing Board to go out and consult Judge Thurman.

DETROIT, Mich., March 6.--The bankers of Michigan are in a great state of ferment over the recent order of the Controller of the Currency requiring all bankers to report the amount of Canadian currency handled and circulated by them since the passage of a law in 1864, now construed to include such money.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6.--The debate on the High License Local Option bill has absorbed all of the interest and most of the attention of the Legislature to-day. The galleries of the Senate were crowded all day, while in the Assembly it was difficult to keep a quorum, so general was the interest in the discussion on the bill and its probable fate.

LONDON, March 6.--I get the statement to-night from inside diplomatic circles that Count Herbert Bismarck, when here the other day, said the German Crown Prince would probably live six weeks. The source from whence this comes is about the best that could be desired.

PARIS, March 6.--Some interesting details are published concerning the personal fortune of the Pope, which never will enrich his family. By the way, all he has done or ever will do for his own flesh and blood was to give the title of Count to his nephews and arrange for them honorable marriages.

DOVER, Del., March 6.--Dr. J.H. Parvis, a well-known physician of Middletown, was struck by the 7:30 south-bound Delaware train this evening and instantly killed. He was driving over the track at the time, the engine striking his carriage and throwing him a distance of over a hundred yards.

ST. LOUIS, March 7.--One railroad war hae been declared off. The Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific and the Chicago and Alton, which have been waging a bitter war for two months between here and Chicago, have settled their differences and agreed on a substantial advance in rates to go into effect next Monday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 7.--The congregation of the First Congregational Church in Branford celebrated the bi-centennial of that church to-day. It was established in 1688 and the Rev. John Russell was its first Pastor. A large number of clergymen were present and the church was beautifully decorated. The Rev. J.E. Twitchell, D.D., made the address of congratulation, and the Rev. H.B. Blake, the present Pastor, gave the history of the church.

BALTIMORE, March 7.--Mrs. Elizabeth Sands celebrated her ninety-ninth birthday to-day under very pleasant circumstances. There was a flow of visitors all day long and telegrams were received from Philadelphia, New-York, and other cities. Mrs. Sands has been twice married. She has two sons, 13 grandchildren, 45 great-grandchildren, and 19 great-great-grandchildren.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 7.--The new office of the Evening Union was burned out about 4 o'clock this afternoon. The blaze was attended with the most sickening horror ever witnessed in this city. At least six of the employes met a terrible death, most of them jumping from the fifth story and being crushed into a shapeless mass below.

SACO, Me., March 8.--Much anxiety is felt here regarding the schooner Delhi, of which Capt. Charles F. Green of Saco is master. She sailed from the West Indies for Wilmington, N. This is something very unusual for Rockland County.

There was little discussed in Stock Exchange houses yesterday but the news that came (or professed to come) from the sickroom of Germany's royal household. The miners already at work complain bitterly that the companies are taking advantage of their necessities and requiring them to work for less than was paid before the strike.

MITCHELL, Dakota, March 9.--Fire broke out in the Methodist University at 3 o'olock this morning from the spontaneous combustion of oily rags in the oil rooms. There were 40 inmates, including the Faculty, students, and servants. All but 10 escaped without trouble.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 9.--The Parliamentary committee on "Combines" met this morning and in a three hours' session examined Messrs. Lighbound and Mathewson of Montreal with respect to the sugar monopolies.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., March 9.--A premature explosion of a blast occurred in the stone quarry operated by the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company here last evening, frightfully mangling Foreman George Stuber and his 17-year-old nephew. Both died in a few hours in terrible agony.

EUFAULA, Ala., March 9.--The Daily Mail satin copy of Presidential anniversary issue of 12 pages, printed to-day and placed on exhibition, is pronounced a triumph of the printer's art, and the streets are thronged this afternoon with ladies inspecting it.

ST. LOUIS, March 9.--George R. Tozer, agent of the Missouri Pacific Railway Company at Hannibal, Mo., was indicted to-day under the inter-State commerce act for unjust discrimination. This is the first indictment under the act.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 9.--P.F. Laurence, a young society man, who had charge of the Toronto branch of Hanrahan Co.'s brokerage business, has taken his departure for New-York. There is a shortage in his accounts, and he has left many creditors behind him.
Fraulein Brandt's farewell matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House, announced for to-day, will be postponed until next Saturday on account of the death of the Emperor of Germany.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 9.--A negro named Will Thomas was lynched at Tunnell Hill, Ga., 20 miles south of this city, this afternoon. The negro assaulted Mrs. Eliza Anderson, a widow, Thursday afternoon.

MILLERSBURG, Ky., March 9.--Miss Annie Jones, Sam Jones's daughter, has left the Millersburg Ladies' College, where she has been completing her education. Miss Jones left suddenly, and did not explain her reasons.

The Committee on Railroads of the Board of Aldermen yesterday received from Roy Stone, the engineer of the Long Island Bridge Company, a protest against compensating this city for the required franchise.
WASHINGTON, March 9.--Major Israel O. Dewey, Paymaster, was to-day placed on the retired list of the army.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--President Young of the National Baseball League to-day appointed Mr. S.M. Decker of Bradford, Penn., to be a League umpire.

The Bijou Opera House property, fronting on Broadway and Sixth-avenue and comprising two lots on each thoroughfare, belongs to the James estate. Forty years ago there were twostory brick buildings on it and the site was in the suburbs.

Dr. F.R.S. Drake died yesterday morning, after a short illness, at his home, 8 West Thirtyfifth-street. Last Tuesday he was attacked with a sore throat, which was not considered serious until a few hours before his death, when a fatal heart complication set in.

Eadweard Muybridge, the inventor of photography of animals in motion, lectured before the members of the Union League Club last evening on the methods and results of his art. By means of the zoopraxiscope he reproduced upon a screen the acutal movements of men and women, as well as of horses and other quadrupeds and of birds. The lecture was very interesting, and was listened to by a delighted audience.

The body of the late Dr. Charles Reed of Lafayette-avenue, Brooklyn, who died on Tuesday, was cremated at Mount Olivet Crematory yesterday, in accordance with the wishes of the dead man. The widow and a number of her friends accompanied the body to the crematory and remained until it was placed in the retort.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 10.--George Brown, a white man, living in Bedford County, waylaid and shot his father-in-law, named Sanders, yesterday. Brown's wife had secured a divorce, and being afraid of violence sent for her father. On his arrival Brown shot him through the back. The entire neighborhood is aroused and a large party is hunting for the murderer. If caught he will be lynched.
